questions.text: A 25-year-old newly married woman wants effective contraception with a minimum failure rate. Which contraceptive method would be the most suitable for her considering both efficacy and ease of use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Implants

Explanation: 

Implants: The 3-year implant has one of the lowest failure rates at 0.05%, indicating high effectiveness. This method is suitable for a newly married woman who desires reliable contraception without daily adherence. The implant also offers long-term protection (up to 3 years) with minimal user intervention after insertion, making it convenient.

Oral Pills (Option B): Effective with perfect use (0.3% failure), but higher failure with typical use (8%) due to daily dosing and missed pills. Implants are preferred for better compliance and efficacy.

Condoms (Option C): Typical use failure rate is 15%, less reliable than implants. Offer dual protection (pregnancy & STIs), but not ideal for sole contraceptive use.

IUD (Option D): Low failure rates—levonorgestrel IUD (0.2%) and copper T (0.8%)—but can cause menstrual irregularities, dysmenorrhea, and pelvic pain. Implants are often favored.

Pearl Index: Measures contraceptive failure per 100 woman-years of exposure. Indicates community-level protection through family planning.

questions.text: A newborn presents with microcephaly, cleft lip and palate, and polydactyly. Cardiac evaluation reveals a ventricular septal defect. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B- Trisomy 13

The clinical presentation described in the question is most consistent with Trisomy 13, also known as Patau syndrome.

Clinical features of Trisomy 13 and Trisomy 18:

Feature

Trisomy 18 (Edwards Syndrome)

Trisomy 13 (Patau Syndrome)

Prenatal Findings

Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), polyhydramnios, single umbilical artery

IUGR, holoprosencephaly, omphalocele, polyhydramnios

Craniofacial Features

Micrognathia, low-set ears, prominent occiput

Cleft lip/palate, microphthalmia, holoprosencephaly, scalp defects

Extremities

Clenched hands with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet

Polydactyly, clenched hands, rocker-bottom feet

Cardiac Anomalies

Ventricular septal defect (VSD), patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), polyvalvular dysplasia

VSD, atrial septal defect (ASD), PDA, dextrocardia

Gastrointestinal Abnormalities

Omphalocele, malrotation

Omphalocele, umbilical hernia, imperforate anus

Genitourinary Anomalies

Horseshoe kidney, hydronephrosis

Polycystic kidneys, cryptorchidism, abnormal genitalia

Neurological Abnormalities

Severe intellectual disability, seizures, microcephaly

Severe intellectual disability, seizures, microcephaly, holoprosencephaly

Survival

Median survival is 3-14 days; <10%  survive beyond the first year

Median survival is 2.5 days;  <10% survive beyond the first year

Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) (Option A):

  • While Down syndrome can present with cardiac defects, it typically doesn't include microcephaly, cleft lip/palate, or polydactyly.
  • Common features include upslanting palpebral fissures, flat facial profile, and hypotonia.

Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) (Option B):

  • Trisomy 18 can present with similar cardiac defects and occasionally cleft lip/palate, but microcephaly and polydactyly are more characteristic of Trisomy 13.

Turner syndrome (45, X) (Option D)

  • Turner syndrome affects females and is characterized by short stature, webbed neck, and gonadal dysgenesis.
  • It doesn't typically present with the features mentioned in the question.

questions.text: A 12-year-old patient presents with a history of sinusitis and now has swollen, red eyelids, pain with eye movement, and restricted extraocular motion. There is no proptosis, and CT imaging shows diffuse inflammation of the orbital tissues without abscess formation. According to Chandler's classification, what is the most likely stage of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Orbital cellulitis

 

Explanation:

Orbital cellulitis involves inflammation of the orbital tissues with pain on eye movement and restricted mobility but without abscess formation. There is no proptosis or pus collection, which is consistent with Stage II of Chandler’s classification.

 

Chandler’s Classification of Orbital Cellulitis

Stage

Description

Key Features

I - Preseptal cellulitis

Infection confined to the eyelid

Eyelid swelling, no ocular involvement

II - Orbital cellulitis

Infection spreads to the orbit

Pain with eye movement, restricted mobility, no abscess formation

III - Subperiosteal abscess

Pus collection beneath periosteum

Localized pus, proptosis, pain on movement, swelling

IV - Orbital abscess

Pus collection within the orbital tissues

Severe proptosis, potential vision loss, risk of optic nerve damage

V - Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Spread of infection to the cavernous sinus

Bilateral eye involvement, headache, cranial nerve palsies

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a 15-year history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) presents with severe ocular pain, redness, and progressively worsening vision in her left eye for the past 2 weeks. Examination reveals a localized area of scleral thinning with adjacent congestion. There is no posterior involvement on B-scan ultrasound. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Necrotizing scleritis with inflammation

 

Explanation:

 

  • Severe pain, scleral thinning with adjacent congestion are hallmark signs of necrotizing scleritis, the most severe form of RA-associated scleritis.
  • RA leads to immune-mediated vasculitis, causing ischemic necrosis of the sclera.


 

Classification of Scleritis:

 

Anterior Staphyloma (Option A):

  • Anterior staphyloma is a late-stage complication, where uveal tissue bulges through a thinned, scarred sclera.
  • This patient has active inflammation, whereas staphyloma occurs after chronic necrosis and healing.

 

Nodular Scleritis (Option C):

  • Nodular scleritis presents with discrete, firm nodules on the sclera, without necrosis.
  • This patient has scleral thinning and avascular necrosis, which rules out nodular scleritis.

 

Scleromalacia Perforans (Option D):

  • Scleromalacia perforans is a form of necrotizing scleritis WITHOUT inflammation (painless, non-red eye).
  • This patient has severe pain and congestion, so active necrotizing scleritis is the correct choice.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with discomfort in her left breast. Mammography reveals a suspicious mass. Ultrasound-guided core needle biopsy is performed. Based on the histopathological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : D) Mucinous carcinoma

 

Explanation :

Mucinous or Colloid Carcinoma:

  • A subtype of infiltrating ductal carcinoma with Excellent prognosis.
  • Clinical findings:
    • Soft to firm lump due to mucilage.
    • It may be mistaken for a benign tumor.
  • Histopathology:
    • Gross: Soft, shiny, rubbery texture with pale gelatinous/jelly consistency.
    • Microscopy: Tumor cells arranged in clusters or islands with pools of mucin extracellularly and may be intracellularly (called signet ring cell).

  • FNAC: Chicken wire blood vessels (blood vessels get entangled in FNAC needle because of presence of mucin).
    • ​​​​​​​Chicken wire blood vessels is also seen in Oligodendroglioma, which is a brain tumor showing fried egg appearance on biopsy and Chicken wire blood vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following structures do not contain any ganglion cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Foveola

 

Explanation:

The foveola is the central part of the fovea and is unique in that it lacks ganglion cells, which allows for optimal light entry, contributing to high visual acuity. It contains only cones.

  • Macula lutea
    • Circular, 5–5.5 mm in diameter
    • Covers central 15–20° of visual field
    • Contains yellow pigments lutein and zeaxanthin
  • Fovea
    • Central depression of macula, ~1.5 mm diameter (same as optic disc)
  • Foveola
    • Central floor of fovea, ~0.35 mm diameter
    • Thinnest part of retina
    • Contains only cone photoreceptors & Müller cells (no ganglion cells)
  • Umbo
    • Central pit of foveola
    • Associated with foveolar light reflex (loss = early damage)
  • Foveal avascular zone (FAZ)
    • Vessel-free zone within fovea, ~0.6 mm diameter
    • Surrounded by capillaries
    • Best visualized by fluorescein angiography

questions.text: In newborns, phytomenadione is routinely administered to prevent hemorrhagic disease. However, its administration is contraindicated in the presence of a deficiency in which specific condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Protein C deficiency

Explanation:

  • Phytomenadione (Vitamin K1) is routinely given to newborns to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn (HDN), which occurs due to Vitamin K deficiency and can cause severe bleeding. However, its administration is contraindicated in newborns with Protein C deficiency, a rare inherited disorder that increases the risk of blood clots.
  • In these infants, Vitamin K can exacerbate clotting, leading to (Purpura fulminans) a life-threatening condition characterized by widespread blood clots and tissue necrosis.
  • But in most cases , as Protein C deficiency would go undiagnosed at birth, Vitamin K birth dose is almost always given.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency (Option A): This genetic disorder affects red blood cells and can lead to hemolytic anemia when exposed to triggers like certain medications. Vitamin K does not cause oxidative stress or hemolysis in G6PD deficiency.

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (Option B): This genetic disorder can lead to lung and liver disease but does not affect the safety of Vitamin K administration in newborns.

Cystic fibrosis (Option D): This genetic disorder affects the lungs and digestive system, leading to malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins like Vitamin K. Newborns with cystic fibrosis often need Vitamin K supplementation, making its administration necessary rather than contraindicated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with right-sided hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo has an MRI showing a mass at the right cerebellopontine angle from the vestibulocochlear nerve. Biopsy reveals encapsulated tissue with areas of dense cellularity and loose myxoid regions, as depicted in the image below. Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Associated with NF-1 gene mutation

NF1 (Neurofibromatosis type 1)

  • Gene: NF1 gene on chromosome 17

  • Protein: Neurofibromin (tumor suppressor)

  • Features:

    • Multiple café-au-lait spots

    • Cutaneous neurofibromas

    • Lisch nodules (iris hamartomas)

    • Optic gliomas

NF2 (Neurofibromatosis type 2)

  • Gene: NF2 gene on chromosome 22

  • Protein: Merlin (schwannomin)

  • Features:

    • Bilateral vestibular (acoustic) schwannomas – 8th cranial nerve

    • Meningiomas, ependymomas

Histology & IHC of Schwannoma

  • Antoni A and B areas: dense cellular vs loose hypocellular regions

  • Verocay bodies: parallel rows of palisaded nuclei with fibrillary processes between → characteristic of schwannoma

  • S100 positivity: marker of neural crest origin (seen in schwannomas & neurofibromas

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with hypertension and T2DM presents with right sided weakness in arm and leg with progressive cognitive decline for the past 1 year. On examination: MMSE: 20/30, Mild right-sided weakness and hyperreflexia. MRI brain shows periventricular white matter hyperintensities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Vascular dementia

  • The presence of features of stroke for last one year with dementia and low MMSE score points to diagnosis of VD. Option A will not have cognitive decline. Option B is seen in preterm babies. Option D will not present over one year.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Cryptococcus gattii except?

choices.text: C. gattii is commonly found in Tropical and subtropical parts
It corresponds to the serotypes B and C
C. gattii inhabits around eucalyptus tree

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) It primarily affects immunocompromised individuals

 

Explanation:

Cryptococcus gattii is known for causing infections primarily in immunocompetent individuals, which distinguishes it from Cryptococcus neoformans, which mainly affects immunocompromised patients.

 

  • Commonly found in tropical and subtropical regions, particularly around eucalyptus trees (Options A and C ruled out)
  • It corresponds to the serotypes B and C (Option B ruled out)
  • C. gattii can cause severe respiratory illnesses and can disseminate to the CNS, leading to cryptococcal meningitis.
  • Diagnosis is typically made through microscopy, culture, serological tests for cryptococcal antigen, and imaging studies for lung lesions.
  • Treatment usually involves antifungal medications, such as amphotericin B and fluconazole, depending on the severity of the infection.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with intermittent chest pain and difficulty swallowing for the past few months. The chest pain is often severe and mimics angina but is not related to exertion. His symptoms often occur at night. Barium swallow reveals a typical finding given below. Which of the following disorders is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Diffuse esophageal spasm

 

Explanation:

 

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm (DES)

 

Definition

Uncoordinated, simultaneous contractions of the esophagus with normal LES function.

Clinical Features
  • Dysphagia (solids and liquids)
  • Severe chest pain
  • Less common regurgitation
  • Globus sensation

Investigations

Esophageal Manometry: Multiple simultaneous non-peristaltic contractions with an amplitude of > 30 mmHg; normal LES pressure and relaxation.
 

Barium Swallow (Esophagram): "Corkscrew" or "Rosary bead" appearance.

(Option A)
 

Endoscopy: Generally normal mucosa; rule out structural abnormalities.

Management

Non-Pharmacological: Dietary Modifications (smaller, frequent meals)
 

Pharmacological:

  • Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., nifedipine)
  • Nitrates (e.g., isosorbide dinitrate)
  • Botulinum Toxin Injection
 

Surgical:

  • Esophageal Myotomy (rare)
  • Peroral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM)
 

Endoscopic: Dilation (less effective)

questions.text:
A forensic surgeon is examining a stab wound on a victim. Which of the following statement/s is/are true about the dimensions of the wound?

 

1. Breadth of the wound is equal to the thickness of the weapon.

2. Depth is the greatest dimension of a stab wound.

3. The edges of the wound are clean-cut.

4. The length of the wound is usually slightly less than the width.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 2, 3, and 4

Explanation:

Wound description: when describing a stab wound, it’s important to note the length, width, direction, and appearance of the wound's margins and angles.

 

Margins:

  • The edges of the wound are clean-cut (statement 3) and typically show no abrasion or bruising.
  • In cases of full blade penetration, a patterned abrasion or bruising may occur due to the hilt guard striking the skin.
  • The margins are regular, sharp, and well-defined; however, wounds caused by pointed or conical instruments may have lacerated edges.

 

Length:

  • The length of the wound is usually slightly less than the width (statement 4) of the weapon because of skin stretching.

 

Breadth:

  • The breadth is generally greater than the thickness of the blade (statement 1) due to gaping; proper approximation of the edges is necessary for accurate measurement.

 

Depth:

  • Depth is the greatest dimension of a stab wound (statement 2) and corresponds to the length of the weapon entering the body.
  • If the entire length of the weapon penetrates without producing an exit wound, this depth is critical.

 

Safety note:

  • It is unsafe to determine the depth of a stab wound by probing in the emergency room, as this can disturb any loose clot and lead to severe hemorrhage.
  • Probing may also create a false track by passing between fascial planes or within muscles.
  • Depth assessment should be conducted in the operating theater during wound repair.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with acute diarrhoea after returning from a trip from southeast Asia. Laboratory tests confirm an infection with enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC). Which of the following peptides is most likely influenced by this bacterial toxin?
questions.solution:
Guanylin is the peptide hormone that is influenced by Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC).

  • Guanylin promotes fluid absorption in the small and large intestines.
  • Serum ProGuanylin levels indicate intestinal guanylin levels and reflect intestinal fluid balance.
  • Heat-Stable Enterotoxin of E. coli:
    • Activates guanylyl cyclase enzyme, thus increasing cGMP levels.
    • It reduces intestinal guanylin levels.
    • This results in excessive water and electrolyte secretion into the GIT lumen, leading to secretory diarrhoea.

 

Motilin (Option A): This is involved in stimulating gastric and small intestine motility during fasting. It helps initiate and regulate migratory motor complexes and is not typically influenced by E. coli.

 

Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) (Option C): VIP can induce intestinal water and electrolyte secretion, but it is not specifically targeted by E. coli enterotoxins. VIP-induced diarrhoea is seen in VIPomas.

 

Calcitonin gene receptor peptide (CGRP) (Option D): CGRP is involved in somatostatin release, which is an inhibitor of GIT secretion; it also causes smooth muscle contraction

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman visits her dentist with swelling and pain in her left lower jaw, along with difficulty chewing. She reports persistent bone pain, weakness, and fatigue. Recently, she has experienced kidney stones. X-rays of her jaw are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the findings in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Brown's tumour

 

Explanation:

Brown's tumor is a manifestation of hyperparathyroidism (either primary or secondary), resulting from excessive osteoclast activity. The clinical presentation of bone pain, kidney stones (due to hypercalcemia), and the X-ray showing a well-defined radiolucent lesion in the affected bone are consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Brown's tumour

  • A Brown’s tumour, also referred to as osteitis fibrosa, cystica generalisata, or Von Recklinghausen’s disease of bone, is a metabolic bone condition that can occur in primary, secondary, or tertiary hyperparathyroidism.
  • Brown's tumours are expansile lytic lesions associated with increased osteoclast activity, which can affect the mandible and is consistent with the patient's symptoms and X-ray findings.
  • Brown tumors are not true tumors; instead, they are reparative granulomas (form as a part of the healing process rather than being actual cancerous growths).
  • The most common sites include ribs, clavicle and pelvis. But they can occur anywhere- even in the mandible/maxilla/phalanges.
  • Clinical features: Bone pain, fractures, kidney stones, headache, constipation, paraesthesia.
  • Histological features:
    • Vascular fibroblastic stroma
    • Osteoclast-like multinucleated giant cells
    • Hemorrhagic areas with hemosiderin deposits.

Osteosarcoma (Option A) typically presents with aggressive bone pain and swelling and shows bimodal age presentation (occurs in teenagers and older adults after 65 years of age). It is characterized by the formation of a mass rather than the cystic changes seen in brown tumours.

 

Osteoclastoma (Option C) (giant cell tumour) typically occurs around the knee and is characterized by lytic lesions, but is less common in the jaw and does not fit the overall clinical picture.

Osteoid Osteoma (Option D) usually presents with localized pain relieved by salicylates and appears as a small nidus on imaging. It is not associated with the symptoms or location described in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true regarding demographic gifts?

choices.text: It occurs when there is a significant increase in the working-age population.
It involves a higher proportion of elderly individuals.
It leads to a demographic dividend for economic development.
It is associated with a decline in dependency ratios.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It involves a higher proportion of elderly individuals

Explanation: The higher proportion of elderly individuals refers to demographic liability.

 

Demographic Gift

Demographic Liability

The demographic gift occurs when the working-age population is high relative to dependents.

The higher proportion of elderly individuals refers to demographic liability.

Represents a potential demographic dividend due to a larger workforce contributing to economic growth.

Represents potential economic challenges due to increased dependency ratios and healthcare costs

Contributors include higher productivity, increased savings, and economic growth

Dependents include retirees, elderly individuals, and those requiring significant healthcare

questions.text: A 50-year-old male smoker presents with a painless swelling in the parotid region. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) reveals murky fluid. Which of the following histopathological features is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Proliferation of squamous epithelial cells with keratinisation

questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation (history of chronic smoking) and histopathological image (Murky fluid on FNAC) suggest a Warthin tumour or Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, a benign salivary gland tumour that typically occurs in the parotid gland.
  • On histopathology it is characterised by:
    • Pink coloured oncocytic cells, which are double-layered.
    • Deep blue coloured lymphocytes.
  • Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum:
    • Papillary: Shows papillary projections
    • Cyst: Cyst which is filled with murky fluid which is aspirated on FNAC.
    • Adenoma: Because it is a benign tumor
    • Lymphomatosum: It contains significant lymphoid components.
  • It is seen in chronic smokers and commonly involves bilateral parotid glands.
  • This characteristic appearance is often referred to as "Cystic oncocytic hyperplasia."

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Proliferation of squamous epithelial cells with keratinisation (Option A): Seen in pleomorphic adenoma

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of gout presents to the clinic with increased frequency of gout attacks. His daily medications include rosuvastatin, low-dose aspirin and losartan for hypertension. He has been advised to avoid certain medications that can exacerbate his gout. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aspirin

Explanation:

Aspirin affects renal handling of uric acid in two ways:

  • High doses (>3 g/day): Uricosuric effect (blocking urate reabsorption).
  • Low doses (<2 g/day): Uric acid retention (inhibiting urate secretion).

Gout triggers can include alcohol, red meat, and certain medications. 

Drugs causing gout

Drugs beneficial in gout

Mnemonic – PAINED

  • P: Pyrazinamide
  • A: Aspirin (Normal dose <2 gms)
  • I: Immunosuppressive: Cyclosporine
  • N: Niacin
  • E: Ethambutol
  • D: Diuretic like loop diuretics, thiazides

Mnemonic – FALSe

  • F: Fenofibrate
  • A: Aspirin in toxic dose >5 gm
  • L: Losartan (OPTION B)
  • Se: Statins (Pravastatin, rosuvastatin) (OPTION D)

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman is being assessed for suspected appendicitis. An abdominal ultrasound shows inflammation but in limited detail. What is the best contrast agent to enhance USG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Sulfur Hexafluoride microbubbles

  • In contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS), microbubbles or microspheres, such as those found in Sonovist and Levovist, contain sulfur hexafluoride gas encapsulated in a phospholipid shell.
  • These microbubbles improve the visualization of blood flow and enhance the imaging of vascular structures and lesions.
  • Another type of microbubble in CEUS consists of octafluoropropane gas within a phospholipid shell.

 

Contrast agents for USG

Examples
  • Sonovue (sulfur hexafluoride)
  • Lumason (sulfur hexafluoride)
  • Definity (perflutren)
  • Sonozoid (perflubutane)

Preferred route

Intravenous

Eliminated by

Lungs (hence safe in Renal conditions)

Indications
  • Liver lesions
  • Micturating cystosonography
  • Renal lesions
  • Obstruction in Crohn's disease
  • Evaluation of Aortic aneurysm repair

Adverse Effects

It is the safest contrast media and rarely causes mild anaphylactoid reactions.


 

Barium sulfate (Option A) is the most commonly used contrast agent for identifying gastrointestinal tract issues such as ulcers, tumours, strictures, or inflammation. It is not water-soluble and is given orally or rectally.

 

Iodinated contrast agents (Option B) are water-soluble and are widely used for X-rays, CT scans, and interventional radiology. However, they are highly nephrotoxic and should be used with caution in patients with renal impairment only after evaluating renal function.


Saline solution (Option C) enhances the visualisation of internal structures, such as in saline infusion sonohysterography and hysterosalpingo-contrast sonography, which is mixed with air to improve the visibility of fallopian tubes and identify peritoneal spills.

questions.text: All of the following physiological changes in the cardiovascular system during pregnancy increase except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: Option B

Explanation

Blood pressure reduces because there is decrease in peripheral systemic vascular resistance due to the vasodilation in pregnancy 

Note - Ejection fraction in normal pregnancy remains unchanged.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents with early breast development and pubic hair growth. Which among the following investigations can differentiate between central and peripheral causes of precocious puberty?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) GnRH stimulation test

Explanation:

The GnRH stimulation test is used to differentiate between central and peripheral causes. 100 µg of GnRH is adminis­tered (SC), and the serum level of LH is measured. A Value Of LH >15 mIU/mL suggests gonadotropin-dependent (central) precocious puberty.

  • In Central Precocious Puberty, GnRH stimulation significantly increases LH and FSH levels, resulting in elevated estrogen levels.
  • In Peripheral Precocious Puberty, these levels will not increase significantly because of negative feedback by the exogenously produced estrogen.

Central (True precocious puberty)

Peripheral precocious puberty
  • Premature activation of the HPO axis
  • Elevated LH (diagnostic)
  • Elevated FSH (diagnostic)
  • Elevated estrogen
  • Due to an increase in estrogen, puberty is always isosexual
  • Due to the exogenous production of estrogen
  • Isolated elevated estrogen and elevated androgen.
  • Negative feedback on LH and FSH
  • Due to:
    • Elevated estrogen: Isosexual
    • Elevated androgen: Heterosexual

Causes:

  • 90% idiopathic
  • 10% brain tumor (hamartoma of tuber cinerum)

Always do an MRI scan

Causes:

  • Elevated estrogen
    • Granulosa cell tumor
    • Hypothyroidism (Alpha subunit similar to LH and FSH).
    • McCune Albright syndrome
  • Elevated androgen
    • Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor (androgen-secreting tumor of ovary)
    • CAH (Congenital adrenal hyperplasia)

 

Basic investigations in precocious puberty:

  • Serum hCG, FSH, LH, and prolactin (A baseline prepubertal LH level of greater than 0.3 IU/L is suggestive of Central Precocious Puberty).
  • Thyroid profile (TSH, T4).
  • Serum estradiol, testosterone, 17-OH progesterone, DHEA.
  • USG, CT, or MRI of the abdomen and pelvis to rule out pathology of ovaries, adrenals, or uterus.
  • Skull X-ray, CT scan, or MRI brain—to exclude intracranial lesions (hypothalamic hamartoma).
  • Electroencephalogram (EEG): Abnormal EEG is often associated with CNS disease.
  • X-ray hand and wrist (nondominant) for bone age.
  • GnRH stimulation test

Bone age assessment (Option A): In cases of precocious puberty, bone age is usually advanced beyond the child's chronological age, indicating early hormonal influence on bone growth. However, it does not differentiate between central and peripheral precocious puberty.
 

Pelvic ultrasound (Option B): It can identify ovarian cysts or tumours that might be responsible for peripheral precocious puberty, but it only rules out ovarian pathologies.
 

Serum estradiol levels (Option D): It does not differentiate between central and peripheral causes of precocious puberty.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the sequence of events during gastrulation in the third week of gestation?

choices.text: Epiblast cells form the primitive streak, leading to the formation of the three germ layers.
The primitive streak forms at the cephalic end, initiating neural tube, gut, and cardiovascular development.
The prechordal plate forms after the notochord, and epiblast cells migrate to create the three germ layers.
The Endoderm forms from mesodermal cells, with ectoderm and mesoderm forming later.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Epiblast cells form the primitive streak, leading to the formation of the three germ layers.

 

Explanation:

  • During gastrulation, epiblast cells migrate to form the primitive streak.
  • This migration leads to the differentiation of epiblast cells into the three germ layers: endoderm, mesoderm, and ectoderm. 

Start of Process
  • Formation of the primitive streak on the surface of the epiblast.

Primitive Streak
  • Initially indistinct, it becomes a narrow groove with bulging regions by days 15-16.

Primitive Node
  • Located at the cephalic end of the streak, a slightly raised area surrounding a small pit.

Cell Migration
  • Epiblast cells migrate toward the primitive streak and undergo invagination.

Invagination
  • Cells transform into flask-shaped forms, detach from the epiblast, and move beneath it.

Regulation
  • Fibroblast growth factor 8 (FGF8) regulates cell movement and mesoderm formation.
  • FGF8 decreases E-cadherin levels, which helps in migration

Cell Spread
  • Invaginated cells replace the hypoblast and spread laterally and cranially.

Contact with Extraembryonic Mesoderm
  • Cells establish contact with the extraembryonic mesoderm covering the yolk sac and amnion.

Prechordal Plate
  • Forms between the notochord tip and the oropharyngeal membrane.
  • Important for forebrain induction.

Oropharyngeal Membrane
  • Composed of tightly joined ectoderm and endoderm cells.
  • Will become the future oral cavity opening.

Formation of Germ Layers
  • Endoderm: Displaces the hypoblast.
  • Mesoderm: Forms between the epiblast and endoderm.
  • Ectoderm: Develops from the Remains of the epiblast.

Outcome
  • The epiblast gives rise to all embryonic tissues and organs through the process of gastrulation.

questions.text: In unresectable or metastatic Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans (DFSP), which targeted therapy is considered the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Imatinib

 

Explanation:

  • Imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, is the drug of choice for unresectable or metastatic Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans (DFSP) when surgery is not feasible.
  • Targets the COL1A1-PDGFB fusion protein present in most DFSP cases.
  • Effectively inhibits tumour growth.
  • Shown significant efficacy in clinical trials for unresectable or metastatic DFSP.

Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans (DFSP):

  • It is a rare, low-grade sarcoma of the dermis.
  • It is characterised by slow growth and local aggressiveness but rarely metastasises.
  • Clinical features: It presents as a firm, painless plaque or nodule on the trunk or extremities, often mistaken for a benign lesion initially.
  • Pathology: Translocation resulting in COL1A1-PDGFB fusion.
  • Treatment:
    • Surgery with wide local excision or Mohs micrographic surgery is the primary treatment.
    • Targeted therapy with imatinib is used for unresectable or metastatic cases.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is admitted with a traumatic brain injury and is being evaluated for brain death. Her core body temperature is 36.5°C, and her systolic blood pressure is 95 mm Hg despite volume resuscitation. Neuromuscular blocking agents were recently administered. Which of the following should be done before proceeding with the brain death diagnosis?

choices.text: Administer vasopressors to increase systolic blood pressure above 100 mm Hg and wait for drug clearance before proceeding.
Perform brainstem reflex testing immediately since her core temperature is adequate.
Reduce the temperature to less than 36°C to continue with the exam.
Start administering antidotes for neuromuscular blockade and proceed with the diagnosis.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Administer vasopressors to increase systolic blood pressure above 100 mm Hg and wait for drug clearance before proceeding.

 

Explanation:

  • Before deciding to proceed with the diagnosis of brain death, several conditions must be evaluated and met.
  • In this scenario, the patient’s systolic BP should be >100 mmHg to meet the criteria, and administering vasopressors would help stabilize the blood pressure to meet the required threshold.
  • The team must wait for five half-lives of drug clearance (adjusted for the patient's renal and hepatic function) to ensure the drugs (neuromuscular agent) have cleared, as they can interfere with the neurologic exam by paralyzing the patient, falsely mimicking brain death.

 

Pre-evaluation for brain death:

Several conditions must be evaluated and met before deciding to proceed with the diagnosis of brain death.

  • The cause of the coma must be identified.
  • Any confounding factors, such as severe metabolic, endocrine, or acid-base abnormalities, should be ruled out and corrected.
  • If drug intoxication or recent use of neuromuscular blocking agents is suspected, it is necessary to wait for five half-lives of drug clearance, adjusted for the patient’s kidney and liver function. (Option B & D ruled out)
  • The patient's core body temperature should be above 36°C. (Option C ruled out)
  • The systolic blood pressure must be higher than 100 mm Hg, with vasopressors administered if required.
  • A neurologic examination suggests widespread cortical destruction that is reflected by deep coma and unresponsiveness to all forms of simulations and should include testing for brainstem reflexes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with chronic nasopharyngeal discomfort and intermittent nasal obstruction. Imaging studies reveal a midline cystic structure in the nasopharynx. The patient is diagnosed with Thornwaldt's disease. Which of the following anatomical remnants is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Remnant of the notochord

Explanation:

The persistence of notochordal remnants can lead to the formation of midline cystic structures in the nasopharynx, which is consistent with Thornwaldt's disease.

 

Thornwaldt's disease

  • Thornwaldt’s bursa is an epithelial-lined recess in the nasopharynx, representing a remnant of the attachment of the notochord to the endoderm of the pharynx during early development.
  • Thornwaldt’s disease is characterised by a midline nasopharyngeal cyst resulting from the persistence of a remnant of the notochord.
  • It presents with persistent postnasal discharge or crusting, nasal obstruction, dull occipital headache, low-grade fever, recurrent sore throat, obstruction to the eustachian tube and serous otitis media.

Remnant of Rathke’s pouch (Option A): Rathke’s pouch is an embryonic structure that forms the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland. Remnants of Rathke’s pouch typically result in Rathke’s cleft cysts, which are located in the sellar region of the skull and are not related to the nasopharynx.

Remnants of pharyngeal clefts (Option B) usually lead to branchial cleft cysts or sinuses, which are typically located along the lateral neck or anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. They are not associated with midline cystic lesions in the nasopharynx.

Persistence of the Thyroglossal Duct (Option D): The thyroglossal duct is a temporary embryonic structure that connects the thyroid gland to the base of the tongue. It normally obliterates after development, but when it fails to do so, it can form a thyroglossal cyst, which typically appears as a midline neck mass.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Global Hunger Index?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Infant mortality rate

Explanation:

  • The Global Hunger Index (GHI) does not include the Infant mortality rate.
  • It measures three dimensions of hunger:
    • Food availability (Option D)
    • Child's nutritional status (Option B) 
    • Child mortality due to undernutrition (Option C)
  • It includes three equally weighted indicators(arithmetic mean): 
    • The proportion of people who are food energy-deficient (FAO estimates)
    • Prevalence of underweight children under 5 years (WHO data)
    • Mortality rate of children under 5 years (UNICEF reports)

In 2022, India's GHI rank was 107 out of the 121 countries with sufficient data to calculate 2022 GHI scores. With a score of 29.1, India has a serious level of hunger.

questions.text: Which BNS section denotes that consent given by an insane person is invalid?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) 28 BNS / IPC 90

 

Explanation:

The consent given by an insane or intoxicated person, who is unable to understand the nature and consequences of that to which he gives his consent is invalid ( 28 BNS / IPC 90 )

 

Provisions under the Act

BNS Section

Corresponding IPC Section

Any act done without intent to cause death or serious harm, but done with consent, is not considered an offense.

25 (Option A)

87

An act done in good faith with the consent of the person, for their benefit, is not an offense.

26 (Option B)

88

An act done in good faith for the benefit of a child under 12 years old or an insane person, with the consent of a guardian, is not an offense.

27

89

Consent is invalid if:

  • Given under fear or misconception
  • Given by an insane person

28 (Option C)

90

The exceptions under sections 25, 26, and 27 do not apply to acts that independently constitute offenses, or are intended or likely to cause harm to the person giving consent or on whose behalf consent is given.

29

91

Acts done in good faith without consent are permissible in the following situations:

  • During an emergency
  • When the person is incapable of giving consent
  • When there is no guardian to give consent

30 (Option D)

92

Acts causing slight harm are not considered offenses.

33

95

questions.text: Which stimulation pattern is specifically designed to assess deep neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Post Tetanic Count (PTC) stimulation

Explanation:

Post Tetanic Count (PTC) stimulation is used to assess deep levels of neuromuscular blockade that are not detectable by TOF stimulation.

 

Patterns of Nerve Stimulation for the evaluation of the neuromuscular function:

Stimulation Pattern

Mechanism

Interpretation

Clinical Implication and Limitation

Single-Twitch Stimulation

(Option B)

Single electrical stimulus applied at a frequency of 0.1 Hz to 1 Hz.

Requires comparison to pre-NMBA administration value.

Muscle response to the stimulus reflects neuromuscular block onset; changes in twitch height help assess blockade.

Used to evaluate onset of neuromuscular block.

Limited utility as a standalone test.

Train-of-Four (TOF) Stimulation

(Option A)

Four supramaximal stimuli delivered at 0.5-second intervals (2 Hz).

Fade between responses indicates degree of block.

TOF count assesses onset.

TOF ratio measures recovery.

Fade suggests nondepolarizing block.

Most common pattern for intraoperative monitoring.

Cannot measure deep block or phase I block.

Double-Burst Stimulation (DBS)

(Option D)

Two bursts of 50-Hz stimulation with a 750-ms interval.

Fade between the two bursts indicates block.

Fade between bursts correlates with TOF ratio.

DBS is more sensitive for detecting fade.

Better tactile detection of residual block than TOF but cannot reliably assess recovery at higher TOF ratios.

Tetanic Stimulation

High-frequency stimulation (50-100 Hz for 5 seconds) causing sustained muscle contraction.

Fade indicates nondepolarizing block; sustained response suggests normal transmission or depolarizing block.

Painful and limited use in practice.

May cause lasting muscle antagonism, affecting recovery assessment.

Post Tetanic Count (PTC) Stimulation

(Option C)

Tetanic stimulation (50 Hz for 5 seconds) followed by single twitches at 1 Hz after 3 seconds.

Counts discernible twitches after tetanic stimulation; assesses deep block not detectable by TOF.

Used for monitoring deep neuromuscular blockade.

Requires 6-minute intervals, limiting continuous use.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with complaints of a yellowish-green, foul-smelling vaginal discharge. She reports painful urination and pain during intercourse & no itching. On speculum examination, her vulva and vaginal walls appear inflamed. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Trichomonas vaginalis

 

Explanation:
Trichomonas vaginitis is the most common cause of vaginitis in women of reproductive age.

Symptoms include :

  • Sudden, profuse, yellowish-green, frothy, foul-smelling discharge
  • Irritation and itching in and around the vaginal opening
  • Painful urination
  • Pain during intercourse
  • Recurrent infections
  • Inflamed vulva
  • Inflamed vaginal walls with small, punctate hemorrhages ("strawberry cervix")

 

Candida albicans (Option B):

  • Characterized by a scanty, white, curdy vaginal discharge
  • Intense vulvovaginal itching present leading to erosions causing splash dysuria and dyspareunia

Gardnerella vaginalis (Option C):

  • Characterized by a foul-smelling, thin, gray-white, or green-yellow vaginal discharge
  • Absence of itching, dysuria, or dyspareunia

Neisseria gonorhhea (Option D):

It does not typically cause vaginitis alone. It can cause cervicitis, whose symptoms can overlap with that of vaginitis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents to the orthopedic OPD with a four-month history of left knee pain, which worsens with activity and at night. She has had episodes of low-grade fever and fatigue but denies any recent trauma. Upon physical examination, the left knee has limited range of motion and noticeable soft-tissue swelling. An image of the X-ray of the left knee joint is shown below. What is Phemister’s triad, and how does it relate to this case?

choices.text: A triad of symptoms indicating septic arthritis
A triad of radiological findings indicating tuberculous arthritis
A set of criteria for diagnosing osteosarcoma
A triad of radiological criteria for diagnosing Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A triad of radiological findings indicating tuberculous arthritis

 

Explanation: Phemister’s triad of juxta-articular osteopenia/osteoporosis, peripheral osseous erosions, and joint space narrowing suggests tuberculous arthritis but is nonspecific.

X-ray findings:

  • Characteristic signs are soft-tissue swelling and periarticular osteoporosis.
  • Bone ends appear ‘washed-out,’ and the articular space narrows.
  • In children, epiphyses may enlarge due to prolonged hyperemia.
  • Subarticular bone erosion occurs on both sides, indicating synovial inflammation.
  • Cystic lesions may appear in adjacent bone ends.
  • Little to no periosteal reaction, unlike a pyogenic infection, where reactive periosteal new bone formation is an important feature.
  • Phemister’s triad of juxta-articular osteopenia/osteoporosis, peripheral osseous erosions, and joint space narrowing suggests tuberculous arthritis but is nonspecific. (Option B)

 

A triad of symptoms indicating septic arthritis (Option A): Septic arthritis typically presents with sudden onset of joint pain, swelling, and fever, often with systemic signs of infection. The radiological findings associated with septic arthritis usually include joint effusion, slight subluxation, and periosteal reaction but do not specifically include Phemister’s triad. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

A set of criteria for diagnosing osteosarcoma (Option C): Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that typically presents with bone pain particularly at night, and swelling, and may have characteristic radiological features like a sunburst pattern or Codman's triangle. However, it is not related to Phemister’s triad. Thus, this option is incorrect.

A triad of radiological criteria for diagnosing Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (Option D): It is a chronic inflammatory condition in children that can present with joint pain, swelling, and systemic symptoms like fever. The radiological findings are synovial thickening, joint effusion, cartilage loss, and bone erosions. Phemister’s triad is not a feature of JIA. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman is brought to the ER due to confusion, tremors, and episodes of visual hallucinations for past 2 days. She has history of hypothyroidism on levothyroxine therapy. On examination, she is disoriented, febrile (100.8°F), and BP is 140/90 mmHg, pulse is 98/min. Neurological exam reveals asterixis and hyperreflexia, but no neck stiffness.


	Her lab results show:
	TSH: 42 μ IU/mL (↑)
	Free T4: Low
	Sodium: 134 mEq/L
	Liver and renal function: Normal
	Serum ammonia: Normal
	Anti-TPO antibody: Strongly positive


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Ice packs and Propranolol and Propylthiouracil

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: High-dose intravenous steroids

  • Patient is having Hashimoto encephalopathy. There is no hypothermia. So myxoedema coma is ruled out. Option A is used for myxoedema coma. Option B and D is used for Thyroid storm.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old female from Africa presents with hepatosplenomegaly, pallor, and generalised lymphadenopathy. Given her clinical features, there is a high suspicion of kala-azar. Which laboratory tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?

 


	rk39 serological test
	Bone marrow aspirate
	Splenic aspirate
	Liver biopsy
questions.solution:
rk39 serological test, bone marrow aspirate and splenic aspirate are 3 important investigations done for the diagnosis of kala-azar.

 

Diagnosis of Kala-azar :

Depends upon direct and indirect evidences:

CFT: complement fixation test; CIEP: counter immunoelectrophoresis; DAT: direct agglutination test; DNA: deoxyribonucleic acid; ELISA: enzyme linked immunosorbent assay; ICT: immunochromatographic test; IFAT: indirect immunofluorescent antibody test; LD: Leishman-Donovan; NNN: Novy, MacNeal and Nicolle; PCR: polymerase chain reaction; rK39: recombinant kinesin 39

 

Microscopy

Demonstration of amastigotes in smears of tissue aspirates is the gold standard for diagnosis of kala-azar / VL

 

Materials collected:

Peripheral blood smear: Peripheral blood contains the amastigotes present inside circulating monocytes. It is best to examine buffy coat smear, Buffy coat smears show a diurnal periodicity, more smears being positive when collected during the day than at night.

 

Blood smear test showing macrophages with amastigotes and extracellular Leishmania parasites (white arrows)

 

Bone marrow aspirate: Generally, the sternal marrow is aspirated by puncturing the sternum at the level of the 2nd or 3rd intercostal space, using a sternal puncture needle. Bone marrow samples can also be obtained by puncturing the Iliac crest.

 

Bone marrow aspirate showed Leishmania donovani bodies (LD bodies) in macrophages characterized by a kinetoplast and characteristic double dot appearance (Fig. A and B).

Splenic aspirate (most sensitive): Splenic aspirates are richer in parasites and, therefore, are more valuable for diagnosis. Splenic aspiration is contraindicated in patients with prolonged prothrombin time or if platelet count is less than 40,000/mm³

Lymph node aspirate: It is not useful in the diagnosis of Indian kala-azar

Culture

Media: NNN (Novy, MacNeal and Nicolle).

Serodiagnosis
  1. Detection of antigen: ELISA and PCR
  2. Detection of antibody:
    • rk39 test: A specific rapid immunochromatographic test (ICT) method for antibodies using a recombinant leishmanial antigen rk 39. The sensitivity of the test is 98% and specificity is 90%.
    • Complement fixation test
    • Indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFAT)
    • Counter immunoelectrophoresis (CIEP)
    • ELISA and DOT-ELISA
    • Direct agglutination test (DAT)

Non-specific serum tests
  1. Napier aldehyde test
  2. Chopra's antimony test

Skin test

  • Leishmanin skin test- Montenegro test: Delayed hypersensitivity test.
  • Positive result is indicated by induration and erythema of 5 mm or more after 48-72 hours.
  • Positive result indicates prior exposure to the leishmanial parasites. In active kala-azar, this test is negative and becomes positive usually 6-8 weeks after cure from the disease.

Image obtained after 48 hours after injection

Complete blood count
  • It shows normocytic normochromic anemia and thrombocytopenia.
  • Leukocyte count reveals leukopenia.
  • The ratio of leukocyte to erythrocyte is greatly altered and may be about 1:200 to 1:100 (normal 1:750).
  • The serum shows hypergammaglobulinemia and a reversal of the albumin: globulin (A: G) ratio.
  • Liver function tests show mild elevations of liver enzymes.
  • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is elevated.


Liver biopsy is not a safe procedure and carries a risk of haemorrhage.

questions.text:
Match the following structures with their corresponding CT score.

 


	
		
			
			Structure
			
			
			CT score in HU
			
		
		
			
			a) Air
			
			
			1) 0
			
		
		
			
			b) Water
			
			
			2) -1000
			
		
		
			
			c) Grey Matter
			
			
			3) 700 to 3000
			
		
		
			
			d) Bone
			
			
			4) 37 to 45
questions.solution:
Structure

CT score in HU

a) Air

1) -1000

b) Water

2) 0

c) Grey Matter

3) 37 to 45

d) Bone

4) 700 to 3000


 

Housenfield unit (HU):

  • In each slice of a CT scan, every tiny cube of tissue (called a voxel) is given a CT number. This number is based on how much the x-rays are blocked by that tissue, compared to distilled water at 0°C and 1 bar of pressure, and is measured in Hounsfield Units (HU).
  • The ones with a lower CT number appear the darkest, and the ones with a higher CT number appear brighter.
  • The values of some structures are as follows:

 

Structure

CT score (HU)

Air

-1000

Water

0

CSF

8 to 15

White matter

20 to 30

Blood

30 to 45

Grey matter

37 to 45

Contrast

100 to 300

Bone

700 (cancellous) to 3000 (inner and outer tables)

questions.text: A 16-month-old child is visiting the clinic for a routine check-up. The child's parents enquire about starting the varicella vaccination series. The child is healthy and has no known allergies or medical conditions. Which of the following vaccination schedules is most appropriate for this child?

choices.text: Administer the varicella vaccine today and schedule the second dose 23 months later.
Administer the varicella vaccine today and schedule the second dose 3-6 months later.
Administer the varicella vaccine today and schedule the second dose 2 weeks later.
Administer the varicella vaccine today and schedule the second dose 1 month later.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Administer the varicella vaccine today and schedule the second dose 3-6 months later.

 

Explanation:

The appropriate vaccination schedule for a 16-month-old child is the second dose correctly scheduled 3-6 months after the first dose.

 

VARICELLA VACCINE

About Vaccine
  • Live-attenuated vaccine
  • Oka strain

Dose, Route & Site
  • 0.5 mL, Subcutaneously
  • Anterolateral thigh or upper arm

National Program

Not included

IAP 2021
  • All children, especially high-risk categories; those exposed to varicella, and exposed unvaccinated adolescents/adults.
  • The first dose is taken at 15-18 months (minimum age 12 months).
  • Second dose 3-6 months later.

Catch Up

Administer two doses ≥3 months apart (≥4 weeks apart if over 13 years old) for those without proof of immunity.

Post-exposure prophylaxis

When administered for PEP within 72 hours of contact, a single dose of the vaccine offers only about 70% protective efficacy.

Adverse Reactions
  • Fever, rash, local pain or redness.
  • Mild rash after 2-3 weeks (5%).

C/I
  • The IAP advises against administering the MMR-V vaccine to children under 2 years old.
  • Anaphylaxis after the previous dose
  • Immunodeficiency
  • Active leukaemia or lymphoma
  • During immunosuppressive therapy

Precautions
  • Moderate to severe illness
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Recent receipt of blood products or immunoglobulins
  • Therapy with aspirin

Storage
  • Freeze-dried, lyophilized; Store at 2-8°C; Protect from light.
  • Use within 30 minutes of reconstitution.

questions.text: A patient has been experiencing dyspnea for the past few weeks. A biopsy of his lungs has revealed the finding given below. What is the characteristic finding shown below in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ferruginous body

 

Explanation:

The histopathological slide shows golden brown, fusiform, or beaded rods with a translucent core containing asbestos fibres coated with an iron-containing proteinaceous material suggestive of asbestos (ferruginous) bodies. They arise when macrophages phagocytose asbestos fibres; the iron is presumably derived from phagocyte ferritin.\

Asbestosis: 

  • It is due to occupational exposure associated in people working in shipyard or cement industry.
  • It effects the pleura (outer covering of lung), so the first lesion formed is pleural plaque.
    • After many years of exposure, pleural plaques may develop into pleural nodules, which, with prolonged exposure, can progress to cancers.
  • Most common cancer seen in Asbestosis: Adenocarcinoma lung.
  • Most specific cancer seen in Asbestosis: Mesothelioma lung

Creola bodies (Option A): Seen in asthma.

Schaumann bodies (Option B): These are calcium deposits that are seen in sarcoidosis.

Asteroid bodies (Option D): Seen in sarcoidosis and in fungal infection Sporothrix schenckii (Rose gardner's disease)

questions.text: Which of the following is used in management of dangerous hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
• Calcium levels in excess of 13mg/dl can increase the risk of cardiac arrest. Hence Normal saline plus Furosemide is first line. Then Bisphosphonates and calcitonin is used. Option A is used in eclampsia and severe acute asthma. Option B is used in CKD for secondary hyperparathyroidism. Option D is used in CKD for hyperphosphatemia.

Drugs

Onset

Duration

Role

Calcitonin

4-6 hours

~48 hours

Rapid, short-term control

Bisphosphonates

48-72 hours

Weeks

Long-term control

questions.text:
All of the following drugs correctly match their mechanism of action.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with sudden, massive hematemesis. An upper endoscopy identifies a small mucosal defect surrounded by normal gastric mucosa. Angiography reveals a large, tortuous artery in the left gastric artery distribution. What is the underlying pathophysiological mechanism of bleeding in Dieulafoy’s lesion?

choices.text: Erosion of the mucosa due to excessive acid secretion
Rupture of varices caused by portal hypertension
Erosion of mucosa due to pulsations from a large submucosal artery
Ulceration of the gastric mucosa due to chronic use of NSAIDs

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Erosion of mucosa due to pulsations from a large submucosal artery

 

Explanation:

Dieulafoy’s lesion involves a large, tortuous artery in the submucosa that causes erosion of the overlying mucosa due to its pulsations, leading to bleeding.

Dieulafoy’s lesion
  • Dieulafoy's lesion is characterized by an abnormally large, tortuous artery that runs through the submucosa of the stomach without a primary ulcer.
  • Artery measures 1-3 mm and is typically found near the gastroesophageal junction along the lesser curvature.
  • The lesion develops as the pulsations of the large submucosal artery erode the superficial mucosa. (Option C)
  • The mucosal defect is usually small, measuring 2-5 mm, and is surrounded by normal-appearing gastric mucosa. Once the artery is exposed to gastric contents, further erosion and bleeding occur.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is undergoing evaluation for palpitations. ECG reveals a supraventricular tachycardia with HR of 190/min. An echocardiogram reveals hypertrophy of the right ventricle and enlargement of the right ventricular outflow tract. Which structure separates the inflow and outflow tracts in the right ventricle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Supraventricular crest

Explanation:

The supraventricular crest is located within the right ventricle and separates the inflow tract, which carries blood from the right atrium through the tricuspid valve, from the outflow tract, which directs blood into the pulmonary trunk.

  • It is a thick, muscular “U” shaped structure extending from the interventricular septum to the anterolateral wall of the right ventricle.
  • The crest provides the main attachment for the anterosuperior leaflet of the tricuspid valve.
  • The septal limb of the crest is connected to the septal limbs of the septomarginal trabeculation (moderator band).

    

Crista terminalis (Option A)

  • Located in the right atrium - separates the smooth and rough parts of the atrium, not the right ventricle's inflow and outflow tracts.

 

The moderator band (Option C) facilitates conduction in the right ventricle and contains the right bundle branch (RBB).

  • Helps prevent overdistension of the right ventricle during systole by acting as a stabilizing structure. It does not separate the inflow and outflow regions.

 

Interventricular septum (Option D) separates the left and right ventricles but does not partition the right ventricle's inflow and outflow tracts.

questions.text: All of the following criteria are used for diagnosing PCOS except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Elevated estrogen levels

Explanation:

Elevated estrogen levels can occur in some cases of PCOS due to disturbances in hormone regulation, it is not a primary diagnostic criterion for PCOS.

Rotterdam Criteria:

Any 2 of the following 3 should be present to make a provisional diagnosis for PCOS

Increased androgen levels (Option A): Hyperandrogenism/Hirsutism: PCOS is associated with elevated androgen levels, which can manifest as clinical signs (like hirsutism and acne) or biochemical findings (elevated testosterone).

Ovulatory dysfunction (Option B): Oligomenorrhea/Amenorrhea- Irregular menstrual cycles (oligomenorrhea) or absence of menstrual periods (amenorrhea) are common features of PCOS due to ovulatory dysfunction.

Presence of ovarian cysts (Option D): On USG: 1 or both ovaries >12 follicles with 2-9mm in size (<1cm)- One of the diagnostic criteria for PCOS is the presence of polycystic ovarian morphology, which is confirmed by ultrasound showing multiple cysts on the ovaries.

USG: Necklace pattern arranged towards the periphery.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with a history of hypertension and smoking presents with back pain, and imaging shows a thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm starting at the sixth intercostal space and extending to just above the renal arteries. According to the Crawford classification, which type does this aneurysm correspond to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Type V

 

Explanation:

  • Given the description, the patient is diagnosed with Type V thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm

 

Crawford's classification of thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm:

 

Type

Involvement

I

Descending thoracic aorta to above renal arteries.

II

Descending thoracic aorta to below renal arteries.

III

From the sixth intercostal space to below renal arteries.

IV

The entire abdominal aorta from the twelfth intercostal space to the aortic bifurcation.

V

Portion of the thoracic aorta below the sixth intercostal space to above renal arteries.

questions.text:
A 2 y/o child presents with abdominal distension and a palpable abdominal mass. A CT scan is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Neuroblastoma

Explanation:

Neuroblastoma commonly occurs in children under 2 years, presents as a poorly marginated mass encasing vascular structures, and is associated with features such as midline crossing, which aligns with the CT findings. CT shows a hypodense mass displacing the kidney posteriorly and displacing structures away from the midline.

 

Wilms Tumor (Nephroblastoma)

Neuroblastoma

• Calcification: Uncommon (10-15%)

• Vascular involvement: Displaces renal vessels but does not encase them

• Age group: Slightly older (peak at 3-4 years)

• Margins: Well-circumscribed

• Claw sign: Kidney claw sign present

• Vascular extension: Common into IVC/renal vein

• Midline crossing: Does not cross midline

• Bone metastases: Rare, lung metastases are common

• Spinal canal extension: Never seen

• Retroperitoneal lymph nodes: Uncommon

• Hemorrhage: Higher incidence

 

• Calcification: Very common

• Vascular involvement: Encases but does not invade vessels

• Age group: Younger (<2 years)

• Margins: Poorly marginated

• Aorta: Elevates aorta away from the vertebral column

• Midline crossing: Frequently crosses the midline, especially behind the aorta

• Thoracic extension: Common

• Bone metastases: Common (Hutchinson syndrome)

• Spinal canal extension: Can occur

• Retroperitoneal lymph nodes: Common

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Wilms Tumor (Nephroblastoma) (Option A): Typically presents in slightly older children (peak at 3-4 years) with well-circumscribed margins, making this less likely.

Renal Cell Carcinoma (Option C): More common in adults and does not typically present in this age group.

Hepatoblastoma (Option D): While it can present in young children, it typically originates from the liver rather than the kidneys and does not match the imaging findings described.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of palpable purpura on her lower legs, no systemic symptoms, and all investigations including ANA, ANCA, and complements are normal. Skin biopsy shows leukocytoclastic vasculitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text:
A 28-year-old shepherd presents with chronic cough and occasional hemoptysis. A chest X-ray is shown below.



Which of the following radiological signs is most likely represented in this image?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Water Lily sign

 

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical feature of chronic cough with occasional hemoptysis in a patient with livestock exposure, along with the characteristic Water Lily sign on chest x-ray, points towards the diagnosis of a ruptured pulmonary hydatid cyst.

 

  • Radiographic Findings of Hydatid Cyst:
    • Uncomplicated cysts appear as thin-walled, round or oval masses with low-attenuation contents and a thin enhancing wall, up to 10 cm in size.

 

  • Signs of Impending Rupture:
    • Meniscus Sign: Air lucency between the pericyst and laminated membranes when cyst communicates with bronchioles. (Option A)
  • Signs Associated with Cyst Rupture:
    • Cumbo Sign or Onion Peel Sign:
      • Indicates that the endocyst has shrunk and ruptured due to increasing air.
      • Curvilinear membrane outlined by air both inside the endocyst and a crescent of air between the endocyst and pericyst. (Option B & D)
    • Water Lily Sign:
      • Also known as the camalote sign.
      • Indicates that the endocyst membrane is detached; it will appear as a floating curvilinear structure (fluid-filled cyst ) within an intact pericyst.
      • This gives the appearance of a floating water lily. (Option C)
    • Mass Within the Cavity: An endocyst floating in a completely fluid-filled cyst.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with swelling around his eyes, ankles, and abdomen, along with frothy urine. Urinalysis shows proteinuria, elevated serum creatinine, and BUN levels. Image of renal biopsy is given below. Which of the following is not an established cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Diabetes mellitus

Explanation:

Based on the given clinical scenario and HPE image (segmental sclerosis, glomerular hyalinosis, and tubular atrophy, with negative immunofluorescence), the most likely diagnosis is Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults.

Diabetes mellitus primarily causes diabetic nephropathy, characterised by diffuse glomerulosclerosis rather than the focal and segmental pattern seen in FSGS.

 

Causes of FSGS:

1. Primary (Idiopathic) FSGS.

2. Secondary FSGS: Mnemonic- H3R3S1

  • Hypertension (Option C)
  • HIV associated nephropathy (Option B)
  • Heroine drug abuse
  • Reflux nephropathy
  • Renal tissue loss
  • Sickle cell anaemia (Option D)

3. Inherited forms:

  • Genetic mutations affecting slit diaphragm proteins like nephrin, podocin, α-actinin 4, and TRPC6.

questions.text: 30-year-old grand multipara develops extreme SOB after delivery of term Small for gestational age boy. On examination her Pulse is 120/min, BP is 80/60 mm Hg with prominent neck veins and bilateral crepitations in lung fields. Which of the following is correct about immediate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Furosemide and morphine

  • Patient is having AHF. BP is low. NTG is not given when BP is less than 90/60 mm Hg. Morphine has vagotonic action will help in conserving oxygen. Digoxin is not used unless first line drugs are not used. Option D will be used after using option A.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female presents with fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance. On physical examination, she has diffuse goitre and dry skin. Histopathological examination shows lymphoid infiltration, atrophic thyroid follicles lined in many areas by epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Hashimoto's thyroiditis

 

Explanation:

The above scenario and HPE findings suggest a diagnosis of Hashimoto's thyroiditis/Lymphocytic thyroiditis..

  • It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas.
  • In histopathology, there is extensive lymphocytic infiltration with well-developed germinal centres. The thyroid follicles are atrophic and are lined in many areas by epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm, termed Hürthle cells (hallmark feature of Hashimoto's thyroiditis).
  • It is an autoimmune condition, so on hematological testing we see autoantibodies like Anti-TSH receptor antibody, antithyroglobulin antibody, and anti-TPO antibodies.
  • Genetic cause of Hashimoto's thyroiditis is HLA-DR3 and HLA-DR5 polymorphisms.
  • Long standing Hashimoto's thyroiditis can give rise to some cancers like:
    1. Papillary carcinoma thyroid
    2. Maltoma (a marginal zone lymphoma)

questions.text: An X-ray image shows multiple large chondromas in the hands and feet of a 28-year-old female patient. Based on this radiological finding, which of the following statements is false regarding her condition?

choices.text: The presence of large chondromas may indicate a higher risk of malignant transformation.
These chondromas can lead to bone expansion and thinning of the cortex.
Surgical excision of all chondromas is the standard treatment to prevent malignant transformation.
Patients with multiple chondromas have an increased risk of extra-skeletal malignancies

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Surgical excision of all chondromas is the standard treatment to prevent malignant transformation.

 

Explanation:

It is a case of Multiple Enchondromatosis associated with Maffucci syndrome.

Surgical excision may be indicated for symptomatic chondromas or those showing signs of malignant transformation, it is not necessary to excise all chondromas as a preventive measure.

 

Multiple Enchondromatosis

  • Definition: Condition characterized by numerous benign cartilaginous tumors (chondromas).
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Ollier's disease- only enchondromas
    • Maffucci syndrome- enchondromas + hemangiomas

Ollier's Disease

Common findings:

Asymmetric limb shortening

Swelling of fingers/toes

Impaired movement of interphalangeal joints

Can be unilateral or bilateral

Progression

New chondromas typically stop after puberty

Tumor growth in adulthood may indicate malignancy

Risk of pathological fractures

Malignant Transformation

20-30% risk of secondary chondrosarcoma

Transformation usually occurs in the 30s or 40s

Warning signs:

Increase in size of existing chondroma

New symptoms

Increased risk for carcinomas (breast, liver, ovary) (Option D ruled out)

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic hepatitis B presents with increasing fatigue, weight loss, and right upper quadrant pain. Physical examination reveals jaundice and hepatomegaly. Imaging shows multiple lesions with a 4 cm mass in the right lobe and satellite nodules in the left lobe, along with portal vein thrombosis. His LFT shows elevated bilirubin and low albumin levels. The patient is diagnosed with HCC.

According to standard protocol, what is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Sorafenib
 

Explanation:

  • The patient has BCLC Stage C Hepatocellular carcinoma, characterized by the presence of vascular invasion, extrahepatic spread, or performance status of 1-2, the recommended treatment is systemic therapy with Sorafenib.

  • Sorafenib is used for both advanced and metastatic HCC as the preferred agent.

  • The treatment protocol adheres to the Barcelona Clinic Liver Cancer (BCLC) guidelines for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)

Management of HCC

Barcelona Clinic Liver Cancer (BCLC) Staging system

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy presents with failure to thrive, developmental delay, and intermittent episodes of vomiting and lethargy. The episodes coincide with the introduction of solid foods. Blood tests reveal elevated ammonia levels and high levels of ornithine in blood. Urine analysis shows increased excretion of homocitrulline. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
This child with hyperammonemia triggered after solid food introduction is most likely to have HHH syndrome.

 

Hyperornithinemia-Hyperammonemia-Homocitrullinuria Syndrome

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Defective Gene

ORC1

Defective Protein

Mitochondrial Ornithine Transporter: This transporter moves ornithine into the mitochondria and citrulline out of the mitochondria.

Mechanism
  • Prevents ornithine from entering the mitochondria, which is necessary for the urea cycle.
  • The buildup of ammonia in the blood (hyperammonemia).
  • Ornithine also accumulates in the cytoplasm (hyperornithinemia).
  • Carbamoyl phosphate reacts with lysine to form homocitrulline.

Symptoms
  • Failure to thrive.
  • Developmental delay.
  • Intermittent episodes of vomiting and lethargy (triggered by protein intake).
  • Seizures.
  • Intellectual disability.

Diagnosis
  • Elevated blood ammonia
  • Elevated blood ornithine
  • Elevated urinary homocitrulline.

Treatment
  • Low-protein diet
  • Nitrogen scavenger medications
  • Liver transplant in severe cases.

 

  • Citrullinemia (Option A) leads to the accumulation of citrulline, which would be elevated in blood tests, unlike in this scenario.

 

  • Argininosuccinate aciduria (Option B) causes the characteristic symptom of trichorrhexis nodosa (brittle, easily broken hair), which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

  • Argininemia (Option D) involves hyperammonemia. Compared to other urea cycle disorders, its presentation is typically delayed, appearing around 2 years of age, not at 5 months.
