questions.text: What effect does aldosterone have on acid secretion in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) and collecting duct (CD)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increases activity of H⁺-ATPase

Explanation:

  • In intercalated cells of the DCT and collecting duct, H⁺ is secreted via H⁺-ATPase and H⁺/K⁺ ATPase.
  • Aldosterone stimulates these proton pumps, enhancing urinary acidification and bicarbonate reabsorption.
  • This mechanism is independent of Na⁺ transport.

 

Takeaway:

  • Aldosterone = ↑ H⁺ secretion (via H⁺-ATPase) → helps maintain acid–base balance.
  • Decreases the activity of Hᐩ-ATPase (Option A): Aldosterone increases the activity of Hᐩ-ATPase but does not decrease it.
  • Inhibits the secretion of Hᐩ (Option B): Aldosterone enhances the secretion of Hᐩ, not inhibits it.

questions.text:
Match the following phases of translation (Column A) with the events involved (Column B).


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			1. Elongation
			
			
			a. RF1 binds with RF3 and GTP
			
		
		
			
			2. Initiation
			
			
			b. Binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to the ribosome's A site
			
		
		
			
			3. Termination
			
			
			c. Methionine tRNA scans mRNA for AUG codon
questions.solution:
Phases of translation

Key events

Initiation
  • Dissociation of 80s ribosome into 60s and 40s, and stabilized by various initiation factors.
  • Formation of the 43S Preinitiation Complex: The 40S ribosomal subunit, in association with initiation factors, binds to the initiator tRNA (carrying methionine in eukaryotes or formyl-methionine in prokaryotes)forming the 43S preinitiation complex.
  • Formation of 48S initiation complex: The 43S complex binds to the 5' end of the mRNA, and scans for start codon which upon recognition, the 48S initiation complex is formed.
  • Formation of the 80S Initiation Complex: Binding of the 60S ribosomal subunit to the 48S initiation. The met-tRNA on the P site of the ribosome is ready for the elongation cycle.

Elongation
  • Binding of Aminoacyl-tRNA to the A Site
  • Peptide Bond Formation
  • Elongation factor 2 (EF2) binds to and displaces the peptidyl tRNA from the A site to the P site

Termination
  • Ribosome reaches the terminator codon sequence (UAA, UAG or UGA)
  • Releasing factor(RF1), (RF3) and GTP complex promotes hydrolysis releasing the protein and the tRNA from the P site.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an action of the combined oral contraceptive pill?

choices.text: Suppression of ovulation through inhibition of pituitary hormones.
Thickening of cervical mucus to block sperm entry.
Induction of atrophic changes in the endometrium to prevent implantation.
Kills the sperm in the cervix.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Kills the sperm in the cervix.

Explanation:

  • The OCPs do not have spermicidal action.
  • The combined oral contraceptive pill containing Estrogen and progesterone which help suppressing ovulation by inhibiting pituitary hormones, FSH, and LH. (Option A)
  • The progestogen in the pill makes the cervical mucus thick and tenacious, preventing sperm from penetrating. (Option B)
  • The progestogen causes atrophic changes (thinning) in the endometrium, making it unsuitable for implantation. (Option C)
  • The combined OCPs also increase tubal motility, leading to the fertilized egg reaching the uterus before the endometrium is ready for implantation.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man with a history of T2DM presents to the ER with right-sided hemiplegia and slurred speech. On examination:


	BP: 180/100 mmHg
	HR: 96 bpm, irregularly irregular
	GCS: 14
	Time last seen normal: 9 PM last night
	NIHSS score: 12
	Non-contrast CT brain at 8:00 AM: No evidence of haemorrhage
	CT angiography: Left MCA occlusion


What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: E.V.T

  • Patient is having acute ischemic stroke. Hints are irregularly irregular pulse indicating atrial fibrillation. This is wake up stroke and patient is outside the window period for stroke. Hence thrombectomy will be done. Lowering of BP is indicated before doing thrombolysis to reduce the chance of CNS bleeding.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with a high fever, chills, and painful lymphadenopathy in the inguinal region. He mentions recent travel to a rural area known for plague outbreaks. Suspecting Yersinia pestis, the physician orders various diagnostic tests, including biochemical reactions and serology. Which of the following findings would support the diagnosis of Yersinia pestis?

choices.text: Positive catalase test, Positive oxidase test, and Passive hemagglutination against F1 antigen with a titer> 64 A in a single sample
Negative catalase test, Positive oxidase test, Passive hemagglutination against F1 antigen with a titer> 64 A in a single sample
Positive catalase test, Negative oxidase test, and Passive hemagglutination against F1 antigen with a titer> 128 A in a single sample
Negative catalase test, Negative oxidase test, and Passive hemagglutination against F1 antigen with a titer> 128 A in a single sample

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Positive catalase test, Negative oxidase test, and Passive hemagglutination against F1 antigen with a titre > 128 A in a single sample

Explanation:

Serology and Biochemical Reactions of Yersinia pestis

Biochemical Reactions

  • Fermentation [+ve acid production -ve gas production] - Glucose, Maltose, Mannitol
  • Catalase Test - Positive
  • Oxidase Test - Negative
  • IMViC - + - -

Serology
  • Passive hemagglutination by antibody against F1 antigen
  • Titre > 128 Å in a single sample (1:128)

questions.text: A state recorded 150 maternal deaths in a year. The number of live births during the same period was 50,000. The total number of women in the reproductive age group (15-49 years) is 10,00,000. What is the maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for this state?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 300 per 100,000 live births

 

Explanation:

The question specifically asks for the maternal mortality ratio.

Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is the number of maternal deaths during the antenatal period, during delivery, and up to 42 days post delivery per 100,000 live births. It is calculated as follows:

Maternal Mortality Ratio =  ( No. of maternal deaths / No. of Live births )    x   100000

So the answer will be, (150/50000) x 100000 = 300

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl with a BMI in the 98th percentile presents with lethargy, frequent thirst, increased urination, and dark patches on her neck. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) with associated obesity.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) with associated obesity.

Explanation:

The child's BMI at the 98th percentile indicates obesity, a major risk factor for T2DM. The symptoms of lethargy, frequent thirst, and increased urination (polydipsia and polyuria) are classic signs of diabetes. Additionally, the dark patches on the neck, known as acanthosis nigricans, are often associated with insulin resistance, a hallmark of T2DM.

Obesity

 

 

Obesity

Overweight

Adult

BMI ≥ 30

BMI between 25 and 30

Children

BMI ≥ 95th percentile for age and sex

BMI between 85th and 95th percentiles


 

Aetiology:

  1. Constitutional causes:
    • Imbalance between caloric intake and energy expenditure.
    • Easy access to energy-dense foods, and large portion sizes.
    • Sedentary lifestyle.
    • High intake of sugary beverages, processed foods, and large portions.
  2. Genetic syndromes eg. Prader-Willi syndrome
  3. Endocrine causes:
    • Cushing syndrome
    • GH deficiency
    • Hypothyroidism
  4. Chronic sleep deprivation can disrupt appetite-regulating hormones, leading to weight gain.
  5. Disruption of hormones like leptin and adiponectin.

Hypothyroidism with weight gain (Option B): Hypothyroidism can cause weight gain and lethargy, but it is less likely to cause the symptoms of increased thirst and urination. Additionally, acanthosis nigricans is not commonly associated with hypothyroidism.

Cystic Fibrosis-related diabetes (CFRD) (Option C) occurs in individuals with cystic fibrosis, which other symptoms, such as recurrent lung infections or gastrointestinal issues would typically accompany. There is no indication of cystic fibrosis in this child's history.

Adrenal insufficiency (Option D) can cause symptoms like fatigue and weight loss rather than weight gain. It does not typically cause polyuria, polydipsia, or acanthosis nigricans.

questions.text: A 45-year-old radiology technician consults his occupational health physician about his annual radiation exposure, concerned about potential health risks and whether his exposure is within safe limits. What is the maximum annual radiation exposure level a person can tolerate without significant health risks?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 5 rem

Explanation:

The International Commission of Radiological Protection (ICRP) has set the maximum permissible level of occupational exposure to ionising radiation at 5 rem per year for the whole body.

  • This limit protects individuals from various health risks associated with ionising radiation exposure.
  • Ionising radiation, such as X-rays and specific radioisotopes like cobalt-60 and phosphorus-32, plays a significant role in medical and industrial applications.
  • Certain tissues, such as bone marrow, exhibit higher sensitivity to ionising radiation.
  • Exposure to the gonads presents unique genetic risks.
  • Hazards from ionising radiation include various health effects such as genetic mutations, birth defects, cancer, leukemia, hair loss, skin ulceration, infertility, and, in severe cases, death.

questions.text: Biomarkers for Alzheimer disease

Correct Option A: CSF A beta 42/40

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis presents with progressively worsening abdominal distention, decreased urine output, and swelling in his legs. On examination, his abdomen is tense and distended with caput medusa and ascites, and his chest shows spider angioma. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum creatinine levels. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Terlipressin

 

Explanation:

  • Terlipressin is a vasopressin analogue that acts as a V1 receptor agonist, leading to vasoconstriction of splanchnic vessels and reducing portal hypertension.
  • It is the drug of choice for treating hepatorenal syndrome, as it helps improve renal perfusion and function in patients with advanced liver disease.

Spironolactone (Option B) is a potassium-sparing diuretic commonly used in the management of cirrhotic ascites.

Furosemide (Option C) is a loop diuretic used to treat fluid overload in patients with cirrhosis and ascites, but it is contraindicated in hepatorenal syndrome.

Lactulose (Option D) is a non-absorbable sugar used to treat hepatic encephalopathy by reducing ammonia levels in the colon.

Correct Option B: Stomach volvulus

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with a rapidly growing thyroid mass accompanied by severe pain and hoarseness of voice. Imaging shows the direct invasion of surrounding structures, including the trachea and oesophagus. The diagnosis of anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is confirmed. In managing this condition, which of the following is not typically included?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Radioactive iodine

 

Explanation: Radioactive Iodine is not typically used for anaplastic thyroid carcinoma due to the lack of iodine uptake in this aggressive form of thyroid cancer.

 

  • Management of Anaplastic carcinoma:
    • Resectable Tumors (restricted to Thyroid): Total thyroidectomy + Central Neck Dissection + Modified Radical Neck Dissection
    • Unresectable Tumors: Palliative care with tracheostomy for airway obstruction
      • Chemotherapy: Doxorubicin (Option C)
      • Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors: Dabrafenib, Trametinib (Option D)
      • Tumour Debulking: Isthmusectomy done if pressure over the Trachea. (Option B)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT one of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted by the United Nations in 2015?

choices.text: End poverty in all its forms everywhere
Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education for all
Promote sustainable consumption and production patterns

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Achieve world peace and disarmament

Explanation: 

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), adopted by the United Nations and UNDP in 2015, aim to eradicate poverty, ensure prosperity, and protect the planet by 2030. There are 17 goals:

  1. End poverty everywhere in all its forms. (Option A ruled out)

  2. Zero hunger- Achieve food security, improve nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture.

  3. Ensure healthy lives and well-being for all ages.

  4. Provide inclusive and equitable quality education and lifelong learning opportunities. (Option B ruled out) 

  5. Achieve gender equality and empower women and girls. 

  6. Ensure access to sustainable & clean water and sanitation for all.

  7. Ensure access to affordable, clean and modern energy for all.

  8. Promote sustainable economic growth, full employment, and decent work.

  9. Build resilient infrastructure, promote sustainable industrialization, and foster innovation.

  10. Reduce inequality within and among countries.

  11. Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable

  12. Ensure sustainable consumption and production patterns. (Option C ruled out) 

  13. Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts. 

  14. Conserve and sustainably use water bodies - oceans, seas, and marine resources. 

  15. Protect, restore, and sustainably use terrestrial ecosystems and preserve biodiversity. 

  16. Promote peaceful and inclusive societies, ensure access to justice, and build effective institutions. 

  17. Strengthen global partnerships for sustainable development.

questions.text: A 31-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester presents with fishy-smelling vaginal discharge. A wet mount examination revealed clue cells and diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis. What is the recommended treatment for managing this condition?

choices.text: Boric acid suppositories, intravaginally for 5 days
Metronidazole 500 mg orally twice daily for 7 days
Tinidazole 2 g orally once daily for 2 days

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Metronidazole 500 mg orally twice daily for 7 days

Explanation:

Recommended treatment guidelines for bacterial vaginosis:

  • Metronidazole 500 mg orally 2 times/day for 7 days OR
  • Metronidazole gel 0.75% one full applicator (5 g) intravaginally, once a day for 5 days OR
  • Clindamycin cream 2% one full applicator (5 g) intravaginally at bedtime for 7 days

Alternative Regimes:

  • Clindamycin 300 mg orally 2 times/day for 7 days OR
  • Clindamycin ovules 100 mg* intravaginally once at bedtime for 3 days OR
  • Secnidazole 2 g oral granules in a single dose† OR
  • Tinidazole 2 g orally once daily for 2 days OR
  • Tinidazole 1 g orally once daily for 5 days

Any of the regimens used in non-pregnant women can be used in pregnancy. In the 1st trimester we usually prefer vaginal route, beyond 1st trimester - both vaginal & oral can be used

questions.text: A patient is given a 300 mg dose of a drug. After 1 hour, 75 mg of the drug is excreted. Assuming the drug is eliminated from the system by following first-order kinetics, how much of the drug will remain after 4 hours of starting the drug?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 94 mg

Explanation

The given drug follows a first-order kinetic elimination; hence, its clearance rate remains constant and proportional to the plasma concentration per unit of time.

  • Initial dose: 300 mg

  • After 1 hour: 75 mg excreted

  • So, 225 mg remains → this means 75% (¾) remains after 1 hour

  • Drug follows first-order kinetics, so the fraction eliminated per unit time remains constant

Therefore, the remaining drug after each hour is:

  • After 1 hour:
    300×3/4=225 mg

  • After 2 hours:
    225×3/4=168.75 mg

  • After 3 hours:
    168.75×3/4=126.56 mg

  • After 4 hours:
    126.56×3/4=94.92 mg

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a 20-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes and an HbA1c of 10.5% came for an ophthalmic examination. Fundoscopy reveals microaneurysms, hard exudates, and retinal thickening. Which of the following is the most likely cause of future vision loss in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- C) Macular Edema

Explanation: 

The most likely cause of future vision loss in this patient is macular edema. 

 Complications of Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • Macular Edema: The most common cause of vision loss in diabetic retinopathy is leakage from dilated capillaries.

 

  • Vitreous Hemorrhage (VH) (Option A): Seen as blood floating in the vitreous, occluding the view of the retina. Secondary to proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is a cause of severe vision loss in diabetic patients

 

  • Retinal Detachment (Option B): PDR causes scars to form in the back of the eye. When the scars pull the retina away from the back of the eye, it's called tractional retinal detachment.

 

  • Neovascular Glaucoma (Option D): PDR causes abnormal blood vessels to grow out of the retina and block fluid from draining out of the eye, leading to neovascular glaucoma. Can cause vision loss and blindness.

 

  • Rubeosis Iridis: Neovascularization of the iris is when blood vessels develop on the anterior surface of the iris in response to retinal ischemia. Prone to spontaneous hyphema as the blood vessels are fragile

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with complaints of epiphora. On examination, there is an eversion of the punctum noted. Which among the following is incorrect regarding the type of ectropion seen in this patient?

choices.text: Age-related changes are implicated in etiopathogenesis
Starts from lateral eyelid and progresses medially

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Starts from lateral eyelid and progresses medially

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is indicative of involutional ectropion.

 

Involutional ectropion:

  • Most common form (Option A)
  • Caused by age-related laxity of lower eyelid structures. (Option C)
  • It usually begins medially and extends laterally. (Option D)
  • Progression leads to: Conjunctival inflammation, Keratinization, Lagophthalmos (Option B)

 

Type of Ectropion

Description

Causes

Clinical Features

Treatment

Involutional Ectropion
  • Most common; age-related
  • Horizontal laxity
  • Canthal tendon laxity
  • Epiphora
  • Tarsal thinning
  • Lagophthalmos
  • Medial conjunctivoplasty for mild cases.
  • Horizontal lid shortening for moderate cases.
  • Byron Smith's modified Kuhnt-Szymanowski operation for severe cases.
  • Lateral tarsal strip technique for generalized ectropion.

Cicatricial Ectropion
  • Scarring of anterior lamella
  • Trauma/surgery
  • Scarring conditions (e.g., blepharitis)
  • Scarring
  • Skin fibrosis
  • Mild cases: V-Y operation.
  • Mild to moderate cases: Z-plasty (Elschnig's operation).
  • Severe cases: Excision of scar tissue and full-thickness skin grafting.

Paralytic Ectropion
  • Facial nerve palsy (Bell’s)
  • Bell’s palsy
  • Trauma/surgery
  • Exposure keratopathy
  • Temporary measures: Topical lubricants, eyelid taping, suture tarsorrhaphy.
  • Permanent measures (if needed): Horizontal lid tightening with/without middle lamellar buttress, palpebral sling operation.

Mechanical Ectropion
  • Mass or lesion pushing eyelid
  • Tumors
  • Conjunctival growths
  • Eyelid displacement
  • Conjunctival chemosis
  • Treat the underlying mechanical causes.

Congenital Ectropion
  • Present at birth
  • Tarsal plate atrophy
  • Down syndrome
  • Associated eyelid malformation
  • Mild cases may not require treatment.
  • Moderate or severe cases: Horizontal lid tightening and full-thickness skin graft.


 

Grading of Ectropion:

 

GRADE

FEATURE

0

I

Only punctum is everted

II

Lid margin everted and palpebral conjunctiva visible

III

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient diagnosed with dry eye syndrome asks about the typical features of the condition. Which of the following is not commonly associated with dry eye?

choices.text: Frothy tears along the lid margin
Punctate epithelial erosions on the cornea

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Follicles on the conjunctiva

 

Explanation:

Follicles on the conjunctiva are typically seen in viral or chlamydial infections, not in dry eye.

 

Etiology of Dry eye:

Symptoms:

  • Irritation
  • Foreign body (sandy) sensation
  • Eye dryness
  • Reduced vision
  • Itching
  • Nonspecific ocular discomfort

 

Signs:

  • Tear Film Signs:
    • Presence of stingy mucus and particulate matter
    • Reduced or absent marginal tear strip
    • Frothy tears along the lid margin indicate meibomian gland dysfunction (Option A)
    • Posterior Blepharitis (Meibomitis): Inflammation of meibomian glands.

 

  • Conjunctival Signs:
    • Lustreless and mildly congested conjunctiva
    • Conjunctival xerosis and keratinization may occur (Option C)
    • Positive Rose Bengal or Lissamine green staining
  • Corneal Signs:
    • Punctate epithelial erosions (Option B)
    • Filaments and mucus plaques
    • Loss of corneal luster
    • Lesions delineated by fluorescein, Rose Bengal, or Lissamine green staining

questions.text: Arrange the stages of spore formation (sporulation) in correct order:

choices.text: Axial filament formation ➔ Septum formation ➔ Asymmetric division ➔ Engulfment ➔ Cortex formation ➔ Maturation and lysis
Engulfment ➔ Cortex formation ➔ Septum formation ➔ Asymmetric division ➔ Axial filament formation ➔ Maturation and lysis
Septum formation ➔ Asymmetric division ➔ Engulfment ➔ Cortex formation ➔ Maturation and lysis ➔ Axial filament formation
Asymmetric division ➔ Engulfment ➔ Cortex formation ➔ Septum formation ➔ Axial filament formation ➔ Maturation and lysis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Axial filament formation ➔ Septum formation ➔ Asymmetric division ➔ Engulfment ➔ Cortex and coat formation ➔ Maturation and lysis

 

Explanation:

Stages of spore formation/sporulation in order:

  1. Axial filament formation: The bacterial cell prepares for sporulation by forming an axial filament.
  2. Septum formation: Under stress (e.g., nutrient depletion), the bacterium divides asymmetrically, forming a septum that separates the mother cell from the forespore.
  3. Asymmetric division: The smaller compartment forms the forespore (future spore), while the larger one becomes the mother cell.
  4. Engulfment: The mother cell engulfs the forespore within a second membrane.
  5. Cortex formation: A thick layer of peptidoglycan forms between the two membranes of the spore.
  6. Coat formation: Various proteins assemble around the spore, forming the coat.
  7. Maturation: The spore matures, becoming highly resistant to environmental stresses.
  8. Lysis: The mother cell lyses, releasing the mature spore into the environment.

questions.text:
A hematologist is reviewing the peripheral blood smears of three patients diagnosed with different types of thalassemia.

Patient A has severe anemia, target cells, and nucleated red blood cells (NRBCs).

Patient B has mild anemia with microcytosis and hypochromia but no NRBCs.

Patient C has mild anemia with microcytosis and hypochromia but also shows a small number of NRBCs and some hemoglobin H inclusions.

Based on the peripheral smear findings, which of the following correctly matches the patients with their thalassemia types?

choices.text: Patient A: β-thalassemia major, Patient B: β-thalassemia minor, Patient C: α-thalassemia
Patient A: β-thalassemia minor, Patient B: α-thalassemia, Patient C: β-thalassemia major
Patient A: α-thalassemia, Patient B: β-thalassemia minor, Patient C: β-thalassemia major
Patient A: β-thalassemia major, Patient B: α-thalassemia, Patient C: β-thalassemia minor

questions.solution:
The peripheral smear findings can help distinguish between different types of thalassemia:

  • β-thalassemia major (Patient A): This condition is characterized by severe anemia. The peripheral smear typically shows significant abnormalities, including target cells, nucleated red blood cells (NRBCs), microcytosis, hypochromia, and anisopoikilocytosis. These findings are consistent with the severe hemolytic anemia and ineffective erythropoiesis seen in β-thalassemia major.
  • β-thalassemia minor/β-thalassemia trait (Patient B): This condition usually presents with mild anemia. The peripheral smear shows microcytosis and hypochromia but generally lacks significant numbers of NRBCs.
  • α-thalassemia (Patient C): This condition can vary in severity. The peripheral smear of a patient with α-thalassemia trait may show mild anemia, microcytosis, and hypochromia. In cases of HbH disease (a form of α-thalassemia), the smear can also show NRBCs and hemoglobin H inclusions (golf ball cells), which are not seen in β-thalassemia minor.
    • Hemoglobin H inclusions are seen in α-thalassemia patients when there are 3 out of 4 alpha genes deletions.

questions.text: Which of the following is the testicular cause of infertility?
questions.solution:

Kartagener syndrome causes abnormal ciliary structure or function leading to decreased ciliary motility, resulting in infertility due to testicular aetiology. In females, it leads to immotile cilia in the fallopian tube leading to infertility.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding Work Sampling as a health management technique?

choices.text: Work Sampling involves systematic observation and recording of activities at random intervals to estimate the proportion of time spent on different tasks.
Work Sampling is used for the evaluation of Doctors, Nurses, and Pharmacists.
Work Sampling helps to calculate the total project cost by evaluating the monetary benefits of health interventions.
Work Sampling is a quantitative type of health management technique.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Work Sampling helps to calculate the total project cost by evaluating the monetary benefits of health interventions.

Explanation:
Work Sampling does not involve calculating project costs or evaluating monetary benefits.

  • It is primarily used to systematically observe and record the activities of individuals at random intervals to estimate how time is allocated among various tasks, aiding in workforce management and efficiency improvement. (Option A)
  • It is used to evaluate how time is spent by healthcare providers like doctors, nurses, and pharmacists on different activities. (Option B)
  • It is a type of quantitative health management technique. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate initial antihypertensive agent for a child with CKD and proteinuria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Enalapril

 

Explanation:

ACE inhibitors (Enalapril) and Angiotensin II Receptor Blockers (Losartan) are the antihypertensive medications of choice in all children with pediatric CKD as they decrease BP as well as proteinuria.

 

Treatment of Pediatric CKD: 

 

Nutrition Management
  • Dietary Protein restriction is not suggested.
  • Children with CKD stage 2-5 should receive 100% of the daily reference intake of vitamins and minerals.

Blood Pressure Control
  • Antihypertensive drugs, like ACE inhibitors or ARBs, are often prescribed to manage high BP.

Anemia Treatment
  • Erythropoietin-stimulating agents (ESAs) or iron supplements.

Phosphate Binders
  • (Calcium carbonate, calcium acetate, Sevelamer, Ferric citrate) to maintain normal serum calcium and phosphorus levels.

Ergocalciferol or Cholecalciferol
  • Typically recommended to treat insufficient 25OH vitamin D

Bicitra or Sodium Bicarbonate tablets
  • Used to maintain the serum bicarbonate levels > 22mEq/L.

Recombinant human growth hormone(rHuGH)
  • Given by daily subcutaneous injections and continues until the patient reaches the 50th percentile for mid-parental height.

Dialysis and Kidney Transplantation
  • Preferred treatment for children with end-stage renal disease.

Vaccinations
  • Special considerations for immunocompromised children.

 

  • Metoprolol (Option A), Amlodipine (Option B) & Furosemide (Option D): They do not have the added benefit of reducing proteinuria or slowing the progression of CKD.

questions.text: In a population of 1000 individuals, 200 develop oral cancers over a 10-year period. Among the total population, 100 are regular tobacco users, from which 60 developed oral cancers. Calculate the Population Attributable Risk (PAR) of oral cancers due to tobacco use in this population.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) 22%

Explanation:

 

Tobacco user

No Tobacco

Total

Disease Present

60

140

200

Disease Absent

40

760

800

Total

100

900

1000

Calculate the overall incidence rate (Itotal) of oral cancers in the population:

Given:

  • Total population (N) = 1000
  • Cases of oral cancers (C) = 200

Total = 200/1000 = 0.2
The overall incidence rate of oral cancers in the population (Itotal) is 0.2, or 20%.

Calculate the incidence rate (Iunexposed) of oral cancers in non-tobacco users:

Given:

  • Non-tobacco users = Total population (N) - Tobacco users.
  • Cases of oral cancers among non-tobacco users = Total cases - Cases among tobacco users.

Therefore, the incidence rate of oral cancers among non-tobacco users (Iunexposed) is 0.1556 or 15.56%.

Population Attributable Risk (PAR):


PAR = (0.20.−0.1556​)/0.2

= 0.044/ 0.2

= 0.22

Population Attributable Risk (PAR) of oral cancers due to tobacco use in this population is approximately 0.22 or 22%

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with hypopigmented patches on her skin and silvery-white hair. She also experiences easy bruising and prolonged bleeding following minor injuries. Examination reveals reduced iris pigmentation and visual impairment. Which primary pathological mechanism contributes to the hypopigmented skin observed in this patient?

choices.text: Ceroid lipofuscin accumulation in epidermal cells
Defective melanosome formation, trafficking, or transfer to keratinocytes
Autophagocytosis and defective fission of large melanosomes

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option C

EXPLANATION:

The given clinical scenario of a patient with symptoms of bleeding diathesis (easy bruising, prolonged bleeding following minor injuries), hypopigmentation of skin, hair & eyes with visual impairment & reduced iris pigmentation (oculocutaneous albinism), is suggestive of Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome.

Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome (HPS) is a rare, autosomal recessive form of oculocutaneous albinism and non-pigmented symptoms such as bleeding diathesis. 

It is caused by mutations in genes encoding components of specific protein complexes involved in lysosome biogenesis and trafficking. These mutations lead to impaired melanosome maturation and the absence of dense bodies in platelets.

Common manifestations across HPS subtypes include reduced pigmentation in the eyes, hair, and skin, along with easy bruising, bleeding tendencies, interstitial pulmonary fibrosis, and granulomatous colitis in severe cases.

Platelet granule defects: 
Alpha granule defect- Grey platelet syndrome
Delta granule defect- Hermansky Pudlak syndrome

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option A: Ceroid lipofuscin accumulation is observed in abnormal lysosomes of various organs in HPS, including alveolar macrophages in the lungs, it is not primarily associated with epidermal cells in the skin.

Option B: Weibel-Palade bodies are secretory granules found in endothelial cells and are involved in regulating vascular function. Dysregulation of Weibel-Palade bodies can result in impaired hemostasis, endothelial dysfunction, and a high risk of thrombus formation.

Option D: Autophagocytosis and defective fission of large melanosomes are seen in Chediak-Higashi syndrome, which occurs due to a loss-of-function mutation in the LYST gene (lysosomal trafficking regulator/CHS 1).

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with recurrent UTIs and a history of chronic immunosuppression after a renal transplant presents with non-tender abdominal nodules. The biopsy shows histiocytes with basophilic inclusions staining positive for PAS and von Kossa stains. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: Commonly associated with Gram-negative bacteria like E. coli
Characteristic histological feature is Langhans giant cells
Usually self-limiting and resolves without treatment

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Commonly associated with Gram-negative bacteria like E. coli

Explanation:

  • Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory condition often seen in immunocompromised patients, such as those with chronic immunosuppression following organ transplants.
  • It is commonly associated with Gram-negative bacteria, particularly Escherichia coli.
  • The histological hallmark of malakoplakia is the presence of von Hansemann cells (large, foamy histiocytes) and Michaelis-Gutmann bodies (PAS-positive, basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions that also stain with von Kossa and Perl’s stains).
  • Treatment- Antibiotics (fluoroquinolones, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), possible surgical excision

Michaelis-Gutmann bodies:

questions.text: A 10-year-old patient presents with symptoms suggestive of rheumatic fever. According to the modified Jones criteria, which of the following is considered a major criterion for diagnosing rheumatic fever for a low risk population ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Carditis

 

Explanation:

  • Carditis is one of the major criteria in the modified Jones criteria for diagnosing rheumatic fever.
  • It involves inflammation of the heart and is a significant sign of rheumatic fever.

Diagnosis of Initial ARF:

  • 2 Major Manifestations, or
  • 1 Major Manifestation plus 2 Minor Manifestations

 

Modified Jones Criteria for Diagnosing Rheumatic Fever

Historical Background:

  • Original Jones criteria established in 1944.
  • Significant updates in 1992 and later.

Key Components:

Criteria Type

Components

Major Criteria
  1. Carditis (Option D)
  2. Polyarthritis
  3. Chorea
  4. Erythema marginatum
  5. Subcutaneous nodules

Minor Criteria
  1. Fever (Option C ruled out)
  2. Arthralgia (Option A ruled out)
  3. Elevated acute phase reactants (e.g., ESR, CRP) (Option B ruled out)
  4. Prolonged PR interval on ECG

Major Criteria

Low-risk Population

  • Carditis (clinical or subclinical)
  • Arthritis (polyarthritis only)
  • Chorea
  • Erythema marginatum
  • Subcutaneous nodule

Moderate- to High-risk Population

  • Carditis (clinical or subclinical)
  • Arthritis (polyarthritis, polyarthralgia, and/or monoarthritis)
  • Chorea
  • Erythema marginatum
  • Subcutaneous nodule

 

Supporting Evidence:

  • Importance of clinical history, including:
    • Previous episodes of acute rheumatic fever
    • Presence of streptococcal infection

Echocardiographic Findings:

  • Recent adaptations include echocardiographic criteria to assess rheumatic heart disease (RHD).
  • Focus on valve abnormalities and functional implications.
  • World Heart Federation (WHF) guidelines provide specific criteria for diagnosing definite and borderline RHD.

questions.text: A 6 y/o child presents with irritability, pallor of nail beds, and fatigue. Laboratory tests reveal microcytic, hypochromic red cells, and reduced serum iron levels. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this child's iron deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Oral iron supplementation at 3-6 mg/kg/day

Explanation:
The patient's clinical features and lab findings are suggestive of iron deficiency anemia.

Oral iron supplementation at 3-6 mg/kg/day is the first-line treatment for iron deficiency anemia in children. It provides the elemental iron necessary to replenish stores and correct anemia.

 

Iron

Source:

  • Heme sources: meat, poultry, fish.
  • Nonheme sources: dairy, eggs, plant-based foods, breads, cereals, breakfast foods.

 

RDA

  • 1-9 yrs: 7-10 mg/day.
  • Adolescents:11-18 mg/day

 

Iron Deficiency Anemia

Causes:

  • Diminished dietary intake or reduced iron absorption in the proximal small intestine.
  • Excessive loss of body iron.
  • Intercurrent infections (e.g., hookworm infestation, malaria).
  • Dietary inhibitors (e.g., phytates, phosphates, tannates).
  • Cow’s milk is a poor source of bioavailable iron and is not advised for children under 1 year old.

Clinical Features

  • Behavioral: Irritability, anorexia.
  • The pallor of Nail beds, oral mucous membranes, and palpebral conjunctivae are reliable indicators
  • Physical: Weakness, fatigue, leg cramps, breathlessness, tachycardia.
  • Severe cases: Congestive cardiac failure, splenomegaly
  • Severe deficiency signs: Angular stomatitis, glossitis, koilonychia, paronychia

Laboratory Findings:

  • Peripheral blood smear: Microcytic, hypochromic red cells, anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, increased RDW.
  • Reduced MCV and MCHC.
  • Decreased serum iron, increased TIBC, transferrin saturation <16%.
  • Early reduction in serum ferritin, and high free erythroprotoporphyrin (FEP) before anemia.

Treatment

  • Address Underlying Causes: Identify and correct the cause of anemia, such as treating hookworm infestation.
  • Dietary Counseling: Provide guidance on iron-rich foods and avoid inhibitors of iron absorption.
  • Iron Supplementation:
    • Oral iron medications (e.g., ferrous sulfate, 20% elemental iron).
    • Dosage: 3-6 mg/kg/day of elemental iron,
    • Administration: On an empty stomach or between meals for best absorption,
    • Duration: Continue for 4-6 months after anemia correction to replenish iron stores,
    • Monitor reticulocyte count: Should increase within 72-96 hours of therapy initiation,
    • Side effects: Gastrointestinal issues (nausea, discomfort, vomiting, constipation, diarrhea)
  • Parenteral iron therapy: eg Injection Iron sucrose, Injection Ferric carboxymaltose.
  • Blood transfusion: Packed red cell transfusions are essential in emergencies such as severe bleeding, urgent surgery, or severe anemia with congestive heart failure (administered slowly with monitoring).

Iron-rich dietary counseling (Option A) is important but not sufficient as a standalone treatment for established iron deficiency anemia. It should complement iron supplementation.

Intravenous iron administration(Option C) is generally reserved for cases where oral iron is not effective, not tolerated, or when a rapid response is needed, which is not indicated as the initial treatment for this case.

Treatment for intercurrent infections(Option D) should be addressed if an infection is identified as a contributing factor, but the immediate treatment of iron deficiency anemia requires direct iron supplementation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with abnormal uterine bleeding and a pelvic mass. An ultrasound reveals a solid ovarian mass. The mass is surgically removed, and the HPE shows small, follicle-like structures filled with eosinophilic material. Which histological feature is most likely associated with this ovarian tumour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Call-Exner bodies

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and histopathological findings are consistent with a Granulosa cell tumour, a sex cord-stromal tumour.

  • Granulosa cell tumors are typically seen in postmenopausal women and secrete large amounts of estrogen, leading to a hyperestrogenic state.
  • Increased estrogen levels cause endometrial hyperplasia, which leads to abnormal uterine bleeding.
  • 2 microscopic features of Granulosa cell tumors:
    • Call-Exner bodies: These are small, follicle-like structures filled with pinkish eosinophilic material in the lumen of the follicles.
    • Coffee bean nuclei
  • Tumor marker: Inhibin and CD99 positivity

 

Spindle cells with lipid droplets (Option A): It descrives Fibrothecoma which is an ovarian tumor

Reinke crystalloids (Option C): Seen in Leydig cell tumor.

Signet ring cells (Option D): Seen in Krukenberg tumor.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			1. Durham’s rule
			
			
			a. A person is not guilty because of insanity if they were unaware of the nature, quality, and consequences of their acts or could not realise they were wrong.
			
		
		
			
			2. Curren’s rule
			
			
			b. An accused is not criminally responsible if their unlawful act is the product of mental disease or defect.
			
		
		
			
			3. McNaughten’s rule
			
			
			c. An accused is not criminally responsible if, at the time of the act, they couldn’t regulate their conduct due to mental disease or defect.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

 

Explanation:

Rules related to Criminal responsibility:

Durham’s rule
  • An accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of a mental disease or mental defect.
  • Later, this rule was discarded in the USA.

Curren’s rule

An accused person is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law as a result of mental disease or defect.

McNaughten’s rule

(Section 84, IPC,

Section 22, BNS)
  • A person is not criminally responsible if, due to a mental disease, they were unaware of the nature and consequences of their actions or unable to recognise that the act was wrong.
  • It has the following requirements:
    • There must be evidence of a mental disorder.
    • The mental disorder must be present at the time of the crime.
    • The disorder must impair the individual's ability to understand the wrongfulness or illegality of the act.

Section 85 IPC

(Section 23 BNS)
  • A person who is intoxicated may not be criminally responsible if they were so impaired at the time of the act that they could not understand the nature of their actions or recognize that their actions were wrong or illegal.
  • This applies only if the intoxication was caused against their will or without their knowledge.

Section 86 IPC

(Section 24 BNS)
  • A voluntarily intoxicated person is still considered criminally responsible if they had the intention or knowledge to commit a crime, despite their intoxication.

questions.text: A 78-year-old female Alzheimer's patient presents to the geriatric clinic with complaints of urinary urgency, frequency, and urge incontinence for the past six months. She is currently taking donepezil for Alzheimer's disease. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for managing this patient's urinary symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Trospium

Explanation:

  • Donepezil causes contraction of the detrusor muscle of the bladder, causing urinary incontinence.
  • Trospium, an anticholinergic medication, is commonly used to manage overactive bladder (OAB) symptoms in Alzheimer's patients.
  • This medication is particularly suitable for those with Alzheimer's disease and the elderly due to its reduced CNS penetration, which minimizes the risk of cognitive side effects compared to other anticholinergics like oxybutynin.

Oxybutynin (Option A) and Solifenacin (Option C): Although they are anticholinergic drugs and help in relaxing detrusor muscles, they cross the BBB and worsen the symptoms of Alzheimer's

Mirabegron (Option D): Mirabegron also treats OAB by relaxing the detrusor muscle, but Trospium is a better drug for treating OAB in Alzheimer's disease

questions.text: Which of the following is false for Anganwadi centres (AWC)?

choices.text: It is used to run ICDS
AWC can be opened on demand
1 AWC is for every 500-1000 people in plain areas

questions.solution:

1 AWC is for every 400-800 people in plain areas

 

Anganwadi centres (AWC):

AWC

Courtyard through which ICDS is run (Option A)

Capacity

    • Plain areas: 400-800 population
    • Hilly areas: 300-800 population

Anganwadi worker (AWW)

Supervises the work of AWWs

Supervises the overall functioning of ICDS.

1 CDPO can supervise:

  • 100 AWWs

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT used to minimize blood loss in myomectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) GnRH agonist given post-operatively


Explanation:

GnRH agonist is given preoperatively to reduce bleeding. It reduces tumour vascularity and reduces blood loss during the procedure.

Techniques for reducing blood loss in myomectomy:

  • Pre-operative GnRH agonist reduces bleeding.
  • Pre-operative correction of anaemia (Option A)
  • Arrange blood and FFP. Autotransfusion is also a possibility for major surgeries.
  • Intra-op methods used to stop bleeding:
    • Uterine clamp (myoma clamp)
    • Tourniquet (Option C)
    • Injection of vasopressin called Pitressin (Option D)
    • Avoid entering the uterine cavity

questions.text: A 60-year-old man on long-term proton pump inhibitor therapy for acid reflux undergoes an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy for recurrent epigastric discomfort. The endoscopy reveals smooth-surfaced lesions in the gastric body and fundus. Which statement about these findings is likely correct?

choices.text: PPIs decrease gastrin secretion, reducing the risk of fundic gland polyps
Fundic gland polyps are commonly associated with H. pylori infection.
Composed of cystically dilated glands lined by parietal, chief, and foveolar cells.
Sporadic fundic gland polyps carry a significant risk of neoplasia.

questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of smooth-surfaced lesions in the gastric body and fundus and a history of long-term proton pump inhibitor therapy suggest Fundic gland polyps.

  • Histologically, they are characterised by irregular, cystically dilated glands lined by parietal, chief, and foveolar cells, with minimal inflammation. (Option C)

PPIs decrease gastrin secretion, reducing the risk of fundic gland polyps (Option A): Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) inhibit acid production, leading to increased gastrin secretion, which can contribute to the growth of fundic gland polyps.

Fundic gland polyps are commonly associated with H. pylori infection (Option B): They are primarily associated with conditions such as familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), which is due to APC gene mutation.

Sporadic fundic gland polyps carry a significant risk of neoplasia(Option D): Sporadic fundic gland polyps usually have no significant neoplastic risk.

questions.text: During a disaster, a patient is suffering from a closed femur fracture with stable vital signs and another patient with a penetrating chest wound with respiratory distress. Which of the following are the colour coding given to the patients respectively based on triage principle?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Yellow and Red
 

Explanation:
The first patient, with a closed femur fracture and stable vitals, is triaged as YELLOW, requiring assistance within 24 hours. The second patient, in respiratory distress, necessitates immediate resuscitation and is triaged as RED.

Triage:

During a disaster, the quantity and severity of injuries overwhelm the operative capacity of the health facilities. Triage involves rapidly organizing the injured individuals based on the severity of their injuries and survival with prompt interventions.

During triage, tagging should be done to each individual, including:

  1. Name
  2. Age
  3. Place of origin
  4. Triage category
  5. Diagnosis and
  6. Initial treatment.

Color coding in triage:

 

Types of triage:

Reverse triage:

  • Used in surge (bed scarcity) and during wars.
  • Priority: Green→Yellow→Red.

Simple triage and Rapid Treatment (START):

  • Done in remote or inaccessible areas.
  • Laymen can start doing triage before rescue teams reach.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is appropriate to administer to an 18-month-old child who has not received any prior vaccination according to national immunisation schedule?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (A) OPV + MMR

  • OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine) and MMR (Measles, Mumps, Rubella) are administered up to 5 years of age in the catch-up vaccination schedule.

  • BCG is given only up to 1 year of age, so it is not recommended at 18 months. (Option C, D)

  •  Pentavalent (DPT, Hep B, Hib) is given up to 1 year of age and is not recommended after that. (Option B)

Delayed Immunization Schedule

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a content of the broad ligament?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Urethra

Explanation:

Urethra is a tube that conducts urine from the bladder to the outside of the body. It is part of the urinary system and is not contained within the broad ligament.

Broad Ligament

Definition

Two winglike structures extending from the lateral uterine margins to the pelvic sidewalls, each formed by a double layer of peritoneum

Function

The broad ligament helps stabilize the uterus's position within the pelvic cavity.

Contents
  • Fallopian tube - Upper portion: The peritoneum that folds over the fallopian tube is the mesosalpinx.
  • Round ligament - Anteriorly: The peritoneum surrounding the round ligament is called the mesoteres. (Option A)
  • Ovarian ligament - Posterior fold: The peritoneum that encompasses the ovarian ligament is known as the mesovarium.
  • Vestigial structures of Wolffian body - Epoophoron and paroophoron.
  • Vestigial structure of Wolffian duct - Gartner's duct.
  • Ureter. (Option B)
  • Uterine vessels.
  • Pelvic nerves.
  • Parametrial lymph node.
  • Pelvic cellular tissue condensed to form Mackenrodt 's ligament.
  • lnfundibulopelvic ligament (suspensory ligament of the ovary) - Outer border of the broad ligament. (Option C)

Blood Supply
  • Uterine artery, courses through the base of the broad ligament and supplies the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries.
  • Ovarian artery, enters the broad ligament through the infundibulopelvic ligament and supplies the ovaries and fallopian tubes.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the major regulator of carnitine acyltransferase I (CAT-I) activity?
questions.solution:
Malonyl CoA is the major regulator of CAT-I activity. Malonyl CoA inhibits CAT-I, thus preventing the entry of long-chain acyl groups into the mitochondrial matrix

 

The fate of fatty acid in the cell:

 

  • Fatty acids (FAs) bind to membrane receptors and enter the cytoplasm via transporters.
  • Fatty acyl CoA synthetase adds CoA to the fatty acids.
  • Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase 1A (CPT1A) converts fatty acyl CoA to acylcarnitine, which crosses the mitochondrial outer membrane.
  • Inside the matrix, acylcarnitine exchanges with free carnitine through Carnitine Acyl Carnitine Transferase (CACT).
  • Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase 2 (CPT2) then converts acylcarnitine back to acyl-CoA esters.

Regulation By CAT-I:

  • Mobilized fatty acids enter mitochondria for beta-oxidation.
  • Carnitine acyl transferase I (CAT-I) regulates this entry.
  • In Low energy states:
    • Conditions like diabetes and starvation,
    • Glucagon levels increase.
    • Increased glucagon decreases malonyl CoA levels.
    • Reduced malonyl CoA levels lead to increased beta-oxidation in the mitochondria.
  • In High energy states:
    • Insulin levels are high.
    • Increased insulin increases malonyl CoA levels.
    • Increased malonyl CoA leads to decreased fatty acid oxidation
    • Hence, Acyl CoA gets stored in the form of TAG in the cells

Insulin and glucagon (Option A and B) do not directly influence CAT-1 but their levels indirectly influence it, by increasing or decreasing malonyl COA levels.
 

ATP (Option D) does not directly regulate CAT-I activity.
