questions.text: Which one of the following tests is used to study the association between the use of oral contraceptive pills (OCP) and breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chi-square test

Explanation :
Chi-Square Test is a non-parametric test used to study the association between two qualitative variables. In this scenario, breast cancer and OCP use are both qualitative variables.

questions.text: Which of the following is the comprehensive program the Ministry of Women and Child Development launched to combat trafficking?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ujjawala scheme

 

Explanation:

 

The Ujjawala scheme

The Ujjawala scheme, launched in India on December 4, 2007, by the Ministry of Women and Child Development, is a comprehensive program to combat trafficking. The scheme is primarily implemented through NGOs.

Objectives/Goals

Strategies to Achieve Goals

Prevention

  • Formation of community vigilance and adolescent groups, awareness creation
  • preparation of IEC (Information, Education, Communication) material, organization of workshops.

Rescue
  • Safe withdrawal of victims from the place of exploitation.

Rehabilitation
  • Providing safe shelter, basic amenities, medical care, legal aid, vocational training, and employment opportunities to victims.

Reintegration
  • Supporting victims in their reintegration into society.

Repatriation

  • Providing support to cross-border victims for their safe return to their home countries.

 

The Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana (PMUY) (Option B) is a key initiative to provide rural and underprivileged households with access to clean cooking fuels like LPG, replacing traditional cooking fuels. It comes under the Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas (MOPNG)

The UJALA (Unnat Jyoti by Affordable LEDs for All) scheme (Option C) aims to promote energy efficiency by distributing LED bulbs at affordable prices. This initiative reduces energy consumption and lowers household electricity bills. It also contributes to environmental sustainability by cutting down carbon emissions. The Ministry of Power administers it.

The PM Sahaj Bijli Har Ghar Yojana (PM Saubhagya scheme)(Option D) was initiated in September 2017 to provide electricity to every household by December 2018. The Ministry of Power administers it.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male with a history of epilepsy presents to the emergency department with ongoing tonic-clonic seizures that have lasted for the past 20 minutes. What is the initial drug of choice for the management of status epilepticus in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lorazepam

Explanation:

  • Lorazepam is the drug of choice for the management of status epilepticus due to its rapid onset of action and effectiveness in terminating seizures.
  • It acts by enhancing the effects of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the brain, thereby reducing neuronal excitability and terminating seizures.

Management of status epilepticus:

 

Position the head, provide oxygen, and monitor vital signs.

↓

Establish vascular access and check glucose levels.

↓

Administer benzodiazepines (preferably lorazepam IV).

↓

If seizures persist after 2 doses of benzodiazepines.

↓

Administer antiepileptic drugs (Fosphenytoin, Phenytoin, Levetiracetam, Valproic acid).

↓

If refractory status epilepticus suspected

↓

Initiate continuous infusion of Midazolam, Pentobarbital, Thiopental, or Propofol.
  • Phenobarbital (Option A) and Valproate (Option D) are used in the management of status epilepticus but are not the first-line treatments.
  • Intravenous administration of Lamotrigine (Option C) is contraindicated in emergency situations due to its association with Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman testified in court that she did not give consent during an alleged sexual assault. The case involves an offense under Section 63 of the BNS. During cross-examination, the defense lawyer attempts to question her about her past sexual relationships. The court intervenes and prevents this line of questioning. Which of the following provisions are relevant to this case?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) BSA section 48

 

Explanation:

Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam (BSA) Section 48 states that in a prosecution for an offence under section 64 to 78 of the BNS or for attempt to commit any such offence, where the question of consent is in issue, evidence of the character of the victim or of such person’s previous sexual experience with any person shall not be relevant on the issue of such consent or the quality of consent.

 

Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) Section 48 (Option B) is related to abetment outside India for offence in India. Hence, it is irrelevant in this scenario.

 

Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita (BNSS) Section 48 (Option C) covers the obligation of a person making an arrest to inform about the arrest to a relative or friend, making this option irrelevant.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient has symptoms of a productive cough and difficulty clearing thick mucus from their airways. The patient has a history of COPD and frequently experiences episodes of breathing difficulties. Which of the following drugs can be used to reduce the viscosity of the mucus, thus increasing its clearance in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bromhexine

Explanation:

Bromhexine is a mucolytic agent that helps to break down and reduce the viscosity of mucus, facilitating its removal by coughing.

This action can be beneficial in conditions like COPD, where mucus plugs can obstruct airways and exacerbate breathing difficulties.

Albuterol (Option A) is a bronchodilator.

Dextromethorphan (Option B) is an antitussive.

Guaifenesin (Option D) is a mucokinetic.

None of these directly address the need to reduce mucus viscosity and enhance mucus clearance through coughing.

questions.text:
The patient's blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Four different sphygmomanometers measure his BP, each with 3 readings. Match the sphygmomanometers with their respective accuracy and precision parameters.

 


	
		
			
			Sphygmomanometer readings
			
			
			Accuracy and Precision parameters
			
		
		
			
			1. 120/80, 120/80, 120/80
			
			
			a. Precise but inaccurate
			
		
		
			
			2. 140/96, 108/62, 96/82
			
			
			b. Imprecise but accurate
			
		
		
			
			3. 140/96, 140/96, 140/96
			
			
			c. Precise and accurate
			
		
		
			
			4. 122/82, 120/80, 118/78
			
			
			d. Imprecise and inaccurate
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b

Explanation:

 

A game of darts can help one understand precision and accuracy. Let the centre point be the true value or gold standard value.

  • Accuracy: Closeness to true value.
  • Precision: Findings are replicable.

 

Accurate & precise

Not accurate & precise

Accurate & not precise

Not accurate & not precise

Every line hits the central point exactly at the gold standard value.

The same finding is seen, but far from the true value; it is inaccurate.

It is accurate as the result is closer to the true value in the first circle; it is not precise.

It is not precise or accurate.

Correct Matching:

120/80, 120/80, 120/80 - c) Precise and accurate.
This set of readings consistently measures 120/80 mm Hg, indicating both precision (reproducibility of measurements) and accuracy (close to the true value).

140/96, 108/62, 96/82 - d) Imprecise and inaccurate.
These readings vary significantly (140/96, 108/62, 96/82), indicating both lack of precision (inconsistent measurements) and accuracy (not close to the true value).

140/96, 140/96, 140/96 - a) Precise but inaccurate.
Readings are consistent (140/96 each time), indicating precision (reproducibility) but they are consistently incorrect, hence inaccurate.

122/82, 120/80, 118/78 - b) Imprecise but accurate.
The readings vary slightly (122/82, 120/80, 118/78), indicating lack of precision (slightly inconsistent measurements), but they are close to the true value (accurate).

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student is brought to the emergency after ingesting amphetamine pills night before his final exam. On examination, he presents with agitation, hyperthermia, and severe hypertension. His pupils are dilated, and urine catheterisation reveals dark urine. Which of the following is next best step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Administer ammonium chloride

Explanation:

Ammonium chloride is used to promote urinary drug excretion in cases of Amphetamine poisoning

Amphetamine Poisoning:

  • Abused as “performance-enhancing drugs” among students and sportspersons.
  • Also called “rave party drugs”: Ecstasy/crystal/ methamphetamine/MDMA.
  • Triad: Sudden psychosis + Hypertension + Golden coloured urine.
  • Treatment:
    • Ammonium chloride turns the urine pH acidic and causes forced diuresis of basic drugs like amphetamines.
    • Chlorpromazine: treats psychosis and hypertension through alpha-blocking action.

 

Intravenous sodium bicarbonate (Option A): is used for urinary alkalization in cases of salicylate poisoning (weak acid), which manifests as tinnitus, nausea, and vomiting.

Flumazenil (Option B): is used to reverse the effects of benzodiazepine poisoning, which appears with symptoms of CNS depression and impaired mental status.

Naloxone (Option D): is an opioid antagonist used to treat opioid overdoses, which present as pinpoint pupils and respiratory depression.

questions.text: 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset palpitations, dizziness, and mild shortness of breath. He is known case of pre-excitation syndrome and has a heart rate of 180 bpm and BP of 118/72 mmHg. His ECG shows a wide complex regular tachycardia with QRS duration of 140 msec. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Procainamide

  • The buzz word is pre-excitation syndrome with broad qRS tachycardia. The accessory pathway like bundle of Kent is allowing antegrade conduction causing wide qRS complex tachycardia. The best drug is procainamide that slows conduction via both AV node and Accessory pathway controlling the re-entry circuit.
  • Verapamil will worsen the patient by blocking AV node. Amiodarone is used in VT but not for AVRT. DC shock is used in hemodynamic compromise.

questions.text: A 35-year-old carpenter presents with pain and weakness in his right forearm after repetitive hammering. On examination, you note tenderness over the medial epicondyle and weakness in wrist flexion. There is no sensory loss. Based on these findings, which muscle is not likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Flexor pollicis longus

 

Explanation:

Flexor pollicis longus is a deep muscle of the anterior compartment of forearm which helps in flexion of distal phalanges of the thumb and no action in flexion of wrist.

 

  • The muscles of the anterior compartment of forearm are the flexor-pronator muscles and arranged in 3 layers:
    • Superficial layer:
      • Pronator teres
      • Flexor carpi radialis
      • Flexor carpi ulnaris
      • Palmaris longus
    • Intermediate layer:
      • Flexor digitorum superficialis
    • Deep layer:
      • Flexor digitorum profundus
      • Flexor pollicis longus
      • Pronator quadratus

 

Superficial muscles of anterior compartment of forearm consists of 5 muscles:

1. Pronator teres:

Origin
  • Humeral head- Medial epicondyle of the humerus (via the common flexor tendon)
  • Ulnar head - Coronoid process of the ulna

Insertion

Lateral surface of the midshaft of the radius.

Action

Pronates the forearm and weak flexor of elbow.

Nerve Supply

Median nerve (C6, C7).

2. Flexor Carpi Radialis (FCR):

Origin

Medial epicondyle of the humerus (via the common flexor tendon).

Insertion

Base of the second and third metacarpal bones.

Action

Flexes and abducts the wrist (radial deviation).

Nerve Supply

Median nerve (C6, C7).

3. Palmaris Longus:

Origin

Medial epicondyle of the humerus (via the common flexor tendon).

Insertion

Flexor retinaculum and palmar aponeurosis.

Action

Flexion of hand at wrist makes palmar aponeurosis tense.

Nerve Supply

Median nerve (C7, C8).

4. Flexor Carpi Ulnaris:

Origin
  • Humeral head- Medial epicondyle of the humerus (via the common flexor tendon)
  • Ulnar head- Olecranon and posterior border of the ulna.

Insertion

Pisiform, hook of hamate, and base of the fifth metacarpal.

Action

Flexes and adducts the wrist

Nerve Supply

Ulnar nerve (C7, C8).

5. Flexor Digitorum Superficialis:

Origin
  • Humeroulnar head- Medial epicondyle of the humerus and coronoid process of the ulna
  • Radial head- Oblique line of the radius

Insertion

Middle phalanges of the 2nd to 5th digits.

Action

Flexion of middle and proximal phalanges of digits.

Nerve Supply

Median nerve (C7, C8, T1)

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presented with a 6-week history of swelling of both cheeks as shown, redness of eyes and cough. She reported having difficulty moving the right side of her face. On examination, Angiotensin-converting enzyme levels were elevated. Lymph node biopsy showed the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Heerfordt syndrome

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a subacute variant of Sarcoidosis characterized by Uveo-Parotid fever and facial nerve palsy, known as Heerfordt syndrome.

 

Heerfordt Syndrome:

  • Subacute variant of Sarcoidosis, characterized by anterior uveitis, Parotitis and Facial nerve palsy.
  • ACE (Angiotensin-converting enzyme) levels elevated.
  • Biopsy shows non-caseating granulomas.
  • Treatment: Systemic corticosteroids.

 

Syndromes associated with Facial nerve palsy:

Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Wegener’s Granulomatosis)

(Option C)
  • Autoimmune necrotizing vasculitis.
  • Granulomas in respiratory tracts and kidneys.
  • Facial nerve paralysis with Sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Diagnosis: Elevated c-ANCA.
  • Treatment: Cyclophosphamide + steroids.

Lyme Disease

(Option B)
  • Cause: Borrelia burgdorferi, Vector: Hard tick.
  • Flu-like symptoms, erythema migrans, bilateral facial palsy.

                      Fig: Erythema migrans
  • Diagnosis: Serologic testing.
  • Treatment: Doxycycline or amoxicillin, if contra-indicated - Azithromycin.

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome
  • Peripheral facial nerve palsy with erythematous vesicular rash on ear or mouth.

Melkersson–Rosenthal Syndrome

(Option A)
  • Recurrent alternating facial palsy, furrowed tongue, faciolabial edema.

Moebius Syndrome
  • Congenital agenesis of VI and VII cranial nerve nuclei.
  • Seen with Misoprostol teratogenicity.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a painful, erythematous skin rash over his leg that started two days ago and has been consistently increasing with a history of fever for the past two days. On examination, a tender, erythematous rash with ill-defined margins is visible. The local rise in temperature is present. There are no fluctuant nodules. Which is the most common causative organism for the infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Beta-hemolytic streptococci

  • Cellulitis is an acute bacterial infection involving the deeper dermis and subcutaneous tissue of the skin.
  • It occurs when bacteria enter through a breach in the skin barrier.
  • Present as a warm, tender, erythematous rash with oedema. Margins are ill-defined, unlike erysipelas. There are no fluctuant nodules
  • Treatment:
    • First line Flucloxacillin/ Clarithromycin/Benzylpenicillin;
    • Second line: Roxithromycin
  • Prophylaxis for recurrent infections: Long-term penicillin/ erythromycin.

Candida albicans (Option A): The most common cutaneous manifestation is inflammation of the skin folds, such as intertrigo. It does not lead to acute, progressive cellulitis.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option C): The causative organism for ‘hot tub’ folliculitis, characterized by monomorphic perifollicular rashes following prolonged exposure to contaminated water. It is associated with cellulitis only in neutropenic patients.


Clostridium perfringens (Option D): It causes Clostridial myonecrosis, a severe, rapidly progressing infection characterized by sudden onset, bullous lesions, tense skin, and severe tenderness. Signs of significant systemic toxicity are also present.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with fatigue, muscle weakness, and bone pain for the past several months. She has a history of hypothyroidism and is currently taking levothyroxine. She lives in North India and avoids dairy products. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness over her shins. Laboratory tests reveal:


	
		
			
			Serum calcium
			
			
			8.2 mg/dL (normal range: 8.5-10.5 mg/dL)
			
		
		
			
			Serum phosphorus
			
			
			2.0 mg/dL (normal range: 2.5-4.5 mg/dL)
			
		
		
			
			Parathyroid hormone (PTH)
			
			
			Elevated
			
		
	


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the above scenario, the patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings are most likely to be Vitamin D deficiency.

Blood findings of Vitamin D deficiency

Biochemical Feature

Explanation

Hypocalcemia

Due to decreased calcium absorption in the intestine.

Hypophosphatemia

Due to decreased phosphate absorption in the intestine and decreased reabsorption of phosphate in the kidneys.

Secondary Hyperparathyroidism

In response to low calcium levels, the parathyroid hormone (PTH) increases, which increases calcium reabsorption from bone and the kidneys.

Elevated Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)

Due to Increased bone turnover as a result of increased PTH.

25-hydroxy cholecalciferol

Decreased.

 

Prolonged secondary hyperparathyroidism can cause renal osteodystrophy, which may lead to pathological fractures.

Primary hyperparathyroidism (Option B) leads to excess PTH production, causing hypercalcemia.

Hypoparathyroidism (Option C) presents with low PTH and hypocalcemia. Hypothyroidism is commonly associated with vitamin D deficiency, potentially due to immune dysfunction and impacts on calcium metabolism

Chronic kidney disease (Option D) causes secondary hyperparathyroidism due to impaired phosphate excretion and low 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D levels, it is typically associated with hyperphosphatemia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old swimmer presents with weakness during arm extension and difficulty pulling objects toward himself. He also reports pain during forceful expiration, such as coughing or sneezing. Which muscle is most likely involved, and what is its nerve supply?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Latissimus Dorsi; Thoracodorsal nerve

 

Explanation:

Latissimus Dorsi is involved in arm extension, adduction, medial rotation and forceful expiration (such as coughing or sneezing); innervated by the thoracodorsal nerve.

 

Muscles of the posterior Axioappendicular Region

Muscle

Origin

Insertion

Nerve Supply

Actions

Trapezius (Option A ruled out)
  • Medial one-third of the superior nuchal line of the skull
  • External occipital protuberance
  • Ligamentum nuchae
  • Spinous processes of C7 to T12 vertebrae
  • Corresponding supraspinous ligaments
  • Upper fibers: Posterior border of the lateral one-third of the clavicle
  • Middle fibers: Medial margin of the acromion and upper lip of the spine of the scapula
  • Lower fibers: Apex of a triangular area at the medial end of the spine of the scapula (intervening bursa)
  • Spinal accessory nerve (CN XI)
  • Proprioceptive fibers from C3 and C4.
  • Upper fibers: Elevate the scapula (shoulder shrugging), extend the neck (bilaterally)
  • Middle fibers: Retract the scapula
  • Lower fibers: Rotate the scapula upward, aiding arm abduction beyond 90 degrees
  • Trapezius with rhomboids: Retract scapula and tilt glenoid inferiorly.
  • Trapezius with serratus anterior: Overhead abduction and tilt glenoid superiorly.
  • All fibers together: Stabilize the scapula during arm movements

Latissimus Dorsi (Option B)
  • Posterior one-third of the outer lip of the iliac crest
  • Posterior layer of lumbar fascia (connecting to lumbar and sacral spines)
  • Spinous processes of T7 to T12
  • Lower four ribs
  • Inferior angle of the scapula

Fibers twist to insert into the floor of the intertubercular sulcus of the humerus, wrapping around the lower border of the teres major.

Thoracodorsal nerve (C6, C7, C8).
  • Extends, adducts, and medially rotates the arm (e.g., swimming, climbing)
  • Assists in forceful expiration (e.g., coughing, sneezing)

Levator Scapulae (Option D ruled out)

Transverse processes of C1 to C4 vertebrae

Superior angle and upper part of the medial border of the scapula

Dorsal scapular nerve (C5) and branches from C3 and C4

Elevates and stabilizes the scapula during arm movements.

Rhomboid Minor (Option C ruled out)

Lower part of ligamentum nuchae and spinous processes of C7 and T1

Medial border of the scapula at the base of the triangular area at the root of the spine.

Dorsal scapular nerve (C5)

Retracts and stabilizes the scapula.

Rhomboid Major

Spinous processes of T2 to T5 and supraspinous ligaments

Medial border of the scapula, below the root of the spine

Dorsal scapular nerve (C5)

Retracts and stabilizes the scapula.

questions.text: What is the major concern associated with bupivacaine toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cardiotoxicity

 

Explanation:

Bupivacaine is known for its potential cardiotoxic effects, particularly when administered in high doses or if accidentally injected into a blood vessel, which can lead to severe cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.

 

Bupivacaine

Classification
  • Bupivacaine is an amide-type local anesthetic

Mechanism of Action

  • It works by blocking sodium channels in nerve membranes, preventing the propagation of nerve impulses, which results in local anesthesia.

Clinical Uses

  • Commonly used for spinal, epidural, and peripheral nerve blocks.
  • Widely used in labor and delivery for epidural anesthesia and in long-duration surgeries.

Duration of Action
  • Longer duration of action compared to other local anesthetics like lidocaine. It can provide anesthesia for several hours, making it ideal for prolonged procedures.

Onset of Action
  • Has a slower onset (10-15 minutes) compared to faster-acting anesthetics like lidocaine.

Cardiotoxicity
  • Major concern with bupivacaine is its potential for cardiotoxicity, especially at higher doses or when inadvertently injected intravenously, leading to severe arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.

Metabolism
  • Metabolized primarily in the liver by cytochrome P450 enzymes and excreted by the kidneys.

Enantiomers
  • The S-enantiomer of bupivacaine, known as levobupivacaine, is associated with reduced cardiotoxicity and is often used as a safer alternative.

Lipid Solubility & Protein Binding

  • Bupivacaine has high lipid solubility and high protein binding, which contributes to its prolonged duration of action.

Contraindications
  • Should be avoided in patients with severe cardiac arrhythmias, and caution should be used in patients with liver disease due to its hepatic metabolism.

Common Side Effects
  • In addition to cardiotoxicity, other potential side effects include CNS toxicity, such as dizziness, seizures, and lightheadedness, especially with accidental intravascular injection.

Toxicity
  • Direct intravenous injection or rapid vascular uptake of the drug is the most common reason for bupivacaine toxicity, which has an upper limit of 2.5 to 3.5 mg/kg upper limit of dosing.
  • Treatment for toxicity: 20% intralipid solution.

questions.text: In the Complement Fixation Test (CFT), what indicates a positive result?

choices.text: Lysis of sheep red blood cells (SRBCs)
Formation of an immune complex between antigen and antibody
No lysis of sheep red blood cells (SRBCs)
Presence of active complement in the serum

questions.solution:
No lysis of sheep red blood cells (SRBCs) indicates a positive CFT. In a positive test, the complement is fixed by the immune complex formed between antigen and antibody, leaving no free complement to lyse the SRBCs.

 

Complement Fixation Test (CFT):

  • Purpose: Detects specific antigens or antibodies in serum by measuring complement fixation.
  • Principle: Immune complex (antigen-antibody binding) fixes complement, which is then detected using sensitised sheep red blood cells (SRBCs).

Procedure of CFT:

 

Step

Description

Step 1: Complement Fixation

1. Heat patient serum to inactivate native complement.

2. Add known antigen or antibody and complement.

3. Immune complex fixes the complement if a specific antigen or antibody is present.

Step 2: Indicator Stage

1. Add sensitised SRBCs (coated with amboceptor) to the mixture.

2. Positive CFT: Complement fixed, no SRBC lysis.

3. Negative CFT: Free complement lyses SRBCs.

 

Applications:

  • Sensitivity: Detects 0.04 mg of antibody nitrogen and 0.1 mg of antigen.
  • Example: Wassermann reaction for syphilis diagnosis.

Limitations:

  • Requires precise standardisation of reagents.
  • Sera may contain non-specific complement inhibitors, leading to false positives.

Indirect Complement Fixation Test:

  • Modification: Used for sera that cannot fix guinea pig complement (e.g., avian/mammalian sera).
  • Method: Add standard antiserum that can fix complement after the first CFT stage.
    • Positive Result: Hemolysis occurs if antigen-antibody binding has consumed the complement.

Other Complement-Dependent Serological Tests:

 

Test Type

Description

Immune Adherence

Bacteria aggregate and adhere to cells (e.g., erythrocytes) in the presence of complement and specific antibodies.

Immobilisation Test

Antibodies inhibit bacterial motility with complement (e.g., Treponema pallidum immobilisation test).

Cytolytic/Cytocidal Tests

Bacteria are lysed or killed when mixed with specific antibodies and complement.

 

Lysis of sheep red blood cells (SRBCs) (Option A) indicates a negative result, as it shows that the complement was not fixed, and the SRBCs are free to be lysed.

 

Formation of an immune complex (Option B) occurs in both positive and negative results but does not directly indicate a positive outcome.

 

Presence of active complement in the serum (Option C) before heating could interfere with the test, but it is not an indicator of a positive result.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with opioid use disorder presents with severe muscle aches, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, restlessness, and chills after stopping heroin "cold turkey." He has piloerection, dilated pupils, tachycardia, and mild hypertension. He refuses opioid for managing the withdrawals. What is the most appropriate initial pharmacological treatment for his opioid withdrawal symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Clonidine

 

Explanation:

Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that helps reduce the autonomic symptoms of opioid withdrawal, such as sweating, restlessness, tachycardia, and hypertension.

  • It works by decreasing sympathetic outflow, which alleviates symptoms like piloerection, tremors, and rhinorrhea.
  • Clonidine is particularly useful in patients who are unwilling to use opioid-based treatments as in this patient.
  • Methadone (Option A) and Buprenorphine and Naloxone combination therapy (Options B & D) are opioid agonists used for maintenance therapy, but this patient prefers a non-opioid treatment.

 

Opioid withdrawal symptoms include

  • Muscle and Bone aches, Abdominal cramps
  • Diarrhea, Lacrimation, Rhinorrhea, Sweating - resembles flu
  • Piloerection/ Gooseflesh ("Cold Turkey" Means Abstinence Syndrome)
  • Frequent yawning, Insomnia
  • Mydriasis
  • Hypertension, Tachycardia
  • Temperature Dysregulation (Hypothermia Or Hyperthermia)
  • Nausea, vomiting, and restlessness

 

Treatment of Opioid Withdrawal

Detoxification

Maintenance
  • Opioid Agents
  • Methadone: Opioid Agonist.
  • Buprenorphine:Partial Opioid Agonist.

Opioid Substitution Therapy (OST):

  • Methadone: Full opioid agonist
    • Improves treatment retention and reduces criminal behavior.
    • 80–120 mg/day.
    • Side effects: constipation, sweating, sexual dysfunction.
  • Buprenorphine:
    • Partial opioid agonist with a ceiling effect (limits overdose risk).
    • Combined with naloxone to prevent abuse.
    • Taken sublingually (tablet/film).
    • Side effects: constipation, nausea, drowsiness.
 
  • Opioid Antagonists (Naloxone, Naltrexone):
    • Naloxone: Reverses opioid overdose (emergency use).
    • Naltrexone: Blocks opioid effects to prevent euphoria, reduces opioid cravings. Available in oral and long-acting injectable forms.
    • Does not cause dependence or withdrawal but requires patient adherence.

Opioid addicted patient but unwilling to be treated with opioids: Symptomatic agents

  • Clonidine
    • Alpha-2 Adrenergic Agonist.
    • Reduces autonomic withdrawal symptoms- Sweating, Restlessness, Tremor or Rhinorrhea.
  • Anxiety: Benzodiazepines
  • Insomnia: Zolpidem
  • Musculoskeletal Pain: NSAIDs (Ibuprofen)
  • GI Symptoms: Antiemetic Diarrhea (Loperamide)

Pregnant Women with Opioid Use Disorder:

  • Illicit opioid use during pregnancy increases risks for both mother and baby
  • Methadone or buprenorphine maintenance reduces risks, though neonatal opioid withdrawal may still occur.
  • Associated risks- Neonatal infections (HIV), premature labor, low birth weight, and sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).

Psychotherapy Modalities/ Non- Pharmacological Treatment:

  • Effective treatments: Individual therapy, CBT, family therapy, support groups (NA), and social skills training.
  • Social skills training is key for patients with poor social skills.
  • Residential programs for people with substance use disorders.
  • Education on HIV transmission and safe sex is essential.
  • Needle-exchange programs, where available, help reduce unsafe needle sharing and associated infections.
  • Narcotics Anonymous (NA): A 12-step self-help group for abstinent drug addicts.

 

Naloxone (Option D) is a short-acting opioid antagonist used for reversing opioid overdose, not for treating withdrawal.

questions.text: Based on the graph showing potassium ion permeability during an action potential, at which point does the permeability of potassium ions reach its peak?
questions.solution:
• Point D signifies the early phase of repolarization.
  • At this stage, voltage-gated potassium channels are fully open, leading to the highest permeability to potassium ions.

  • Resting Membrane Potential (Point A on graph):
    • At rest, the neuron's membrane potential is around -70 mV.
    • K+ permeability is higher than Na+ permeability due to the presence of K+ leak channels.
    • However, the overall permeability to both ions is relatively low.
  • Depolarization Phase (Between Points A and C):
    • Voltage-gated Na+ channels open faster than K+ channels.
    • Rapid influx of Na+ ions, causing a rapid rise in membrane potential, causing a steep slope.
  • Peak of Action Potential (Point C):
    • Na+ permeability is at its maximum.
    • K+ channels are also opening at this stage but have not reached their peak.
  • Early Repolarization Phase (Point D):
    • Early phase of repolarization.
    • Voltage-gated K+ channels are fully open, resulting in the highest permeability.
    • Na+ channels are rapidly inactivated during this phase.
  • Late Repolarization and After-hyperpolarization (Points E and F):
    • K+ permeability starts to decline as the membrane potential moves towards its resting state.
    • Slow closure of K+ channels results in a period of hyperpolarization, where the membrane potential falls slightly below the resting potential (Point F).

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of previous abdominal surgeries presents with severe abdominal pain that initially started as crampy but has become constant and steady. The patient has a temperature of 102 degrees, 128 beats per minute heart rate, and elevated white blood cell count. Which diagnostic test is most appropriate for confirming in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CECT

 

Explanation:

  • This is a case of strangulating obstruction, characterized by constant, steady pain, fever, tachycardia, and elevated white blood cell count.
  • Given the patient’s history of previous abdominal surgeries, there is a risk of adhesions leading to strangulation.
  • Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm this condition, as it provides detailed images that help identify bowel ischemia and assess vascular compromise effectively.

Strangulating obstruction

Feature

Strangulating Obstruction

Definition

Mechanical obstruction with compromised blood supply.

Pain

Constant, steady pain.

Systemic Symptoms

Fever, tachycardia, and elevated white blood cell count.

Diagnostic Tests

Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT) for detailed evaluation.

Additional Features

Systemic signs of infection (e.g., fever) and inflammation.

Management

Requires urgent surgical intervention to address ischemia and restore blood flow.

questions.text: Which of the following risk factors has highest relative risk for development of stroke and does not show risk reduction with treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Diabetes mellitus

The questions is worded from Harrison. The reference table states up to 6 times risk

16-30%

2.0

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal discomfort. Ultrasound reveals a 5 cm unilocular cystic mass adjacent to the left ovary but separate from it. The ovary itself appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Paraovarian mass

Explanation:

Paraovarian masses are cystic structures in the broad ligament adjacent to but separate from the ovary.

  • Origin: Typically non-neoplastic; arise from paramesonephric duct remnants or mesothelial inclusion cysts.

  • Ultrasound appearance: Unilocular, thin-walled cysts.

  • Symptoms: Often asymptomatic; discovered incidentally during imaging or surgery.

  • Mimicry: When symptomatic, can mimic ovarian cysts.

  • Imaging limitations: Difficult to distinguish from ovarian pathology; managed like ovarian cysts.

  • Treatment: Usually cystectomy or drainage with fulguration.

  • Solid tumors: Rare; most commonly leiomyomas.

  • Management of solid tumors: Typically removed due to the inability to rule out malignancy via imaging alone.

 

Theca lutein cysts (Option A) are usually bilateral and multiple, originate from the ovary itself, and are associated with ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome or gestational trophoblastic disease.

 

Functional ovarian cysts (Option B) originate from the ovary and typically present with a normal-appearing ovary. They are typically smaller (usually < 3 cm), except for a large corpus luteum cyst.

 

Ovarian fibroma (Option D) is a solid tumor of the ovary, appearing as a solid mass within the ovary rather than a cystic structure, and is typically seen in older women (perimenopausal or postmenopausal).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the role of ultrasonography (USG) and laparoscopy in the diagnosis of genital tuberculosis (TB) in women?

choices.text: USG can definitively diagnose genital TB by detecting specific tuberculous lesions in the pelvic organs.
Laparoscopy is mainly used to assess the extent of tubal damage in genital TB, and it allows for direct visualization and biopsy of the affected tissues.
USG is more effective than laparoscopy in identifying tubal obstruction caused by genital TB.
Both USG and laparoscopy are equally effective in diagnosing genital TB and can be used interchangeably.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Laparoscopy is mainly used to assess the extent of tubal damage in genital TB, and it allows for direct visualization and biopsy of the affected tissues.

Explanation:

Laparoscopy is a crucial tool for diagnosing genital TB because it permits direct visualization of the pelvic organs, identification of lesions, and allows for biopsy collection and fluid aspiration for culture, which is essential for a definitive diagnosis.

USG, while useful for identifying abnormalities and guiding further investigation, cannot definitively diagnose genital TB or assess tubal damage as accurately as laparoscopy can (also assess feasibility of adhiolysis in severe distortion).

Investigations for Pelvic Tuberculosis:

  • Blood: Total leucocyte count and ESR may be raised
  • Mantoux test: less specific
  • Chest X-ray: To look for evidence of healed or active pulmonary lesions
  • Diagnostic uterine curettage
    • One part in normal-saline for:
      • Histopathological examination to detect the giant cell system.
    • One part in normal saline for:
      • Culture in Löwenstein-Jensen media
      • Identification of the acid-fast bacilli by Ziehl- Neelsen’s stain (AFB-microscopy)
      • Nucleic acid amplification
      • Guinea pig inoculation.
    • Liquid culture
    • Nucleic acid amplification test
    • GeneXpert (CBNAAT)
  • Biopsy
  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG): In a proven case, HSG is contraindicated for the risk of reactivation of the lesion.
  • Imaging: USG, IVU, CT, MRI
  • Laparoscopy
  • Hysteroscopy

questions.text:
A 54-year-old female with intractable diarrhea and pigmentation was diagnosed with Cronkhite-Canada syndrome. Which of the following statements regarding the disease are true?


	Hamartomatous polyp of colon
	Seen only in females
	Polyps can be present in the stomach and duodenum as well
	15% can turn malignant
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1,2,3,4

 

Explanation:

Cronkhite-Canada syndrome:

  • A rare, non-hereditary syndrome characterised by gastrointestinal polyposis and ectodermal changes.
  • Demographics: Predominantly affects females, typically diagnosed in middle to late adulthood. (Statement 2)
  • Clinical Features:
    • Intractable diarrhoea
    • Cutaneous hyperpigmentation
    • Alopecia (hair loss)
    • Onychodystrophy (nail abnormalities)
  • Polyp Distribution: Hamartomatous polyps are present throughout the gastrointestinal tract, primarily in the stomach, duodenum, and colorectum. (Statements 1 and 3)
  • Malignancy Risk: Approximately 15% of cases may undergo malignant transformation. (Statement 4)
  • Management: Requires a multidisciplinary approach, including nutritional support, endoscopic surveillance, and treatment of associated complications.

questions.text:
An immunocompromised individual presents with a corrugated white lesion on the side of the tongue as shown in the image below, which does not wipe off. The most likely causative agent is?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Epstein Barr Virus (EBV)

 

Explanation:

  • It is known to cause oral hairy Leukoplakia, an EBV-induced lesion typically occurring in immunocompromised individuals.
  • The lesion appears as a white, corrugated (or hairy) patch that cannot be wiped off, which matches the presentation in the image.

Disease associated with EBV

Pathognomonic Findings

Classic Symptoms

Infectious Mononucleosis

Atypical lymphocytosis, positive heterophile antibody test, elevated liver enzymes
  • Fever
  • Pharyngitis, Lymphadenopathy (posterior cervical)
  • Splenomegaly

Burkitt Lymphoma

"Starry sky" appearance on histology
  • Rapidly growing jaw or abdominal mass

Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma

Undifferentiated carcinoma with EBV DNA in tumor cells
  • Nasal obstruction
  • Epistaxis
  • Hearing loss
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy

Hodgkin Lymphoma

Reed-Sternberg cells on histology
  • Painless lymphadenopathy
  • B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss), pruritus

Oral Hairy Leukoplakia

White, hairy patches on lateral tongue, non-scrapable
  • Asymptomatic, common in immunocompromised individuals

EBV-associated Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis (HLH)

Hemophagocytosis in bone marrow/tissues
  • Fever
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Cytopenias
  • Hyperferritinemia
  • Hypertriglyceridemia

Gastric Carcinoma

EBV DNA in gastric carcinoma
  • Weight loss
  • Abdominal pain
  • Nausea and Vomiting

Incorrect Options:

Candida (Option A): It typically causes oral thrush, which presents as white plaques that can be wiped off, unlike the corrugated lesion shown in the image.

 

Candida lesions that cannot be wiped off:

  • Chronic Hyperplastic Candidiasis
  • Erythematous Candidiasis

Human Herpes Virus (HHV6) (Option C): It is not commonly associated with oral lesions in immunocompromised patients. HHV-6 more often reactivates to cause roseola in infants or is asymptomatic in adults.


Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) (Option D): It is associated with Kaposi's sarcoma, not corrugated white oral lesions. Kaposi's sarcoma typically presents as red or purple lesions in the oral cavity or on the skin.

questions.text: According to the Hindu Marriage Act, of 1955, which of the following is considered a ground for a void marriage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bigamy

 

Explanation:

Bigamy (entering into another marriage without dissolving the first) is classified as a void marriage, null from the time of inception.

 

The Hindu Marriage Act, 1955, outlines the legal framework for Hindu marriages in India, addressing the

  • Grounds for void and voidable marriages
  • Grounds for divorce

 

Grounds for Void and Voidable Marriages:

 

Void Marriage

Voidable Marriage

Null from the time of inception.

Remains valid until annulled by the court

Bigamy (entering into another marriage without dissolution of the first).

Impotence (Option A ruled out)

Prohibited degree of relationship (blood relations), unless permitted by custom.

Unsoundness of mind of either party at the time of marriage (Option C ruled out)

Sapinda relationship (relationship extending to 3rd generation in the line of ascent through the mother and 5th generation through the father)

Consent obtained by force, fraud, or misconception of facts (Option D ruled out)
 

Pregnancy of the woman by another person, unknown to the husband at the time of marriage

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a history of two miscarriages, both occurring in the first trimester. Genetic testing of the products of conception shows chromosomal anomalies. What is the most common chromosomal abnormality to cause abortions among the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aneuploidy

Explanation:

The most common chromosomal abnormality to cause abortion is Aneuploidies as a group which will includes trisomies aswell as monosomy. Among aneuploidies - Trisomies as a group are most common & Trisomy 16 is most common trisomy responsible. 
 

Causes of Isolated Abortion

Causes of Recurrent Abortion

Chromosomal abnormalities are the most common causes of early miscarriages.

  • Autosomal trisomy is the most common cause of cytogenetic abnormality which accounts for 50% of cases.
  • The most common trisomy is Trisomy 16. (Option C) (30%)
  • Polyploidy is observed in 22% of cases.
  • Monosomy X (20%) and structural chromosomal rearrangements (2-4%) are also observed.
 

Infections:

  • Viral: Rubella, cytomegalovirus, variola, vaccinia or HIV.
  • Parasitic: Toxoplasma, malaria.
  • Bacterial: Ureaplasma, chlamydia, brucella.
 

Maternal systemic diseases (Diabetes, thyroid disorders, hemoglobinopathies)

 

Endocrine Factors:

  • Luteal phase defect
  • Deficient progesterone
  • Thyroid abnormalities
  • Diabetes mellitus
 

Cervicouterine factors:

  • Fibroid
  • Intrauterine adhesions
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Mullerian anomalies
 

Environmental factors:

  • Smoking and alcohol consumption
  • Contraceptive agents like IUD

Parental Chromosomal Abnormalities.

  • Robertsonian translocations
  • Inversions
  • Aneuploidies
  • Other structural chromosomal abnormalities
 

Anatomical Factors:

  • Uterine Leiomyomas
  • Asherman Syndrome
  • Uterine Polyps
  • Mullerian Defects, most commonly septate uterus
 

Immunological Factors:

  • SLE
  • APLA
 

Endocrine Factors:

  • Overt Hypothyroidism and Iodine Deficiency
  • Subclinical Hypothyroidism with Anti-Thyroid Antibodies

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 41 weeks and 5 days of gestation reports a decrease in fetal movements over the past few days. Which of the following complications is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Polyhydramnios

Explanation:

Polyhydramnios: Excessive amniotic fluid, is not typically associated with post-dated pregnancies. It is commonly seen in maternal diabetes, fetal anomalies, or infections.

Adverse Maternal and Perinatal Outcomes Associated with Post-term Pregnancy:

Maternal

Perinatal

Fetal macrosomia:(Option A)

 

Is a common complication of post-dated pregnancies due to the extended period of fetal growth.

Stillbirth

Oligohydramnios:

(Option B)

Reduced amniotic fluid, because the placenta becomes less efficient at maintaining amniotic fluid levels as it ages.

Post-maturity syndrome

Pre-eclampsia

Meconium aspiration syndrome(Option D):

The fetus is more likely to pass meconium into the amniotic fluid, which can be inhaled into the lungs during birth.

Postpartum hemorrhagic

Hypoxic ischemia encephalopathy

Labour dystocia

Birth injuries

Perineal lacerations

Childhood obesity

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with headaches and focal neurological deficits. Imaging reveals a tumour located in the cerebral hemispheres, characterised by infiltrative growth and low cellularity. Which of the following options best describes the likely diagnosis for this tumour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Diffuse Astrocytoma

Explanation:

  • The diffuse astrocytoma fits the clinical description of infiltrative growth and low cellularity and is commonly located in the cerebral hemispheres.

Diffuse Astrocytoma

  • Prognosis: Intermediate
  • Common Site: Cerebral hemispheres
  • Histological Features: Infiltrative, low cellularity. These tumours are characterised by their gradual growth and infiltration into surrounding brain tissue.
  • Management: Surgical resection is the primary treatment. Radiation or chemotherapy might be considered based on risk factors or residual disease.

questions.text:
Match the following neurotransmitters with their site of production in CNS.

 


	
		
			
			A. Acetylcholine (ACh)
			
			
			1. Raphe nuclei
			
		
		
			
			B. Norepinephrine (NE)

The sites of production of neurotransmitters are as follows:

 

Neurotransmitters

Description
