questions.text: 2-5% of autopsies cannot determine the cause of death even after extensive lab investigations. What are such autopsies called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Negative autopsy

 

Explanation:

In a negative autopsy, the cause of death remains unknown

 

Obscure autopsy (Option A ruled out)

Negative autopsy (Option B)
  • The cause of death may not be clear at the time of dissection but can often be determined after detailed clinical, and laboratory investigations, and interviews
  • Examples: Epilepsy, reflex vagal inhibition, uremia, and anesthetic overdose
  • The cause of death remains unknown even after extensive laboratory investigations
  • Occurs in 2-5% of all postmortem cases

questions.text: Which of the following contraceptive agents are used as the first-line agents in heavy menstrual bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Combined Oral Contraceptives ( COCs)

 

Explanation:

  • Combined Oral Contraceptives (POPs), thin the endometrial lining, preventing its build-up. This results in lighter menstrual periods and is an effective mechanism for reducing heavy menstrual bleeding. Hence, it is the first-line agent used in heavy menstrual bleeding.
  • Progesterone is prescribed to control abnormal bleeding, as it has fewer withdrawal effects and stabilises the endometrium. If progesterone is ineffective, estrogen is given to prevent excessive bleeding.

 

Progesterone-only pills (Option B) are used in the treatment of heavy bleeding & dysmenorrhea. It is the drug of choice for lactating women.

 

Copper-containing Intrauterine Device (IUD) (Option C) are contraindicated in heavy menstrual bleeding as they are known to cause heavy menstrual bleeding.

 

Contraceptive patch (Option D) can also be effective in managing menstrual bleeding, but progesterone-only pills are used as the first-line agents.

questions.text:
Which of the following is incorrect about this scan?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Fibrous cortical defects show hot spot
Tracer in the bladder is physiological
In cellulitis tracer does not show prolonged retention in delayed phase

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fibrous cortical defects show hot spot

 

Explanation:

  • The given image is of a Bone scan
  • Fibrous cortical defects show a cold spot

 

Bone scan:

 

Definition

Nuclear medicine study using technetium-99m (Tc-99m-MDP)

Absorption

~50% of injected dose absorbed by bones (2-6 hours post-injection)

Phases of Study

1. Immediate phase

2. Blood pool phase

3. Delayed phase

4. Optional delayed phase

Indications
  • Detection and follow-up of skeletal metastases
  • Radiographically occult fractures (e.g., stress fractures)
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Complex regional pain syndrome
  • Evaluation of hip joint prosthesis for infection or loosening
  • Paget disease

Patient Preparation
  • Optimal hydration
  • Remove metal objects
  • Void before study

Conditions Affecting Uptake
  • Increased uptake in kidneys/liver in conditions like thalassemia and hemochromatosis
  • Poor image quality with reduced renal function

Tracer Dose
  • 740 - 925 Mbq (20 - 25 mCi) administered intravenously in adults

Renal Uptake
  • Useful for detecting renal abnormalities; faint/absent uptake commonly due to renal insufficiency

Results

Normal: If the radiotracer is present evenly throughout all the bones.

Abnormal:

  • Will show hot spots or cold spots as compared to surrounding bone.
  • Hot spots are areas where there is an increased collection of radioactive material.
  • Cold spots are areas that have taken up less of the radioactive material.

Hot Spots

Areas of new bone formation; are seen in:

  • Fractures
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Osteoblastic bone metastasis

Cold Spots

Seen in:

  • Multiple myeloma (normal alkaline phosphatase)
  • Fibrous cortical defects (VS fibrous dysplasia shows hot spots)

Physiological Presence
  • Tracer present in the bladder due to renal excretion (Option B)

Superscan:

  • Multiple bones show hot spots without kidney uptake.
  • Seen in conditions that affect multiple bones, like hyperparathyroidism and renal failure. (Option D)

Triple-Phase Bone Scan:

 

Criteria

Osteomyelitis

Cellulitis

Delayed Phase Imaging

Tracer retained in the bone (hot spot)

The tracer does not show prolonged retention in the bone (Option C)

Blood Pool Imaging

Increased uptake can occur

Increased uptake can also occur

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of lacrimal pump failure, leading to excessive tearing (epiphora)?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Bell’s palsy

Explanation:

  • The lacrimal pump mechanism relies on the proper function of the orbicularis oculi muscle and the correct positioning of the punctum.
  • In Bell’s palsy, Weakness of the orbicularis oculi muscle prevents proper eyelid closure and tear drainage, as the orbicularis oculi muscle is involved in both the tear suction and drainage phase of the lacrimal pump mechanism.
  • This leads to epiphora (excessive tearing).

Clinical evaluation for Watering Eye (Epiphora):

  • Eyelid and Punctal Examination: Eversion of the punctum can be observed in ectropion or lax eyelids.

Fluorescein Dye Test: This test can help assess the tear drainage system by observing the time it takes for dye to disappear from the eye.

  • Lacrimal Syringing test: Testing with probing or syringing may help identify blockages in the tear drainage system, such as in the canaliculi or nasolacrimal duct.

Trauma to the canaliculus (Option A): While an injury to the canaliculus can block the tear drainage system, it does not directly disrupt the lacrimal pump mechanism. Trauma may cause scar formation or narrowing, but it primarily impacts tear flow through mechanical obstruction rather than pump function.

 

Obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct (Option C): This condition involves a blockage in the nasolacrimal duct, preventing proper tear drainage. However, it is considered a mechanical obstruction rather than a lacrimal pump failure.

 

Narrowing of the punctum (Option D): Punctal stenosis refers to a narrowing or closure of the punctum (the opening at the corner of the eyelid that drains tears). While this causes tear accumulation, it results from a physical obstruction at the punctum, not from a dysfunction of the lacrimal pump mechanism.

questions.text: Which of the following is the largest hepatitis virus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: HCV

  • Hepatitis C is the largest virus. Size is 55 nm while hepatitis B is 42 nm.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered overcrowding?

choices.text: 1 person living in a floor space of 65 sq.ft.
2 persons aged 7 of opposite gender in the same room
A child aged 8 years living in a floor space of 45 sq.ft.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2 persons aged 7 of opposite gender in the same room

Explanation:

Overcrowding is considered when 2 persons of age 9 or more of the opposite gender, not husband and wife, live in the same room.

Overcrowding:

A situation where more people live in a space less than recommended can affect their

  • physical (poor hygiene standards, spread of infections).
  • psychosocial health (difficult sleep, inadequate privacy).

Accepted standards:

Persons Per Room

Floor Space (1 sq.m. = 10 sq.ft.)
  • 1 room - 2 persons
  • 2 rooms - 3 persons
  • 3 rooms - 5 persons (Option A)
  • 4 rooms - 7 persons
  • 5 or more rooms - 10 persons (2 per each room)
  • Not recommended: <50 sq.ft.
  • ½ person : 50-70 sq. ft. (Option D)
  • 1 person: 70-90 sq. ft. (Option B)
  • 1 ½ persons: 90-100 sq. ft.
  • 2 persons : >110 sq. ft.
  • A baby <12 months of age are not counted as a person
  • A child aged 1-10 years is counted as half a unit (Option D)

questions.text:
Match the following


	
		
			
			1. Aliskiren
			
			
			a) Central sympatholytic
			
		
		
			
			2. Lisinopril
			
			
			b) Acts on JG cells of the kidney to reduce renin release
			
		
		
			
			3. Losartan
			
			
			c) Direct renin inhibitor
			
		
		
			
			4. Clonidine
			
			
			d) Prevents formation of Angiotensin 2
			
		
		
			
			5. Beta-blockers
			
			
			e) Block Angiotensin 1 receptor
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-c, 2-d, 3-e, 4-a, 5-b

Explanation: 

 

Name of drug

Class

Mechanism of action

Aliskiren

Direct renin inhibitor

Blocks the formation of angiotensin 1, which decreases BP.

Lisinopril

ACE inhibitor

Blocks the conversion of angiotensin 1 to angiotensin 2

Losartan

ARB

Blocks angiotensin 1 receptor

Clonidine

Central sympatholytic

It acts on alpha 2A receptors, decreasing sympathetic discharge from the brain and reducing renin secretion.

Metoprolol, Atenolol

Beta-blockers

Act on JG cells of the kidney to reduce renin release.

questions.text: Before performing radial artery cannulation on a 7-year-old child for continuous blood pressure monitoring during major surgery, the anesthesiologist compresses both the radial and ulnar arteries, asks the child to make a fist, then releases the ulnar artery while keeping the radial artery compressed. What is the primary purpose of this maneuver?

choices.text: To assess the elasticity of the arterial walls
To evaluate collateral circulation in the hand
To determine the size of the radial artery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) To evaluate collateral circulation in the hand

Explanation:

  • This maneuver, known as the Modified Allen's test, is a non-invasive procedure used primarily to evaluate the collateral circulation in the hand before radial artery cannulation. Its main purposes are:
    • To assess the patency and adequacy of the ulnar artery
    • To evaluate the completeness of the palmar arch
  • The test is performed as follows:
    • Both ulnar and radial arteries are compressed.
    • The child is asked to clench their fist several times to expel blood from the hand.
    • The hand is then opened, appearing pale.
    • Pressure on the ulnar artery is released while maintaining compression on the radial artery.
    • If the hand flushes within 5-7 seconds, it indicates adequate collateral circulation through the ulnar artery.

  • A positive test (rapid flushing) suggests that it's safe to proceed with radial artery catheterization, as the ulnar artery can adequately perfuse the hand if the radial artery is compromised during or after the procedure.
  • A negative test, where the hand fails to flush within 5-15 seconds, suggests inadequate or absent ulnar circulation.
  • In this case, avoid puncturing the radial artery, as it is the sole source of arterial blood to that hand.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male from a tropical region presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and a soft, fleshy nasal mass. Histopathological examination reveals thick-walled sporangia filled with endospores and hyperplastic tissue without eosinophilic infiltration. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is correct?

choices.text: It affects the mucosal membrane of the nose only.
The recommended course of primary treatment is Dapsone
The causative agent cannot be cultured in vitro
It is not associated with contaminated water exposure

questions.solution:
Answer: C) The causative agent cannot be cultured in vitro.

 

 

Explanation:

Rhinosporidium seeberi is a eukaryotic pathogen that exhibits characteristics of both fungi and protozoa, making it difficult to culture in laboratory settings.

Rhinosporidiosis

  • Chronic granulomatous infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi
  • Primarily affects mucosal membranes of: (Option A ruled out)
    • Nose
    • Nasopharynx
    • Conjunctiva
    • Urethra
  • Endemic in tropical and subtropical regions; associated with contaminated water exposure (Option D ruled out)

Microbiology of Rhinosporidiosis

Aspect

Details

Causative Agent
  • Rhinosporidium seeberi - eukaryotic pathogen exhibiting features of fungi and protozoa; cannot be cultured in vitro (Option C)

Pathogenesis
  • Occurs via endospores infecting traumatized mucosal surfaces, leading to hyperplastic growths and rhinosporidial polyps

Histopathology
  • Presence of thick-walled sporangia (50-1000 μm) filled with endospores (5-10 μm)
  • Surrounding tissue shows hyperplasia and infiltration by inflammatory cells (lymphocytes, plasma cells)
  • The lack of eosinophilic infiltration distinguishes it from similar infections.

Staining Techniques
  • H&E: Identifies sporangia and inflammatory response
  • PAS: Stains endospores positively
  • GMS: Visualizes fungal elements

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Clinical Presentation

  • Nasal Masses:
    • Soft, fleshy lesions, pedunculated or flat
    • Red or granular appearance with yellowish-white dots (mature sporangia)
  • Symptoms:
    • Nasal obstruction
    • Epistaxis (nosebleeds)
    • Discharge

Diagnosis

  • Histopathology:
    • Definitive through examination of excised tissue showing characteristic sporangia and inflammation.
  • Clinical History:
    • Important to note exposure to stagnant water or endemic areas.

Treatment

Treatment Option

Details

Surgical Intervention

Wide surgical excision of lesions.

Cauterization of base is recommended to minimize recurrence.

Adjunctive Therapy

Postoperative Dapsone is used to prevent recurrence, though efficacy is controversial due to resistance. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A 50 y/o man undergoes a total hip replacement. Postoperatively, he develops difficulty walking and reports numbness along the posterior thigh, lateral leg, and sole of the foot. O/E, he has weakness in extending the hip and flexing the knee. The injured nerve originates from which of the following spinal roots?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) L4–S3

 

Explanation:

The patient’s symptoms, including weakness in hip extension, knee flexion, and sensory loss along the posterior thigh and leg, are indicative of sciatic nerve injury.

  • The sciatic nerve originates from the ventral rami of the L4–S3 spinal roots.

    • L2–L4 (Option A) forms the femoral/obturator nerves.

    • L5–S1 (Option C) is part of the sacral plexus but not the full sciatic root

    • S1–S5 (Option D) contributes to the pudendal and coccygeal nerves.

Takeaway:

Sciatic nerve = largest nerve, root value L4–S3, vulnerable in hip surgery/injections.

 

 

Sciatic Nerve course

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with weakness in the upper limb following a fall on his shoulder. Physical examination reveals impaired movement in the extensor muscles of the arm. Injury to which part of the brachial plexus is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Middle trunk, posterior division

Explanation:

The posterior divisions of the brachial plexus innervate the extensor muscles of the upper limb. The middle trunk is a direct continuation of the C7 ventral ramus and its posterior division supplies the extensor muscles.

Brachial Plexus Trunks: 

  • Formation:
    • Five ventral rami (C5–T1) form three trunks.
    • Upper Trunk: Formed by C5 and C6.
    • Middle Trunk: Continuation of C7.
    • Lower Trunk: Formed by C8 and T1, crossing over the first rib.
  • Location:
    • Trunks emerge between anterior and middle scalene muscles.
    • Positioned anteriorly to each other, with the subclavian artery running anteromedially.
  • Divisions:
    • Each trunk divides into:
      • Posterior Divisions: Innervate extensor muscles.
      • Anterior Divisions: Innervate flexor muscles.
  • Clinical Relevance:
    • Trunks, especially the upper trunk, can be palpated in the supraclavicular fossa.
    • Important for procedures like nerve blocks.

Brachial Plexus Trunk Formation and Divisions:

Trunk

Formation

Divisions

Upper Trunk

Union of C5 and C6 rami

Anterior: Flexor muscles (Option A ruled out)

Posterior: Extensor muscles

Middle Trunk


 

Continuation of C7

Anterior: Flexor muscles (Option B ruled out)

Posterior: Extensor muscles (Option C)

Lower Trunk

Union of C8 and T1 rami

Anterior: Flexor muscles (Option A ruled out)

Passing over first rib

Posterior: Extensor muscles

questions.text: A 26 y/o male from a rural area in India presents to the clinic with complaints of anxiety, fatigue, and weakness. He is preoccupied with the belief that he is losing semen during urination and nocturnal emissions. He also describes his semen as "milk-like." He is concerned that this will lead to physical weakness and impotence. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dhat syndrome

Explanation:

  • Dhat syndrome is characterized by the fear of semen loss through nocturnal emission, urination, or other means, leading to anxiety, somatic complaints, and weakness, which fits the patient's presentation.
  • His cultural background and the description of his semen as "milk-like" align with the typical presentation of Dhat syndrome.

 

Culture bound syndromes: patterned behaviors of distress or illness whose symptoms appear distinct from psychiatric categories and considered unique to particular cultural settings.

  • Such as Dhat syndrome and Koro syndrome.

 

Dhat syndrome

Koro syndrome
  • Definition: A psychiatric condition marked by fear of semen loss through ejaculation, nocturnal emission, or other means.
  • Cultural Context: Leading culture-bound syndrome in the Indian subcontinent, tied to Ayurvedic beliefs that semen is vital for health.
  • Demographics: Affects young, unmarried males from lower socioeconomic and rural backgrounds.
  • Age: The average onset is around 26 years.
  • This can lead to depression and sexual dysfunction
  • Clinical Presentation
    • Symptoms: Anxiety, fatigue, weakness, and impotence from the fear of semen loss.
    • Beliefs: Semen loss through nocturnal emissions, urination, defecation, or arousal.
    • Somatic Complaints: Physical symptoms tied to weakness, infertility, and fear of death.
    • Semen Description: Often described as "milk-like" or "pus-like."
  • Treatment
    • Psychiatric Care: Treated similarly to depression, with psychotherapy (sex education to dispel the myths) and antidepressants.
  • Diagnosis
    • ICD-10: Concern over semen loss (seen as whitish discharge in urine) with associated anxiety and physical symptoms.

Female Dhat syndrome, presenting with nonpathological vaginal discharge ("safedpaani") seen as a vital fluid, is triggered by warm foods, stress, and dietary imbalances, causing somatic symptoms and linked to Ayurvedic beliefs about bodily balance.
  • Definition: A psychiatric disorder characterized by an intense fear of genital retraction into the body, believed to result in death (in males, the penis; in females, the vulva or breasts).
  • Epidemiology:
    • Epidemic Koro: Common in parts of East and Southeast Asia (e.g., China, India, Malaysia), linked to cultural beliefs and myths.
    • Sporadic Koro: Occurs globally, unrelated to culture, often secondary to psychiatric disorders (e.g., schizophrenia, depression) or substance use.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Overwhelming anxiety with belief of genital retraction and impending death.
    • Symptoms: Panic attacks, physical attempts to prevent retraction, measuring genitals, insomnia, and fear of death
  • Treatment:
    • Psychotherapy: Sex education and counselling to dispel myths.
    • Medications: Anxiolytics, antidepressants, antipsychotics, and sedatives (based on psychiatric comorbidities).


 

Koro syndrome (Option A) involves the fear of genital retraction rather than semen loss and is prevalent in different regions of Asia.

Premature ejaculation (Option C) is a sexual dysfunction, but the focus in this case is on semen loss and its perceived effects, not on ejaculation timing.

Hypochondriasis (Option D) involves excessive health anxiety, but Dhat syndrome specifically involves culturally bound fears of semen loss rather than general health anxiety.

questions.text: All the factors inhibit gastric emptying except?

choices.text: A large volume of solid meals

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hypotonic solution in duodenum

Explanation:

Hypotonic solutions do not inhibit gastric emptying. In fact, they may even promote faster gastric emptying due to their lower osmolarity.

Factors Promoting Gastric Emptying:

Factor

Mechanism

Vagal stimulation

Stimulates antral contraction, promoting gastric emptying

Liquid meal

Faster gastric emptying due to lower viscosity and faster transit through the stomach

Motilin

Stimulates antral contraction and gastric emptying, especially during the interdigestive state

 

Factors Inhibiting Gastric Emptying:

 

Factor

Mechanism

Acid in the duodenum

Releases secretin, inhibiting antral contraction and stimulating pyloric sphincter contraction

Products of fat digestion

Releases CCK and GIP, inhibiting gastric emptying

Hypertonic solutions in the duodenum

Releases hormones inhibiting gastric emptying

Products of protein digestion

Releases gastrin, CCK, and GIP, inhibiting gastric emptying

Large meal volume (solids)

Prolongs gastric emptying time

Stretching of duodenum

Initiates enterogastric reflex, inhibiting gastric emptying

Sympathetic stimulation

Decreased gastric motility (by norepinephrine) and increased pyloric sphincter tone.

Hormones (CCK, GIP, secretin)

-

questions.text: A 15-year-old male child presents with bilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and unsteadiness. His mother had a history of multiple meningiomas and unilateral vestibular schwannoma. Which of the following genetic mutations is most likely associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) NF2 gene mutation

 

Explanation:

The patient's presentation along with a family history of similar features strongly suggests Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2), which is caused by a mutation in the NF2 gene.

Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2) Less Common: NF2 is rarer than NF1.

  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant; affects Schwann cells, leading to tumors on nerve insulation.
  • Incidence: 1 in 25,000 births.
  • Genetic Location: NF2 gene on chromosome 22q1.11.

Diagnosis Criteria (Manchester & Baser Criteria)

NF2 is diagnosed with one of the following:

(Mnemonic: MISME- Multiple inherited schwannomas meningioma and ependymoma)

  • Bilateral Vestibular Schwannomas.
  • Family History + either:
    • Unilateral vestibular schwannoma
    • Any two of the following: meningioma, schwannoma, glioma, neurofibroma, or posterior subcapsular lenticular opacities.
  • Unilateral Vestibular Schwannoma + any two of the features above.
  • Multiple Meningiomas (≥2) + either:
    • Unilateral vestibular schwannoma
    • Any two of the above-listed features.

Clinical Manifestations

  • Common Symptoms:
    • Tinnitus
    • Hearing loss
    • Facial weakness
    • Headache
    • Unsteadiness
  • Age of Onset: Symptoms usually emerge in childhood; cerebellopontine angle masses are common in 20s-30s.
  • Other Signs:
    • Childhood: Café-au-lait macules (CALMs), skin plexiform schwannomas
    • Posterior subcapsular lens opacities in ~50% of cases.

Genetics

  • Mutation: NF2 gene mutation leads to loss of merlin/schwannomin protein.

Management

  • Approach: Conservative management focusing on hearing preservation and quality of life.
  • Regular Monitoring:
    • Ophthalmologic evaluations
    • Brain and spinal MRI
    • Audiology assessments
    • Brainstem-evoked potentials

Comparison Table: NF2 vs. Schwannomatosis vs. Legius Syndrome

Feature

NF2

Schwannomatosis

Legius Syndrome

Tumors

Schwannomas (esp. vestibular)

Multiple schwannomas,

No vestibular schwannomas

Multiple CALMs, no neurofibromas, Lisch nodules

Genetic Mutation

NF2 (22q1.11) (Option C)

SMARCB1 (INI1) (Option D ruled out)

SPRED1 (Option B ruled out)

Diagnosis

Based on criteria (bilateral schwannomas, family history)

Multiple schwannomas, family history

CALMs, macrocephaly

Management

Conservative, regular monitoring

Yearly MRI, no established guidelines

Symptomatic management

 

NF1 (Option A): gene mutation is associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1), which primarily presents with neurofibromas, café-au-lait spots, and Lisch nodules, not vestibular schwannomas.

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines acts on B cells to stimulate class switching to IgE and promotes the development of additional Th2 cells in type I hypersensitivity reactions?
questions.solution:
Interleukins

Role

IL-4
  • Key cytokine in driving the allergic response
  • Enhances Ig E-mediated reaction
  • Stimulates B cells to undergo class switching to IgE and promotes the expansion of Th2 cells

IL-5 (Option B)

Development and activation of eosinophils→ Recruited to the site of allergen exposure→ Release inflammatory mediators and enzymes→ Tissue damage and inflammation

IL-13 (Option C)
  • Amplifies IgE production
  • Acts on epithelial cells to stimulate mucus secretion

IL-10 (Option D)
  • Anti-inflammatory cytokine
  • Inhibits cytokine production by Th1 cells and macrophages.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with palpable purpura on the lower extremities, arthralgia, and abdominal pain. Laboratory tests show elevated serum IgA levels and red blood cell casts in urine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a 10-year-old child with palpable purpura, arthralgia, abdominal pain, elevated serum IgA levels, and RBC casts in urine is suggestive of Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP).

  • Clinical features (PAAARpura):
    • P: Palpable purpura (typically lower extremities and buttocks)
    • A: Arthralgia / joint pain
    • A: Abdominal involvement (pain, nausea, GI bleeding possible)
    • A: Associated with elevated IgA (causative immunoglobulin)
    • R: Renal involvement (hematuria, red blood cell casts)
  • Pathophysiology: HSP is a Small-vessel vasculitis mediated by IgA immune complex deposition.
    • IgA deposits weaken vessel walls, leading to purpura and bleeding.
    • Because the platelet count is normal, also called as non-thrombocytopenic purpura.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male following RTA presented with a deformity of the lower limb. The clinician prescribed him a splint as shown below.



What is the likely site of injury in this patient based on the markings in this X-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) 4


 

Explanation:

  • A foot drop splint has been prescribed to this patient, seen in Common peroneal nerve injury.
  • The most common site of common peroneal nerve injury is the Neck of the fibula.

Markings in the X-ray:

1 - Medial femoral condyle

2 - Intercondylar eminence

3 - Lateral femoral condyle

4 - Neck of fibula

Common peroneal nerve injury:

Anatomy:
  • The terminal branch of the sciatic nerve arises from the popliteal fossa.
  • Root value: L4,L5,S1 & S2.
  • Hooks around the neck of the fibula.
  • Terminates by dividing into Superficial peroneal nerve & Deep peroneal nerve

Muscles supplied:
  • Superficial peroneal nerve: Peroneus longus & brevis (foot eversion)
  • Deep peroneal nerve: Peroneus tertius, Tibialis anterior, Extensor digitorum, Extensor hallucis longus.

Cutaneous supply of foot:

Common peroneal nerve injury:

Causes
  • Most common: Neck of fibula fracture (Option D)
  • Posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Fracture lateral tibial condyle

Clinical features
  • Foot drop (inability to evert)
  • High stepping gait

Treatment
  • Conservative (mainstay): Foot drop splint

  • Surgical (tendon transfer) - only done >12 months of no recovery:
    • Barr’s technique
    • Ober’s technique

questions.text: A 45-year-old male has a history of recurrent peptic ulcers and severe abdominal pain. Despite the use of proton pump inhibitors, his symptoms persist. Endoscopic examination reveals small nodules in the medial wall of the duodenum. His family history is significant for multiple endocrine neoplasia type I. Which of the following statements is most likely true regarding his condition?

choices.text: The tumors are most commonly found in the tail of the pancreas.
The condition is curable with surgical removal of the primary tumor.
The patient's gastrinoma is likely located within the gastrinoma triangle.
The use of proton pump inhibitors has made diagnosis of this condition easier

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The patient's gastrinoma is likely located within the gastrinoma triangle.

 

Explanation:

 

Recurrent peptic ulcers, nodules in the duodenal wall, and MEN 1 family history point to a diagnosis of Zollinger- Ellison syndrome, in which gastrinomas are predominant. Gastrinomas are often located within the gastrinoma triangle, defined by cystic duct/common bile duct, duodenum, and pancreas.

 

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome:

 

Aspect

Details

Tumor Location

Duodenal loop (Option A), Pancreas (head)

Causes

Persistent peptic ulceration

Historical Recognition

Severe peptic ulcers unresponsive to surgery pre-PPI era. The use of proton pump inhibitors (Option D) has made the condition controllable but harder to recognize.

Types

Sporadic, MEN type I (with parathyroid adenoma)

Common Locations

Gastrinoma Triangle (Option C) (cystic duct/common bile duct, duodenum, pancreas)

90% located in Gastrinoma triangle/ Passaro's triangle 

Detection

Small nodules in duodenal wall, endoscopic and surgical inspection needed

Course

Indolent for some malignant gastrinomas

Treatment

Palliative liver resection, liver transplantation, surgical removal for palliation in MEN type I as they are incurable. (Option B)

Prognosis

Worse for tumors outside gastrinoma triangle

questions.text: Which of the following components is not evaluated in the Bloom-Richardson grading system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tumour size

 

Explanation:

The Bloom-Richardson grading system, also known as the Nottingham grading system, assigns points to three histological features of breast cancer.

Features

Score

Tubule Formation:

Percentage of the tumor that forms normal duct structures
  • Score 1: >75% of tumor area forms tubules
  • Score 2: 10-75% of tumor area forms tubules
  • Score 3: <10% of tumor area forms tubules

Nuclear Pleomorphism:

Variation in size and shape of the tumor cell nuclei
  • Score 1: Small, uniform nuclei
  • Score 2: Moderate increase in size and variability
  • Score 3: Marked variation in size and shape, large and bizarre nuclei

Mitotic Count:

Number of mitoses per 10 high-power fields
  • Score 1: 0-9 mitoses per 10 high-power fields
  • Score 2: 10-19 mitoses per 10 high-power fields
  • Score 3: 20 or more mitoses per 10 high-power fields

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain and fever. According to the Tokyo Guidelines, which combination of findings would confirm a diagnosis of acute cholecystitis?

choices.text: RUQ tenderness, elevated C-reactive protein, gallbladder wall thickening on USG.
Murphy's sign, fever, normal gallbladder wall on USG.
Palpable RUQ mass, normal white blood cell count, pericholecystic fluid on USG.
RUQ pain, elevated C-reactive protein, no imaging finding

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) RUQ tenderness, elevated C-reactive protein, gallbladder wall thickening on USG.

Explanation:

Above case meets all criteria (local sign, systemic sign, and characteristic imaging findings) for diagnosing acute cholecystitis.

Tokyo Guidelines for Acute Cholecystitis (2013/2018)

A) Local Signs of Inflammation:
  • Murphy's sign
  • Right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain/ tenderness, or a palpable mass.

B) Systemic Signs of Inflammation:
  • Fever
  • Elevated CRP
  • Elevated WBC

C) Imaging Findings:
  • Gallbladder wall thickening (>3 mm)
  • Pericholecystic fluid,
  • Ultrasonographic Murphy's sign.

Suspected acute cholecystitis is diagnosed when one local sign and one systemic sign of inflammation are present.

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be seen in patients of achalasia cardia

choices.text: Lack of gas bubble in stomach
Standing or sitting up straight during meal times

questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Oesophageal manometry shows hyper- peristalsis

  • Manometry shows lack of peristalsis in lower one third. Due to increase tone of LES gas bubble may be absent. The proximal dilated oesophagus is called sigmoid oesophagus. Due to food getting stuck patient will change his position in an effort to get food mobilize down.

questions.text: 68-year-old hypertensive man presents with recurrent episodes of dizziness and syncope while walking. On examination, pulse 38/min and regular, and BP is 100/70 mmHg. His ECG shows intermittent P waves not followed by QRS. QRS complexes are wide, regular P-P interval, regular R-R interval and lack of consistent relationship with P wave and QRS complexes. Which of the following is best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Dual chamber pacing

  • Patient is having third degree heart block. Ventricular escape rhythm is generated from bundle of his. Key word is lack of consistent relationship between P waves and qRS complexes. Hence answer is Dual chamber pacing to enable coordination between SA node and AV node. Option D is used for dilated cardiomyopathy. Option A and B is used in Bradycardia with hypotension.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with an increasing size of a mole. A lesion with irregular borders and variegated colours is noted, histopathologically confirmed as atypical melanocytes invading the dermis. Which nevus type is most commonly associated with malignant transformation to melanoma?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C
Explanation:
Large congenital melanocytic nevus, especially those over 20cm (giant congenital melanocytic nevus), have a much higher risk of developing melanoma over the individual's lifetime, particularly if they are larger or have a nodular component.

Option A: Dermal nevus are typically benign and are less likely to transform into melanoma compared to congenital melanocytic nevi.

Option B: Compound nevus have Nevus cells in both dermis and epidermis. They have a slight risk of malignant transformation but are not as high as in large congenital melanocytic nevus.
 

Option D: Becker's nevus is a benign cutaneous hamartoma that is usually not associated with malignant transformation.

 

 

 

Types of Nevi:

questions.text: A 62-year-old female patient, receiving treatment with daunorubicin for breast cancer, presents with symptoms of fatigue, shortness of breath, and chest pain. An echocardiogram shows decreased left ventricular ejection fraction. Which of the following agents should be administered to prevent further cardiac damage?
questions.solution:
• The mechanism of cardiotoxicity by Daunorubicin is believed to be partly due to cardiac lipid peroxidation, which is promoted by Fe2+ causing Cardiomyopathy.
  • Dexrazoxane is a cardioprotective, iron-chelating agent. It is used to prevent cardiotoxicity caused by the Anthracyclines like Daunorubicin and Doxorubicin.
  • Dexrazoxane may also prevent anthracycline-derived DNA damage by interacting with topoisomerase II in cardiac cells.

Penicillamine (Option A) is used for copper chelation and certain conditions like rheumatoid arthritis

Dimercaprol (Option D) is used for arsenic and other heavy metal poisonings

EDTA (Option C) is primarily used for lead poisoning.

None of these agents provide the specific cardioprotective effects that dexrazoxane does against anthracycline-induced damage.

questions.text:
Analyze the following statements regarding the structural model of mind and choose the correct set of true statements from these

1) Ego lies in all three- conscious, preconscious & unconscious parts of the mind

2) Instinctual drives are a part of Id.

3) The superego is mostly present in the conscious part of the mind.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 1,2

Explanation:

Structural model of mind (by Sigmund Freud):

Id:
  • Instinctive drives
  • Based on the pleasure principle (immediate gratification)
  • Operates under primary processes
  • Lies in the unconscious mind

Ego:
  • The executive organ of the mind
  • Maintains balance between Id and Superego
  • Works on the reality principle
  • Lies in all three - conscious, preconscious and unconscious parts of the mind

Superego:
  • Moral compass insisting on socially acceptable behavior
  • Develops after 5 years (after resolution of oedipal complex)
  • Predominantly present in the unconscious part of the mind

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of mitral valve replacement (on warfarin) and trigeminal neuralgia (on carbamazepine) has been prescribed clarithromycin for a chest infection. Her regular medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin. Her INR is 1.3 (target > 3 for mechanical heart valve). Which drug most likely interacted with warfarin to give this INR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Carbamazepine

Explanation:

  • Carbamazepine is a strong enzyme inducer, particularly of CYP2C9 and CYP3A4, which are responsible for metabolizing warfarin.
     
  • Enzyme induction leads to increased metabolism of warfarin, resulting in reduced plasma levels and a lower INR (as seen in this case: INR 1.3).
     
  • This is dangerous in patients with mechanical heart valves who require INR > 3 to prevent thromboembolic complications.
     

Mechanism table:

Drug

Effect on Warfarin

Mechanism

Carbamazepine

↓ INR (↓ warfarin effect)

CYP inducer → ↑ warfarin metabolism

Clarithromycin

↑ INR (↑ warfarin effect)

CYP inhibitor → ↓ warfarin metabolism

Amlodipine

No significant effect

No major CYP interaction

Atorvastatin

Mild unpredictable changes

Competes with warfarin at CYP enzymes

Pharmacokinetics of Warfarin:

Parameter

Details

Absorption

Oral

Kinetics

Zero-order kinetics at high doses

Excretion

Excreted in bile, safe in renal failure

Protein Binding

99% bound to albumin

Dialysis Removal

Not dialyzable due to high protein binding

Important Drug Interactions with Warfarin:

Enzyme Inhibitors (↑ INR) – Mnemonic: SICKFACES.COM

Drug

Sodium Valproate

Isoniazid

Cimetidine

Ketoconazole

Fluconazole

Alcohol (binge)

Chloramphenicol

Erythromycin

Sulfonamides

Ciprofloxacin

Omeprazole

Metronidazole

Enzyme Inducers (↓ INR) – Mnemonic: CRAP GPS

Drug

Carbamazepine

Rifampin

Alcohol (chronic)

Phenytoin

Griseofulvin

Phenobarbital

Sulphonylureas

 

Amlodipine (Option A): Incorrect. No major effect on INR or warfarin metabolism.
 

Atorvastatin (Option B): Incorrect. May have minor interactions but not a strong inducer/inhibitor.
 

Clarithromycin (Option C): Incorrect. Would increase INR, not decrease it.

questions.text: A 30 y/o male with a history of rapid weight loss presents with severe postprandial abdominal pain and vomiting. The physician suspects Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA) syndrome. Which imaging technique is most suitable for visualizing the compression of the duodenum by the SMA and accurately measuring the aortomesenteric angle?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Computed Tomography (CT) Scan

 

Explanation:

  • A CT scan is the preferred diagnostic tool for SMA syndrome.
  • A computed tomography (CT) offers detailed visualization of the duodenum, SMA, and aorta.
  • It enables precise measurement of the aortomesenteric angle and distance, which are critical for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Additionally, it can detect associated complications, such as acute pancreatitis or gastric necrosis, making it the most comprehensive method.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain and shortness of breath. His blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg, heart rate is 110 bpm, and has cold, clammy skin and elevated JVP. ECG shows ST-segment elevations in lead II, III and aVF. The patient is also oliguric. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms and signs?
questions.solution:
ST segment elevation in leads II, III and aVF corresponds to inferior wall Myocardial infarction, which leads to cardiogenic shock as in this scenario.

 

Shocks:

 

Types of shock

Pathophysiology

Causes

Cardiac output

Cardiogenic

(Option A)

Inadequate pumping of the heart due to myocardial function.
  • Acute myocardial infarction
  • Heart failure
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  

↓

Hypovolemic

Decreased amount of fluid in the vascular system
  • Acute hemorrhage
  • Burn
  • Metabolic: adrenal insufficiency (Option C ruled out), diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Severe diarrhea or vomiting.

 

↓

Distributive

Sudden increase in the vascular compartment capacity due to acute marked vasodilation
  • Neurogenic shock
  • Anaphylactic shock
  • Septic shock (Option B ruled out)

 

↓

Obstructive

Obstruction to the ejection of blood from the ventricle
  • Cardiac tamponade (Option D ruled out)
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Cardiac tumor
  • Tension pneumothorax

 

↓

questions.text:
Which of the following statements correctly matches with the medications?


	
		
			
			1. Metoprolol
			
			
			A. Contraindicated with Non-DHP calcium channel blockers.
			
		
		
			
			2. Ivabradine
			
			
			B. Increase risk of oral ulcers.
			
		
		
			
			3. Trimetazidine
			
			
			C. Abrupt discontinuation can exacerbate angina.
			
		
		
			
			4. Enoxaparin
			
			
			D. Increase risk of Parkinson’s disease.
			
		
		
			
			5. Nicorandil
			
			
			E. Contraindicated in renal insufficiency.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1:C, 2: A, 3:D, 4:E, 5: B

Explanation:

Medication

Adverse effects

1. Beta-blockers (e.g metorprolol)
  • Abrupt discontinuation can exacerbate angina.
  • Bradycardia, AV block
  • Bronchospasm
  • Peripheral vasoconstriction
  • Worsening of acute heart failure.
  • Worsening of psoriasis.

2. Ivabradine
  • Contraindicated with diltiazem or verapamil.
  • Bradycardia, heart block
  • QT prolongation, atrial fibrillation
  • Enhanced lightness in restricted areas of the visual field.

3. Trimetazidine
  • Increase in the incidence of Parkinson’s disease.
  • Agranulocytosis

4. Low-molecular-weight heparin (e.g., enoxaparin, dalteparin)
  • Accumulation in renal insufficiency.
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.
  • Raised liver enzymes.

5. Nicorandil
  • Hypotension
  • Headache
  • Buccal and GI ulcers
  • Contraindicated with PDE5 inhibitor.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with symptoms of peptic ulcer disease and is diagnosed with H. pylori infection. He is allergic to penicillin. As part of his initial treatment, you decide to start him on triple therapy for H. pylori eradication. Which of the following drugs are used in Triple therapy in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has been diagnosed with H.Pylori and needs to be started on triple therapy. He is also allergic to penicillin so Amoxicillin is avoided, hence he has to be started on PPI + Clarithromycin + Metronidazole for 14 days.

Antibiotics used against H. Pylori:

Generation

Clarithromycin

Amoxicillin

Metronidazole

1st generation

Tetracycline

Levofloxacine

2nd generation

Rifabutin

Furazolidone

3rd generation

 

Guidelines for treatment of H.Pylori:

  1. ≥2 combinations of antibiotics
  2. Give PPI> H2 blocker
  3. Give for >10-14 days

 

Anti-H.pylori regimens:

Drugs used

No. of days:

Triple therapy: PCA

(first line therapy used)

PPI + Clarithromycin + Amoxicillin (Option B)

BD for 14 days

Triple therapy: PCM

(in case of penicillin allergy or resistance) 

PPI + Clarithromycin + Metronidazole

BD for 14 days

Levofloxacin-based triple therapy: 

PPI + Levofloxacin + Clarithromycin (PAL) (Option C)

BD for 14 days

 

PPI + Tetracycline + Amoxicillin for 14 days (Option D) are not used in combination, instead PPI + Amoxicillin followed by PPI + Metronidazole + Levofloxacine for 14 days (PA ➞ PML) is used as a new concomitant therapy.

questions.text: Patient with blunt trauma to chest is brought to hospital. On examination he is using accessory muscles of respiration and trachea appears deviated to contralateral side. Breath sounds appear distant with dullness to percussion. Which of the following should be done in this patient?

choices.text: Urgent wide bore needle in 5th ICS in mid axillary line
Urgent wide bore needle in 2nd ICS in mid clavicular line
Do blood grouping and cross matching and start massive transfusion protocol

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: ​​​​​​​Urgent CXR

  • Patient is having features of haemothorax. Option B is done for tension pneumothorax.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the trauma unit after being assaulted. He presents with severe pain, swelling, and deformity in the lower jaw. Imaging confirms a "bucket handle" fracture of the mandible. What is the most likely nerve to be injured in this type of fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Inferior alveolar nerve

 

Explanation:

Inferior alveolar nerve runs through the mandibular canal and is at risk of injury in fractures of the mandible, especially those involving the body of the mandible, like butterfly fractures.

Butterfly Fractures of the Mandible:

  • Also Known As: "Bucket handle" fractures.
  • Type: Bilateral body fractures of the mandible.
  • Common Causes: High-energy impacts (e.g., motor vehicle accidents, assaults).
  • Main Complication: Airway obstruction.

Characteristics and Mechanism:

  • Appearance: Fracture creates a "butterfly" pattern.
  • Impact: Significant compromise of mandible’s structural integrity.
  • Injury Mechanism: Involves high-force trauma, potentially leading to additional injuries in surrounding tissues.

 

Management Strategies:

Method

Indication

Details

Closed Reduction

Non-displaced or minimally displaced fractures

Uses intermaxillary fixation (MMF) for stabilization.

Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF)

Displaced fractures

Surgical realignment and stabilization using plates/screws.

 

Complications:

  • Malocclusion: Misalignment of teeth.
  • Non-union: Failure of the fracture to heal properly.
  • Nerve Injury: Particularly to the inferior alveolar nerve, causing altered sensation in the lower lip. 

Lingual nerve (Option A): This nerve is less likely to be injured in a mandibular body fracture as it is located more medially and higher up in the jaw.

Hypoglossal nerve (Option C): This nerve is involved in tongue movement and is not typically affected by mandible fractures.

Facial nerve (Option D): The facial nerve controls facial muscles and is usually affected by fractures of the zygomatic arch or parotid area, not the mandible.

questions.text: A 25-year-old athlete presents with exercise intolerance and muscle fatigue, particularly during high-intensity training. Genetic testing reveals a deficiency in the enzyme that facilitates the transfer of electrons from cytosolic NADH to mitochondrial FADH2 in skeletal muscle. Which shuttle system is likely impaired in this athlete?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Glycerol phosphate shuttle

The glycerol phosphate shuttle, present in white muscle fibers and neurons, specifically transfers electrons from cytosolic NADH to mitochondrial FADH2

Electron Transport Chain (ETC):

  • Location: Inner mitochondrial membrane. The ADP-ATP translocase in the inner mitochondrial membrane exports ATP to the cytosol and imports ADP into the mitochondria.. Atractyloside inhibits this transport process.
  • Function:
    • It plays a crucial role in oxidative phosphorylation.
    • Oxidation, which involves the loss of electrons, is central to this process and drives ATP synthesis
  • Shuttles:
    • NADH Shuttles: Glycolysis, which occurs in the cytoplasm, generates 2 NADH molecules per glucose molecule.
    • NADH cannot directly cross the mitochondrial membrane; it requires shuttles for transport.
    • There are two main shuttle systems: the malate-aspartate shuttle (Image 1) and the glycerol phosphate shuttle (Image 2), which facilitate NADH transport across the mitochondrial membrane

 

 

 

Property

Malate Shuttle (Option A ruled out)

Glycerol Phosphate Shuttle

Location

 Present in most cells except white muscle fibers and neurons.

White muscle fibers and neurons

Energy

 "No net ATP loss" → Consumes 2 ATP per glucose molecule.

Loss of 2 ATPs per glucose molecule

Electron Carrier

 Electron Carrier: Transfers electrons to mitochondrial NADH, maintaining cytosolic NAD+/NADH balance.

Transfers electrons to mitochondrial FADH2

Enzymes

 Cytoplasmic and mitochondrial glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase.

Cytoplasmic & mitochondrial glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase

Citrate shuttle (Option C) transports acetyl-CoA from the mitochondria to the cytosol for fatty acid synthesis, not for transferring electrons from NADH to FADH2.

The aspartate shuttle (Option D), also known as the malate-aspartate shuttle, is involved in transferring electrons from cytosolic NADH to mitochondrial NADH.

questions.solution:
Given is a flow-volume loop of a fixed upper airway obstruction.

 

Fixed upper airway obstruction:

  • Both inspiration and expiration affected.

    • Foreign body
