The flow-volume loops in variable extrathoracic, variable intrathoracic, and fixed upper airway obstruction:

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with excessive worry, restlessness, difficulty concentrating, muscle tension, and disturbed sleep for several months. He also experiences occasional panic attacks with palpitations, sweating, and a sense of impending doom. With a family history of anxiety disorders, he is diagnosed with Generalised anxiety disorder (GAD). Which of the following medications is most appropriate for initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) are first-line drugs in the treatment of Generalised anxiety disorder.

Mechanism of action:

SSRIs block serotonin reuptake in the brain, increasing its concentration in the synaptic cleft. This enhances serotonin signalling, which is thought to alleviate symptoms of depression and anxiety.

Uses:

  • Major depressive disorder- drug of choice
  • Generalised anxiety disorder
  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • Premenstrual dysphoric disorder
  • Post-traumatic stress disorder
  • Bulimia nervosa
  • Bipolar depression (using it in bipolar affective disorder can sometimes trigger mania episodes)

Side effects:

  • Nausea, vomiting (Most common)
  • Diarrhea
  • Insomnia
  • Anxiety during the initial weeks of treatment
  • Sexual dysfunction (Reduced libido, Anorgasmia, Ejaculatory delay) - therefore can be used for the treatment of premature ejaculation
  • Increased risk of suicide soon after starting drug
  • Bleeding (thrombocytopenia)
  • Loss of weight

 

Benzodiazepines and Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (Option B and C) are also used to treat anxiety but are not first-line drugs.

Benzodiazepines such as lorazepam and clonazepam are used in the acute phase of anxiety.

 

Tricyclic antidepressants (Option D) are used off-label for treating anxiety and are not preferred.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and high myopia undergoes cataract surgery. During the procedure, she suddenly experiences severe ocular pain and a rapid rise in intraocular pressure. Fundoscopic examination reveals a dark red elevation in the choroidal region. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management step?

choices.text: Increase the infusion pressure in the anterior chamber
Perform immediate vitrectomy to drain the hemorrhage
Close the surgical wound and monitor intraocular pressure

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Close the surgical wound and monitor intraocular pressure

 

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario suggests suprachoroidal hemorrhage. The immediate steps involve closing the wound to prevent further prolapse of intraocular contents and monitoring intraocular pressure.

 

Suprachoroidal hemorrhage:

  • A suprachoroidal haemorrhage involves a bleed into the suprachoroidal space from a ruptured short posterior ciliary artery.
  • If suciently severe, it may result in extrusion of intraocular contents (expulsive haemorrhage).
  • It is a dreaded complication, but extremely rare (0.04%) with phacoemulsication.
  • Signs:
    • Progressive shallowing of the AC, increased IOP, and iris prolapse.
    • Vitreous extrusion, loss or partial obscuration of the red reflex and the appearance of a dark mound behind the pupil.
    • In severe cases, posterior segment contents may be extruded into the AC and through the incision.
  • Management:

Immediate

Subsequate
  • Closure of the incision with a suture to retain residual viscoelastic in the eye.
  • Diagnosis should be confirmed at the slit-lamp as soon as possible.
  • Acetazolamide to lower intraocular pressure.
  • Intensive topical and systemic steroids to reduce inflammation, with standard postoperative antibiotic treatment and IOP management.
  • Drainage, if subsequent hemorrhage fails to resolve (after 7-14 days, by which liquefaction of blood clot has taken place).
  • Pars plana vitrectomy may be considered when the retina appears adherent or detached.


Intraoperative posterior sclerostomy (Option A) should not be performed during the management of suprachoroidal hemorrhage because it increases the risk of complications such as infection and retinal detachment. The immediate focus should be on stabilizing the eye by controlling intraocular pressure and closing the incision. Once stabilized, further surgical interventions can be evaluated in a safer environment.

 

Increase the infusion pressure in the anterior chamber (Option B): Increasing infusion pressure may worsen the bleeding.

 

Perform immediate vitrectomy to drain the hemorrhage (Option C): Immediate vitrectomy is generally avoided initially as it could exacerbate the hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who has lived a normal life and works as an accountant begins to believe that his wife and children have been replaced by impostors. He is convinced that those he interacts with daily are not his real family, leading to significant anxiety and fear. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario describes Capgras Syndrome, a type of delusional misidentification where the individual irrationally believes that a familiar person, usually a close family member or spouse, has been replaced by an identical imposter.

 

Intermetamorphosis (Option A) is characterised by delusions that individuals have swapped identities (psychological and physical transformation) while keeping the same appearance.

 

Fregoli syndrome (Option C) is a delusional misidentification where the individual falsely believes that different people they encounter are actually the same person in disguise.

Nihilistic syndrome (Option D) is a depressive delusion in which the patient denies the existence of their body, their mind, their loved ones and the world around them.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe pain in his left upper arm and wrist drop after a fall while playing football. Examination reveals weakness in wrist extension and numbness over the dorsum of his hand. Radiographs show a humeral fracture. Which part of the humerus is most likely involved in this fracture?

choices.text: Junction of the middle and distal third
Junction of the proximal and middle third

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Junction of the middle and distal third

 

Explanation:

  • This fracture, known as a Holstein-Lewis fracture, typically occurs at the junction of the middle and distal third of the humeral shaft and is associated with radial nerve injury, leading to wrist drop and sensory loss over the dorsum of the hand.
  • Mechanism of injury: Fall on outstretched hand or direct trauma to the arm.

Management:

  • Conservative: There is no role for conservative management in Holstein-lewis fracture
  • The treatment of choice is emergency decompression
  • For stable fractures, the initial management may include:
    • U-slab or Hanging cast
    • Chest arm bandage to immobilise the arm
  • Surgical Intervention: In cases of displaced fractures or complicated cases:
    • Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF)
    • Intramedullary nailing
    • Compression plating and screws
    • External fixation
  • Dynamic cock-up splint is used primarily to support the wrist and hand while allowing for some movement. It is designed to maintain the wrist in a neutral position (slightly extended) while permitting the fingers to flex and extend.
  • Nerve damage is usually temporary, but in case of open fractures exploration might be needed.

Supracondylar region (Option A): Fractures in the supracondylar region typically affect the median nerve, leading to symptoms such as weakness in wrist flexion and the "hand of benediction" sign. These fractures are more common in children and are less likely to cause wrist drop.

 

Junction of the proximal and middle third (Option C) & Surgical neck of the humerus (Option D): Fractures at these locations primarily affect the axillary nerve. This results in weakness of the deltoid muscle, causing difficulty in arm abduction and sensory loss over the lateral shoulder.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with painless swelling in the umbilical region. On physical examination, the swelling is found to be soft, smooth, and freely mobile in a direction perpendicular to the line of the mesentery. Imaging studies confirm the presence of a mesenteric cyst. Which of the following is not a component of Tillaux's triad?

choices.text: Soft, smooth swelling in the umbilical region
Freely mobile in a direction perpendicular to mesentery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Presence of tenderness

Explanation:

  • Presence of tenderness is not a part of Tillaux’s triad.

Mesenteric cyst:

  • It presents as a painless, abdominal swelling in the umbilical region.
  • Commonly seen in the 2nd decade of life.
  • There is a band of resonance in front of the cyst.

Tillaux's triad for mesenteric cysts includes:

  • A soft, smooth swelling in the umbilical region. (Option A ruled out)
  • Freely mobile mass in a direction perpendicular to line of the mesentery (Tillaux Sign) (Option B ruled out)
  • A zone of resonance all around. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is included in Gustafson's method but excluded from Dalitz's method of age estimation from teeth?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Root resorption

Explanation:

Dalitz's method for age estimation from teeth simplified Gustafson's system and excluded two of the six criteria: root resorption and cementum apposition.

 

Gustafson's Method:

Developed by Gosta Gustafson, this method estimates age by evaluating six specific regressive changes in teeth:

  1. Attrition (A): Wear of the occlusal surface due to chewing, starting with enamel and progressing to dentin and pulp.
  2. Periodontosis (P): Retraction of the gums, exposing the root and neck of the tooth, leading to loosening.
  3. Secondary Dentin (S): Gradual deposition in the pulp cavity, reducing its size and potentially obliterating it.
  4. Cementum Apposition (C): Thickening of cementum around the root as the tooth shifts in position, with continuous deposition forming incremental lines.
  5. Root Resorption (R): Degradation of cementum and dentin at the root apex, progressing upwards.
  6. Root Transparency: Increased transparency in the root due to rarefaction of dentin, beginning from the apex and moving upward in lower teeth, and downward in upper teeth. This is considered the most reliable of all criteria.

 

Each change is scored from 0 to 3, and the total score (Y) is used in the formula for age estimation.

  • 0–No change
  • 1–Beginning of change
  • 2–Obvious change
  • 3–Maximum change

 

A + P + S + C + R + T = total score (Y)

 

An increase in age shows a linear increase in the total score. The age is estimated using the following formula:

 

Age = 11.43 + 4.56 × Y (total score)

 

  • The method is most accurate for individuals between 25–60 years old.
  • It requires extracting and microscopically examining a longitudinal section of the tooth, limiting its use to deceased individuals or skeletal remains.

 

Dalitz's Method:

Dalitz refined Gustafson’s method to improve accuracy by discarding less reliable factors like root resorption and secondary cementum apposition. He focused on scoring the following changes in the 12 anterior teeth on a 5-point scoring system from 0 to 4.

  1. Attrition (A)
  2. Periodontitis (P)
  3. Secondary Dentin Deposition (S)
  4. Root Transparency (T)

 

While more accurate, the Dalitz method's main drawback is its limitation to anterior teeth, excluding bicuspid (premolars) and molars from analysis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with swelling and limited mobility in her right shoulder, having experienced a sudden onset three weeks ago. Upon inspection, the right shoulder is swollen, non-tender, and erythematous. She reports a history of unnoticed burns on her hands and neck from cooking and using a hairdryer. An MRI of the cervical spine is given below. An indium WBC scan was performed, and the result was negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Charcot arthropathy

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is a case of Charcot’s arthropathy of the shoulder joint due to syringomyelia because:
    • A history of unnoticed burns suggests a significant loss of sensory function, likely due to the syrinx in her cervical spine (as shown in the MRI).

    • Acute onset of non-tender swelling in the shoulder indicates acute arthropathy.
    • The negative indium WBC scan indicates the absence of acute infection, which would be expected in cases of osteomyelitis or septic arthritis.

Charcot Joints (Neuropathic joint): Progressive, degenerative & destructive joint disorder due to abnormal pain sensation & proprioception

 

Joints involved:

  • Foot and ankle
  • Shoulder
  • Elbow
  • Knee
  • Hand

 

Most Common Joint Involved: Foot

  • 60%: Tarsometatarsal joint
  • 30%: Metatarsophalangeal joint
  • 10%: Ankle joint


 

Etiology:

Cause

Mechanism

Common Joint Involved

Diabetes mellitus (Most common cause)

Peripheral neuropathy leads to altered pain sensation and proprioception

Foot

 

Syphilis (Tabes dorsalis)

Neurological deficits affecting joint function

Knee

Syringomyelia

Dilatation of the spinal cord; may lead to syringobulbia (if it extends to the Brainstem)

Shoulder

Leprosy

Neuropathy leading to loss of sensation

Hand and Foot

Meningomyelocele

Neurological deficits impacting joint function

Variable, but often lower limbs




 

Osteoarthritis (Option A): typically presents as a chronic condition and does not explain the association with the syrinx on MRI.

 

Osteomyelitis (Option C): would likely show positive findings on an indium WBC scan and typically presents with systemic signs of infection, which are absent in this case.

 

DVT (Option D): could cause a tender swelling and would not explain the neurological symptoms associated with the syrinx.

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the association between a new dietary supplement and the development of a rare type of cancer. The study includes 100 patients with the cancer and 100 healthy individuals. All of the following biases can occur in this type of study except?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Pygmalion Bias
 

Explanation:

Pygmalion Bias occurs when the researcher's expectations influence participant performance. This bias is irrelevant to case-control studies, which are retrospective and observational and more susceptible to biases like recall, selection, and ascertainment bias.

 

Pygmalion Bias/ Rosenthal Effect:

  • A phenomenon where higher researcher expectations increase participant performance or outcomes.
  • Motivation is proportional to performance and gives an exaggerated response.
  • Seen in experimental or educational settings.
  • For example, increased motivation by teachers increases student performance.

 

Recall Bias (Option A) occurs when participants do not accurately remember past events or experiences.

  • It is common in case-control studies where cases might remember exposure more clearly than controls.

 

Selection Bias (Option B)

  • Happens when there is a systematic difference in characteristics between those selected for study and those not.
  • It is possible that the cases and controls are not representative of the general population.

 

Surveillance Bias or Ascertainment bias (Option C)

  • Occurs when the disease or outcome is more likely to be identified in the exposed group because they are more closely monitored.
  • This could occur if cases are more frequently monitored for dietary habits than controls.

questions.text:
Given the following enzyme kinetics parameters:


	Maximum velocity (Vmax): 100 µmol/min
	Michaelis constant (Km): 10 µM
	Initial velocity (Vo): 50 µmol/min


What is the substrate concentration [S] of the given enzyme?
questions.solution:
The substrate concentration [S] represents the amount of substrate available for the enzyme to act upon in a given reaction. It is typically measured in units of concentration, such as micromoles per liter (µM) or millimoles per liter (mM).

 

To find the substrate concentration [S], you can use the Michaelis-Menten equation:

 

Vo = Vmax[S]/Km + [S]

 

Given:

(Vmax): 100 µmol/min

(Km): 10 µM

(Vo): 50 µmol/min

 

Substitute the given values into the equation:

 

50 = 100[S]/10+ [S]

 

50 (10 + [S]) = 100 [S]

 

Simplify and solve for [S]:

 

500 + 50[S] = 100[S]

 

500 = 50[S]

 

[S] = 10 µM

 

Therefore, the substrate concentration [S] is 10 µM.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of vertigo but has no reported hearing loss, tinnitus, or aural fullness. Diagnostic tests reveal no abnormalities in the cochlea or hearing function. What is the most likely diagnosis among the variants of Meniere’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vestibular Hydrops

Explanation:
The given scenario is most likely Vestibular Hydrops, as it involves vertigo without cochlear symptoms.

 

Variants of Meniere’s disease

Variant

Description

Pathophysiology

Cochlear Hydrops

Symptoms primarily involve the cochlea: fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and fullness, but no vertigo.

Increased fluid pressure confined to the cochlea, often due to a blockage at the ductus reuniens.

Vestibular Hydrops

Presents with episodic vertigo while cochlear function remains normal (no hearing loss, tinnitus, or fullness).

Fluid pressure affects the vestibular structures, particularly the saccule and utricle, sparing cochlear function.

Tumarkin’s Otolithic Crisis

Sudden"drop attacks" without loss of consciousness and no vertigo or hearing loss

Deformation of otolith membrane of the utricle or saccule due to change in endolymphatic pressure

Lermoyez Syndrome

Symptoms of Meniere’s are seen in reverse order—progressive hearing loss followed by vertigo.

questions.text: A 27-y/o employee from the forest department presents with high fever, malaise, and frontal headaches, followed by bleeding from the nasal cavity, throat, gums and hematemesis. Recently, he worked in a forest area in Karnataka that has a significant population of monkeys. What is the vector responsible for the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hard ticks

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is Monkey fever/Kyasanur forest disease, which is caused by Hard ticks. Endemic in five districts of Karnataka: Shimoga, North Kannada, South Kannada, Chikkamagaluru, and Udupi.

 

Monkey fever/Kyasanur forest disease:

General features:

  • Virus Characteristics: Enveloped virus belonging to the family Flaviviridae; contains single-stranded RNA (ssRNA).
  • Vector: Hard ticks (Haemaphysalis spinigera)
  • Hosts: Monkeys, rodents, and squirrels are common hosts; monkeys act as amplifier hosts where the virus multiplies exponentially.
  • Seasonality: KFD cases peak during dry months (November to June), coinciding with increased human activity in forests.

Fig: The life cycle of Kyasanur forest disease


Clinical features:

  • Incubation Period: 3-8 days.
  • First Stage (Hemorrhagic Fever):
    • Acute high fever with malaise and frontal headaches.
    • Hemorrhagic symptoms: bleeding from the nasal cavity, throat, gums, and gastrointestinal tract.
  • Second Stage: Meningoencephalitis may occur 7–21 days after the first stage.

 

Lab diagnosis:

  • Diagnosis Methods:
    • Virus isolation from blood.
    • IgM antibody detection by ELISA.
    • RT-PCR.

 

Vaccination:

  • Vaccine Type: Killed KFD vaccine (formalin-inactivated chick embryo) developed at Haffkine Institute, Mumbai.
  • Vaccination Schedule:
    • Initial two doses at 2-month intervals.
    • Booster doses at 6–9 months, then every 5 years.
  • Target Area: Recommended for endemic areas of Karnataka.

 

Vector

Diseases transmitted

Sandfly (Option A ruled out)

Kala-azar

Oriental sore

Sandfly fever (Papatasi fever)

Flea (Option C ruled out)

Hymenolepis diminuta

Hymenolepis nana

Bubonic plague

Endemic typhus

Louse (Option D ruled out)

Epidemic relapsing fever

Epidemic typhus

Trench fever

Hard tick

Babesiosis

Kyasanur Forest disease virus (Option B)

Colorado tick fever virus

Russian spring-summer encephalitis virus

Omsk hemorrhagic fever virus

Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever virus

Tularemia

Lyme disease

Rocky Mountain spotted fever

Indian tick typhus

Ehrlichiosis

Soft tick

Endemic relapsing fever

Reduvid bug

Chagas’ disease

questions.text: Which cerebellar peduncle is primarily composed of only afferent fibres?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Middle cerebellar peduncle

 

Explanation:

  • The middle cerebellar peduncle is composed exclusively of afferent fibres originating from the contralateral pontine nuclei.
  • It plays a crucial role in relaying information from various areas of the cerebral cortex to the cerebellum, facilitating the coordination of movement and motor planning.

 

Cerebellar Peduncles
 

Afferent

Efferent

Superior cerebellar peduncle

Ventral Spinocerebellar Tract

All efferent fibres from dentate, emboliform, fastigial and globose nuclei

(Option C ruled out)

Middle cerebellar peduncle

Pontocerebellar Mossy Fibre Pathway

No efferent fibres

(Option A)

Inferior cerebellar peduncle

  • Dorsal Spinocerebellar Tract
  • Olivocerebellar Tract
  • Reticulocerebellar Tract

Few efferents from the cerebellum to the medulla oblongata, mainly to vestibular nuclei and reticular formation.

(Option A ruled out)

All of the above (Option D):

  • Incorrect, as the only peduncle that consists solely of afferent fibres is the middle cerebellar peduncle.
  • The others include both afferent and efferent fibres.

questions.text: A 30 year old male presents with a painless erection following a penile trauma. Doppler ultrasound confirms the presence of blood flow and blood gas analysis shows arterial blood characteristics. What is the most likely type of priapism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Non-ischaemic priapism

 

Explanation

Non-ischaemic priapism is characterized by a painless erection, typically following trauma, with normal or arterial blood gas characteristics which aligns with the patient's condition.

 

Feature

Ischemic Priapism  (Option A)

Nonischemic Priapism

Alternative Names

Low-flow, Anoxic, Veno-occlusive.

High-flow, Arterial.

Commonality

More common

Less common

Onset

Sudden, often painful.

Gradual, less painful.

Etiology

Associated with sickle cell disease, medications (anticoagulants, antihypertensives, antidepressants, PDE5 inhibitors, intracavernous injections, alpha-blockers, methylphenidate, atomoxetine, cocaine), blood disorders (leukemia, thalassemia, multiple myeloma, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura).

Often due to trauma (Perineal, pelvic, or penile trauma) or congenital arterial malformations.

Blood Flow

Decreased or absent (leading to hypoxia and acidosis)

Increased (blood is well-oxygenated)

Cavernosal Blood Gas Analysis

Dark blood, pH <7.25, PO2 <30 mmHg, PCO2 >60 mmHg.

Bright red blood, normal pH, normal PO2 and PCO2.

Doppler Ultrasonography

Minimal or no blood flow in the corpora cavernosa

Normal to increased blood flow

Urgency

Medical emergency

Not an emergency, often resolves spontaneously.

Complications

Risk of tissue damage, fibrosis and long-term erectile dysfunction.

Rarely causes permanent damage.

Treatment
  • Intracavernosal sympathomimetic drugs (e.g., phenylephrine)
  • Aspiration and irrigation.
  • Surgical shunt or penile prosthesis if refractory.
  • Observation
  • Arteriography and embolization if intervention is desired.

Prognosis

Poor if untreated within 24-48 hours, leading to irreversible erectile dysfunction.

Good, often resolves without long-term sequelae.

 

Neurogenic priapism (Option C), associated with spinal cord injuries, typically does not present with trauma-related symptoms and does not fit the provided clinical scenario.

Recurrent priapism (Option D) refers to repeated episodes of priapism, often linked to conditions like sickle cell disease, but the patient's presentation aligns more with non-ischaemic priapism.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient with a history of chronic migraines and increased intracranial pressure due to a recent stroke is scheduled for a minor procedure requiring anesthesia. Which anesthetic agent should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ketamine
Explanation:

Ketamine causes increased cerebral blood flow, which can lead to elevated intracranial pressure. This is especially problematic in patients with conditions such as stroke, where ICP management is crucial to prevent further neurological damage.

Systemic effects, uses and C/I of Ketamine

System

Effects

CNS
  • It is associated with increased cerebral oxygen consumption, blood flow, and intracranial pressure.
  • It causes functional disorganization by selectively depressing neuronal activity in the cortex and thalamus while stimulating the limbic system, leading to disrupted pain perception and emotional processing.
  • Emergence reactions, including vivid dreams, hallucinations, and illusion, occurs due to depression of auditory and visual relay nuclei,
  • It provides analgesia, amnesia, and unconsciousness, making it a "complete" anesthetic.

CVS
  • Increases arterial blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output, particularly after rapid bolus injections.
  • Stimulates the sympathetic nervous system and inhibits norepinephrine reuptake, increasing pulmonary artery pressure and myocardial workload.
  • Direct myocardial depression can occur with sympathetic blockade or catecholamine depletion.

Respiratory
  • Racemic ketamine is a strong bronchodilator, useful in asthmatic patients.
  • Upper airway reflexes remain intact.
  • Excessive salivation can be managed with anticholinergics (e.g., glycopyrrolate).

Muscle
  • It increases muscle tone

Uses:

  • Induction & Maintenance: Effective for unstable cardiovascular patients (e.g., hypovolemia, trauma, sepsis).
  • Combines with propofol or midazolam to reduce side effects (tachycardia, hypertension) and stabilize hemodynamics.
  • Useful in cardiac conditions (congenital heart disease(Right to Left shunt), septic shock, restrictive pericarditis).
  • IV induction agent of choice in bronchial asthma
  • It has prothyroid property: IV induction agent of choice myxedema coma patients
  • Preventive Analgesia: Small doses (20-60 mg) reduce postoperative pain and opioid consumption.
  • Used for chronic pain (e.g., cancer pain, neuropathic pain, fibromyalgia)
  • Procedures & Emergency Use: Common in emergency departments and short painful procedures.

Contraindications:

  • Increased ICP (Head injury, neuro surgery) 
  • Epilepsy
  • Ischemic heart disease, vascular aneurysms
  • Open eye injuries, and
  • Schizophrenia.

Thiopentone (Option A): It is the IV induction agent of choice in increased ICP.

Midazolam (Option B): A benzodiazepine that provides sedation and amnesia without significantly affecting ICP.

Sevoflurane (Option D): An inhalational anesthetic that is typically well-tolerated and does not have a direct effect on increasing ICP, making it a safer option in this scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following is the diluent used for the Measles Rubella vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Distilled water/ Sterile Water

Explanation:

  • The diluent used for the Measles Rubella vaccine is Distilled water/ sterile water.
  • The diluent provided along with the vaccine by the manufacturer ONLY should be used.

Normal Saline (Option A)- is the diluent for the BCG Vaccine.

Phosphate Buffer Solution (Option B)- is the diluent used for Japanese encephalitis vaccine

Cold Physiological saline (Option D)- is the diluent used for Yellow fever Vaccine

Powdered vaccines & their diluents

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice. He has a history of ulcerative colitis. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. MRCP and Histopathological findings from liver biopsy are given below. Which condition is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)
 

Primary biliary cholangitis or
Primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC)
(Option B)

Seen in 30 years old; M>F

Seen in >50 years old; F>M

p-ANCA positive

p-ANCA is also seen in

  • Microscopic polyangitis
  • Churg Strauss syndrome
  • Ulcerative colitis
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis
  • Goodpasture syndrome
  • Pauci-immune glomerulonephritis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis

AMA(Anti-mitochondrial antibody) and ANA(anti-nuclear antibody) positive

Associated with ulcerative colitis, HLA-B8

Associated with Sjogren syndrome, scleroderma

Intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts are affected

Intrahepatic bile ducts affected

HPE: Concentric periductal fibrosis (Onion skin fibrosis)

  

Radiology: Pruning of small bile ducts; Strictures and beading of large bile ducts.

 

Radiology: Normal

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl has limited abduction of the left eye, with globe retraction and narrowing of the palpebral fissure on adduction and widening of the fissure on attempted abduction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Duane Retraction Syndrome Type I

 

Explanation:

  • The child presents with:
     
    • Limited abduction of the left eye
       
    • Globe retraction and narrowing of the palpebral fissure on adduction
       
    • Widening of the palpebral fissure on attempted abduction
       
  • This clinical picture is characteristic of Duane Retraction Syndrome (DRS) Type I, the most common subtype.
     

Duane Retraction Syndrome (DRS)

Feature

Type I

Type II

Type III

Abduction

Limited

Normal

Limited

Adduction

Normal or mildly limited

Limited

Limited

Globe Retraction

Present on adduction

Variable

Present on adduction

Palpebral Fissure on Adduction

Narrows

Slight change

Narrows

Palpebral Fissure on Abduction

Widens

No significant change

Slight change

Pathophysiology

Absent CN VI; CN III innervates LR

CN III innervates LR

Co-contraction of LR and MR
  • Type I is due to congenital absence or hypoplasia of the abducens nerve (CN VI). The lateral rectus is instead innervated by branches of the oculomotor nerve (CN III), causing co-contraction of the lateral and medial recti during adduction.
     

Key Clinical Findings in DRS Type I:

  • Eye fails to abduct normally
     
  • On adduction, the eye retracts into the orbit
     
  • Narrowing of the palpebral fissure due to globe retraction
     
  • Widening of the palpebral fissure during attempted abduction
     

Duane Retraction Syndrome Type II (Option B):
Incorrect because it shows limited adduction with normal abduction, which is the reverse of this case.

 

Duane Retraction Syndrome Type III (Option C):
Incorrect as both abduction and adduction are limited, not just abduction.

 

Sixth Cranial Nerve Palsy (Option D):
Incorrect because, although there is limited abduction, there is no globe retraction or palpebral fissure change on adduction.

questions.text: A 3-week-old neonate is brought to the dermatology OPD with facial rashes exacerbated by sunlight exposure. Examination reveals erythematous, scaly papules around the eyes as shown in the image below. Maternal history includes positive anti-Ro/SSA antibodies. Which congenital cardiac anomaly is commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer a. Heart block

 

Explanation:

  • A neonate presenting with facial rashes exacerbated by sunlight exposure, along with a maternal history of positive anti-Ro/SSA antibodies, is highly suggestive of neonatal lupus erythematosus (NLE).
  • NLE occurs when maternal autoantibodies, particularly anti-Ro/SSA antibodies, cross the placenta and affect the fetus.

Clinical features of Neonatal Lupus Erythematosus are:

  • Cutaneous: Rash resembling subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (SCLE) or discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE).
  • Owl’s eye sign or Racoon sign- Erythematous, slightly scaly eruption on the face and periorbital skin
  • Cardiac:
    • Various degrees of heart block, including first-degree, second-degree, or complete heart block.
    • A complete heart block may require pacemaker placement.
  • Hepatic involvement:
    • Hepatitis
    • cholestasis,
  • Hematological abnormalities:
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • Anemia
  • Neurological manifestations:
    • seizures
    • Developmental delay.
  • Respiratory manifestations:
    • Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)
    • Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN),

Anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies, also known as anti-SSA and anti-SSB antibodies are commonly implicated in neonatal systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and also Sjögren's syndrome.

 

Incorrect Answer Explanation

Option B: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is commonly seen in premature infants and is associated with conditions such as respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), and bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD).

 

Option C: Coarctation of the aorta can occur in the context of Turner syndrome.

 

Option D: Aortic stenosis occurs in Williams Syndrome (Chromosome 7 defect)

questions.text: Which of the following changes does not occur in fetal circulation following birth?

choices.text: Increase in mass and volume of the left ventricle
Increase in mass and volume of the right ventricle

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Increase in mass and volume of the right ventricle

 

Explanation:

After birth, the right ventricle's wall thickness and mass decrease due to the shift to low-resistance pulmonary circulation.

 

Changes in Fetal Circulation Following Birth:

 

Parameter/Structure

Change

Cause

Pulmonary Vascular Resistance (PVR)

Decreases

(Option A ruled out)

Mechanical expansion of the lungs and increased arterial PO2 lead to a rapid decrease in PVR.

Systemic Vascular Resistance (SVR)

Increases

The removal of the low-resistance placental circulation results in an increase in SVR.

Ductus Arteriosus Shunt

Reverses and eventually closes.
  • As PVR becomes lower than SVR, the shunt through the ductus arteriosus reverses from right-to-left to left-to-right.
  • High arterial PO2 leads to the constriction and eventual closure of the ductus arteriosus, which later becomes the ligamentum arteriosum.

Foramen Ovale

Closes

Increased pulmonary blood flow to the left atrium raises left atrial volume and pressure, leading to the functional closure of the foramen ovale.

Ductus Venosus

Closes

(Option C ruled out)

The removal of the placenta from circulation results in the closure of the ductus venosus.

Left ventricular Wall Thickness and Mass

Increases

(Option B ruled out)

The left ventricle's wall thickness and mass increase as it adapts to the high-resistance systemic circulation.

Right ventricular Wall Thickness and Mass

Decreases

(Option D)

The right ventricle's wall thickness and mass decrease as it adapts to the low-resistance pulmonary circulation.

Left Ventricular Output

Increases

The left ventricle now must deliver the entire systemic cardiac output, which is almost a 200% increase compared to fetal conditions.

Right Ventricular Output

Increases

Opening of pulmonary vasculature results in increased right ventricular output.

 

Time frame of closure of shunts following birth:

Shunt

Functional Closure

Anatomical closure

Remnant

Ductus Arteriosus

10-15 hrs after birth

2 -3 weeks after birth

Ligamentum arteriosum

Foramen ovale

3rd month

1 year after birth

Fossa ovalis

Ductus venosus

Immediately after birth

3-7 days after birth

Ligamentum venosum.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with hypertension and hypokalemia. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the genes coding for epithelial sodium channels (ENaCs). Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Liddle syndrome is characterized by hypertension and hypokalemia due to a mutation in the genes coding for epithelial sodium channels (ENaCs), leading to increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion.

Liddle Syndrome (Option B)

  • Rare genetic disorder causing high blood pressure and low potassium levels.
  • Caused by a mutation in genes coding for epithelial sodium channels (ENaCs) in kidneys.
  • Leads to increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion.

Hyperaldosteronism

  • Characterized by excessive aldosterone secretion.
  • Also a cause of high blood pressure and low potassium levels.
  • Classified into primary and secondary types.

Feature

Primary Hyperaldosteronism (Option A)

Secondary Hyperaldosteronism (Option D)

Cause

Adrenal gland disorders

High plasma renin activity conditions

Examples

Adenomas, adrenal hyperplasia, carcinoma, Glucocorticoid-Remediable Aldosteronism (Option C)

Cirrhosis, heart failure, nephrosis, salt-losing adrenogenital syndrome

Renin Activity

Suppressed

Elevated

GRA Mechanism

Hybrid gene sensitive to ACTH

Not applicable

ECF Volume

Normal or increased

Decreased

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a rule for criminally insane individuals?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Morrison's Rule

 

Explanation:

Morrison’s Rule is not a recognised rule related to the criminal responsibility of insane individuals.

Morrison's Rule states that after five months of fetal development, the crown-heel length in centimetres can be divided by five to estimate the fetal age in months. This provides a simple method for assessing gestational age based on fetal size.

 

Criminal responsibility of insane persons rules:

 

  • Durham’s Rule (1954): An accused is not criminally responsible if their unlawful act results from a mental disease or defect. (Option B ruled out)
  • Curren’s Rule (1964): An accused is not criminally responsible if, due to a mental disease or defect, they were unable to regulate their conduct according to the law at the time of the act. (Option A ruled out)
  • American Law Institute Test (1970): A person is not responsible for criminal actions if, due to mental disease or defect, they lack adequate capacity to understand the wrongfulness of their actions or to conform to legal requirements. (Option C ruled out)
  • Brawner Rule (1972): Insanity determinations should be made by a jury, which has the discretion to decide the "insanity question."
  • The Irresistible Impulse: This rule posits that an individual may recognize an act as illegal but, due to mental impairment, cannot control their actions. For example, Lorena Bobbitt was acquitted in 1994 by arguing that an irresistible impulse led her to commit her crime.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not typically associated with secondary congenital glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Angel man syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • Angelman Syndrome (AS) is a rare neurogenetic disorder caused by loss of function of the UBE3A gene on chromosome 15. 
  • Ophthalmic findings that can be seen in Angelman syndrome include Strabismus, Refractive errors, Oculocutaneous albinism, It is not associated with secondary glaucoma.

 

Secondary Developmental/ Congenital Glaucoma

Associated Ocular Anomalies

Associated Systemic Anomalies

Glaucoma Associated with Iridodysgenesis:

  • Congenital Ectropion Uvea
  • Congenital Microcornea
  • Congenital Nanophthalmos

Chromosomal Disorders:

  • Trisomy 13 (Patau Syndrome)
  • Trisomy 18 (Edward’s Syndrome)
  • Trisomy 21 (Down Syndrome)
  • Turner Syndrome (Option C ruled out)

Ectopia Lentis Syndromes:

  • Marfan Syndrome (Option B ruled out)
  • Weill-Marchesani Syndrome
  • Homocystinuria

Glaucoma Associated with Iridocorneal Dysgenesis:

  • Posterior Embryotoxon

Phakomatosis :

  • Sturge-Weber Syndrome

Metabolic Syndromes:

  • Zellweger Syndrome

questions.text: A 22-year-old farm worker presents with chronic diarrhoea, dermatitis over sun-exposed areas, weight loss, and recent-onset depression. Examination shows erythematous, scaly rash on chest. Blood glucose is 286 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Glucagonoma

  • The presence of elevated blood sugar along depression, dermatitis and diarrhoea points to diagnosis as Glucagonoma.

questions.text: The logo shown above represents a health scheme launched by the Government of India. What is the primary objective of this program?

choices.text: To provide comprehensive outbreak response essential drugs and diagnostic services.
To offer health insurance coverage to the economically disadvantaged
To reduce morbidity due to vaccine-preventable diseases in children
To promote accessible, affordable, and quality healthcare to the rural population

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) To offer health insurance coverage to the economically disadvantaged

Explanation:

The logo represents Ayushman Bharat-Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY), a scheme of the Government of India designed to provide health insurance coverage to economically disadvantaged families.

 

Ayushman Bharat - Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY):

  • An initiative launched in 2018 by Govt. of India to achieve UHC
  • Provides all the elements, including NCDS, in primary care.
  • Benefits:
    • Coverage: up to INR 5 lakh per family per year for secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
    • There is no restriction on the number of family members.
    • Cashless access across the country
    • All pre-existing conditions covered
    • Covers the cost of treatment, up to 3 days of pre-hospitalization and 15 days of post-hospitalization follow-up care.
  • Beneficiaries: Vulnerable and poor populations based on the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database.

Option A: Health and Wellness Centre, established under the National Health Policy in 2017, offers comprehensive health care, including maternal and child health, communicable disease, and non-communicable disease services, as well as free essential medications and diagnostics.

Option C: Mission Indradhanush aims to achieve more than 90% full immunization coverage and reduce child mortality and morbidity due to vaccine-preventable diseases.

Option D: The National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) provides accessible, affordable, and quality healthcare to the rural population, reducing mortality rates and disease transmission.

questions.text:
You are called by an ObGyn resident for the referral of care of a G2P1 woman with a known history of psoriasis, currently in her 2nd trimester. She is complaining of fever and malaise, and examination shows the following findings:



 

What could be a possible fetal complication in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C)Low birth weight

Explanation:

  • This patient with a known history of psoriasis and an image showing healing pustular lesions most likely has impetigo herpetifromis.
  • Impetigo herpetiformis is a rare and severe form of pustular psoriasis that typically occurs during pregnancy or postpartum.
  • It is characterized by widespread pustular eruptions with systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, and electrolyte imbalances.
  • A possible fetal complication in this patient with impetigo herpetiformis during the third trimester could be low birth weight, as the condition is associated with significant maternal and fetal risks, including intrauterine growth restriction and placental insufficiency.
  • Treatment includes
    • Admit the patient
    • IV Steroids/ Cyclosporine
    • Strict monitoring with appropriate IV fluids
    • Avoiding aggravating factors

 

No complications (Option A): Impetigo herpetiformis usually presents with fetal complications such as low birth weight and increased perinatal mortality.


Renal Agenesis (Option B):

  • It refers to the absence of one or both kidneys at birth, often leading to severe complications such as oligohydramnios, pulmonary hypoplasia, and an increased risk of urinary tract infections.
  • It is usually genetically inherited (Potter’s sequence) but could also be a complication of intake of ACE inhibitors or reno-toxic drugs during pregnancy.

Neonatal hypoglycemia (Option D):

  • It is characterized by low blood sugar levels in newborns, often due to inadequate glycogen stores or impaired glucose production.
  • It can lead to seizures, neurologic impairment, and long-term developmental issues if left untreated.
  • It is usually caused due to gestational diabetes mellitus.

questions.text:
Question:
A 22 y/o male with a history of worsening vision despite wearing rigid gas-permeable lenses now complains of increased visual distortion. O/E, his corneal topography shows progressive ectasia, and he is advised to consider treatment options to halt disease progression. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate to stabilize the condition and improve contact lens tolerance in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL)

 

Explanation:

  • The patient has keratoconus showing progressive ectasia.
  • Corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL) with riboflavin is the most appropriate treatment for stabilizing keratoconus progression and improving contact lens tolerance in this patient.
  • It works by strengthening the corneal stroma through the cross-linking of collagen fibers, which helps to halt the progression of ectasia, thereby preserving vision and enhancing the effectiveness of contact lenses.

Treatment of Keratoconus

  • Spectacle Correction (Option A):
    • Effective in the early stages, but contact lenses are more beneficial.
    • Less effective in later stages due to irregular astigmatism.
  • Contact Lenses:
    • Rigid gas permeable lenses improve vision in early cases.
    • Specially designed scleral lenses (e.g., Rose-K) are useful in early to moderate cases.
  • Corneal Collagen Cross-Linking (CXL):
    • New treatment modality to slow disease progression.
    • Involves riboflavin (0.1%) eye drops and UVA radiation.
  • Keratoplasty (Option D)
  • Intracorneal Ring Segments (INTACS) (Option B):
    • Effective in early to moderate cases by flattening the cornea.
    • Less effective in halting progression.

questions.text: Histopathological examination of a lesion arising from the right distal femur is given as the image below with such characteristic cells. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Osteoclastoma

 

Explanation:

The histopathological image shows numerous multinucleated giant cells, along with mononuclear cells scattered in the background in a bone lesion, suggesting osteoclastoma/giant cell tumour.

 

Giant cell tumour (Osteoclastoma):

  • It is a benign but locally aggressive tumour characterised by numerous multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells.
  • The neoplastic component is made up of the mononuclear cells, while the multinucleated giant cells are only a reactionary or secondary component.
  • Giant cell tumours develop within the epiphysis and may extend into the metaphysis.
    • Mostly located near the knee, involving the distal femur or proximal tibia.
    • Although rare, they can metastasize to the lungs, but typically regress spontaneously and are rarely fatal.
  • Morphology:
    • Grossly, the tumours are large, red-brown masses that frequently undergo cystic degeneration.

Chondrosarcoma (Option B): Shows malignant cartilage, which is recognised by the presence of multiple cartilage cells within a single lacuna,

Osteochondroma (Option C): It classically shows both bone (osteo) and cartilage components together.

Ewing’s sarcoma (Option D): This belongs to the group of small round blue cell tumors. On histology, we would see sheets of small blue cells and the characteristic Homer Wright pseudorosettes, none of which are seen here.

questions.text: Which of the following structures forms the lateral border of the superficial space of the urogenital triangle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ischial tuberosity

Explanation:

Ischial tuberosity bounds the urogenital triangle laterally.

 

Urogenital triangle is divided into two spaces by the perineal membrane:

  • Superficial space
  • Deep space

Boundaries of the Superficial Space:

  • Anterior: Pubic symphysis
  • Lateral: Ischial tuberosity (Option C)
  • Posterior: Dorsal border of superficial transverse perineal muscle and perineal membrane (Option A & D)
  • Superior: Pubic rami (Option B)

Space

Contents

Superficial Space
  • Bartholin glands
  • Vestibular bulbs
  • Clitoral body and crura
  • Pudendal vessels and nerve
  • Ischiocavernosus
  • Bulbospongiosus
  • Superficial transverse perineal muscles

Deep Space
  • Portions of urethra and vagina
  • Branches of Internal pudendal artery
  • Urogenital sphincter complex

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of resting tremor and muscular rigidity, more prominent on the left side. His gait is slow, and he has mild postural instability. Over the past 6 months, his family has noticed progressive forgetfulness, episodes of vivid visual hallucinations, and marked fluctuations in his alertness and cognition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Dementia with Lewy Bodies

  • The clinical history of vivid visual hallucinations and forgetfulness points to diagnosis of DLB. PD like features is seen in DLB also. Option B is ruled out as it seen after many years of PD.

questions.text: 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest discomfort for the past 3 hours. ECG shows ST depression in leads V4–V6. Troponin I is elevated. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes. BP is 130/80 mmHg, HR 88 bpm. Echocardiography shows mild LV dysfunction. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Start high-dose statin and discharge on dual antiplatelets
IV metoprolol and PCI is contraindicated

questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Administer intravenous eptifibatide and PCI

  • PCI is done in both STEMI and NSTEMI. This case is of lateral wall NSTEMI due to changes in lateral leads. These patients are given anti platelet drugs like Eptifibatide followed by PCI in high-risk cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with persistent nasal crusting and foul odour, unresponsive to medical treatment. Which procedure narrows the nasal cavity to reduce crusting?

choices.text: Use of 25% glucose in glycerine nasal application
Nasal irrigation with an alkaline solution

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lautenschlaeger technique

Explanation:

The patient is diagnosed with atrophic rhinitis, which is characterized by persistent nasal crusting and a foul odour due to the atrophy of the nasal mucosa.

 

The Lautenschlaeger technique specifically involves medial displacement of the lateral nasal wall to narrow the nasal cavities, which can help reduce crusting by improving airflow and humidifying the nasal passages in patients with atrophic rhinitis.

 

Treatment of Atrophic Rhinitis:

Treatment focuses on symptom management, especially foul smell and crusting, and aims to improve quality of life. Both medical and surgical approaches are used.

Medical Treatment:

Treatment

Details

Nasal Irrigation and Crust Removal
  • Use warm normal saline or an alkaline solution for nasal irrigation.
  • Irrigate multiple times daily initially, reducing to once every 2-3 days as symptoms improve.
  • For stubborn crusts, use glucose-glycerin solution before removal with forceps or suction.

Topical Applications

Apply 25% glucose in glycerine to inhibit proteolytic bacteria growth, reducing foul smell.

Antibiotics
  • Systemic antibiotics (e.g., fluoroquinolones with metronidazole) for 7-10 days.
  • Long-term use is not recommended.

Other Therapies
  • Mucolytics: Potassium iodide solutions to liquefy secretions.
  • Experimental: Oestradiol nasal sprays and submucosal placental extract injections have been explored.

Dietary Recommendations

A balanced diet rich in vitamins A, D, folic acid, iron, and protein to support overall health and mucosal recovery.

 

Surgical Treatment:

 

Procedure

Details

Young's Operation and Modifications
  • Complete closure of both nostrils in the nasal vestibule.
  • Reopen nostrils after approximately 6 months to encourage mucosal regeneration and reduce crusting.
  • Modified versions partially close nostrils to reduce discomfort while aiming for similar benefits.

Techniques to narrow excessively wide nasal chambers
  • Autologous grafts (fat, cartilage, bone) placed under the mucoperiosteum of nasal floor/lateral walls or mucoperichondrium of septum.
  • Allografts (Alloderm, Cymetra) can be used.
  • The Lautenschlaeger technique involves medial displacement of the lateral nasal wall to narrow nasal cavities which can help reduce crusting by improving airflow and humidifying the nasal passages. (Option D)

 

Young's operation and its modifications (Option A): Involves closing and then reopening the nostrils to promote mucosal regeneration and reduce crusting, not specifically for narrowing nasal cavities.

Use of 25% glucose in glycerine nasal application (Option B): Helps inhibit bacterial growth and reduce odour, not related to narrowing nasal cavities.

Nasal irrigation with an alkaline solution (Option C): Aimed at crust removal and odour reduction, not for narrowing nasal cavities.

questions.text: A 35 year old woman presents with severe breathlessness, palpitations, and swelling in her legs and face. She primarily eats white rice and lacks fruits and vegetables in her diet. On examination and investigations she has distended neck veins, peripheral edema, and elevated lactate and pyruvate levels. Thiamine deficiency is suspected. What is the most likely diagnosis, and which enzyme activity should be tested to confirm it?

choices.text: Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD); branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase

questions.solution:
Thiamine Deficiency

  • Aleurone layer of cereals (food grains) is a rich source of thiamine. Whole wheat flour and unpolished hand-pound rice have better nutritive value than completely polished refined foods.
  • Polishing grains removes the aleurone layer, reducing thiamine content.

Deficiency Manifestations

Dry Beriberi

  • More common CNS manifestations
  • Pain, paresthesia, and loss of reflexes
  • Peripheral neuritis with sensory disturbances (Option A ruled out)

Wet Beriberi

  • Cardiovascular symptoms: breathlessness, palpitations, and peripheral edema
  • Distended neck veins observed
  • High-output cardiac failure due to vasodilation (Option C)

Biochemical Parameters

  • Thiamine deficiency affects transketolase, an enzyme in the pentose phosphate pathway.
  • Measuring erythrocyte transketolase activity is a specific diagnostic test for thiamine deficiency (Option C).
  • Earliest biochemical change: Reduced erythrocyte transketolase activity, even before clinical symptoms appear.
  • Recommended Daily Allowance: 1–1.5 mg/day

Condition-Wise Role of Thiamine and Deficiency Effects

Condition Biochemical Role of Thiamine Deficiency Manifestations
Dry Beriberi (Option A ruled out) Essential for carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function Peripheral neuritis, sensory disturbances, difficulty walking, paralysis due to CNS involvement.
Wet Beriberi Thiamine is required for pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex; deficiency leads to lactic acidosis, causing vasodilation and cardiovascular symptoms Edema, palpitations, breathlessness, heart failure
Maple Syrup Urine Disease (Option B ruled out) Cofactor for decarboxylation of branched-chain keto acids Accumulation of branched-chain keto acids, causing convulsions, mental retardation, vomiting, acidosis, coma, and death
Lactic Acidosis (Option D ruled out) Cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase, which converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA Impaired pyruvate metabolism, leading to increased lactate and pyruvate, causing lactic acidosis

questions.text: Which of the following acts cannot be considered as rape?

choices.text: Inserting an article into the urethra
Manipulating any part of a woman’s body to cause penetration

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Penetrating wife without consent

Explanation:

In India, sexual intercourse by a man with his wife if she is not under 18 years of age (old definition not under 15 years) is not considered as rape.

Rape:

BNS

BNS 63 (Old: Section 375 IPC)

Definition

Unlawful sexual intercourse by a man with a woman through force or under certain conditions

Acts considered

  • Penetrates his penis into the vagina, mouth, urethra, or anus
  • Inserts any object or body part (not his penis) or applies his mouth to the vagina, mouth, urethra, or anus (Option A ruled out) (Option D ruled out)
  • Manipulates any part of the woman's body to cause penetration into the vagina, urethra, or anus (Option B ruled out)

Circumstances

  • Against her will
  • Without her consent
  • With her consent obtained through fear of death or hurt
  • With her consent, when she believes he is her husband due to impersonation
  • When she cannot understand the nature of consent due to unsoundness of mind, intoxication, or being drugged
  • Statutory rape: With or without her consent, if she is under 18 years of age
  • When she is unable to communicate consent

Exception

  • Medical interventions or procedures
  • Sexual intercourse by a man with his wife if she is not under 18 years of age (Option C)

questions.text: All of the following statements about Ankylosing Spondylitis are true EXCEPT:

choices.text: Infliximab is the drug of choice for refractory axial disease
Methotrexate is the first-line drug for axial spine involvement
Extra articular feature is aortic regurgitation due to aortic root involvement

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Methotrexate is the first-line drug for axial spine involvement

  • NSAIDS are used first line for axial spine involvement and not MTX.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of osteoporosis presents with severe bone pain and multiple vertebral fractures. She has previously undergone treatment that has failed. Which of the following bisphosphonates is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Zoledronate is a third-generation bisphosphonate known for its high potency and long-lasting efficacy after a single infusion.
  • It is indicated for the treatment of osteoporosis and the prevention and treatment of skeletal-related events in patients with metastatic bone disease.

BISPHOSPHONATES:

1st generation

2nd generation

3rd generation
  • Etidronate
  • Clodronate
  • Alendronate
  • Risedronate
  • Ibandronate
  • Zoledronic acid
  • Pamidronate

Mechanism of Action

Direct inhibition of osteoclast activity and bone resorption.

Frequency of administration

More potent drugs require less frequent administration

  • Alendronate: Given once a week.
  • Risedronate: Given once a week.
  • Ibandronate: Given once a month.
  • Zoledronate: Given once a year.

questions.text: Joll’s Triangle is used to identify which of the following nerves?

choices.text: External Branch of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve
Internal Branch of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) External Branch of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve

 

Explanation:

Joll’s Triangle is designed to help identify and preserve the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN) during surgery.

 

Joll’s Triangle (Sternothyroid-laryngeal triangle)

An anatomical landmark used for identifying and preserving the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN).

  • Superior border by the upper attachment of the strap muscles.
  • Medial border by the midline of the neck.
  • Lateral border by the upper pole of the thyroid gland and the superior thyroid vessels.
  • Floor of the Triangle: The EBSLN is located in the floor of the triangle, which is delineated by the cricothyroid muscle.


 

Joll’s Triangle is not used for locating the Recurrent laryngeal nerve (Option A) or Internal Branch of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve (Option C) or Vagus Nerve (Option D).

questions.text: A 28 year old woman, G2 P1 L1 at 38 weeks gestation is seen in early labor. She has a history of cesarean section done 3 years ago for breech presentation. The obstetrician decides on a cesarean section. Which of the following is NOT an indication for a cesarean section in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Gestational diabetes

 

Explanation:

Gestational diabetes that is well-controlled with diet and exercise alone is not an indication for a C-section. Women with GDM can often have a vaginal delivery if there are no other complications. If controlled, there is no significant risk to the mother or fetus.

Maternal Indications for Cesarean Delivery
  • Prior Cesarean Delivery: most common
  • Abnormal Placentation (Option A): Placenta previa and placenta accreta
  • Prior Classical Hysterotomy
  • Prior Uterine Incision Extension
  • Uterine Incision Dehiscence (Option B)
  • Prior Full-Thickness Myomectomy
  • Genital Tract Obstructive Mass
  • Invasive Cervical Cancer
  • Prior Trachelectomy
  • Permanent Cerclage
  • Prior Pelvic Reconstructive Surgery
  • Prior Significant Perineal Trauma
  • Pelvic Deformity
  • HSV or HIV Infection
  • Cardiac or Pulmonary Disease.
  • Cerebral Aneurysm or Arteriovenous Malformation: Increase the risk of a stroke
  • Pathology Requiring Concurrent Intraabdominal Surgery
  • Perimortem Cesarean Delivery
  • Non-reassuring FHR status (Option C)

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with diabetes arrives at the emergency department with sudden right-sided weakness and trouble speaking. His examination shows left-sided ptosis, the left eye in a "down and out" position, and right-sided paralysis of the lower face. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Weber’s syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • The presented case is diagnosed as Weber's Syndrome, which is characterized by right-sided hemiparesis, ight-sided paralysis of the lower face, left-sided ptosis and a "down and out" position of the left eye.
  • This syndrome impacts the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) nucleus and corticospinal fibers, leading to the loss of the medial lemniscus, red nucleus, superior cerebellar peduncle, and oculomotor nerve fibers.
  • Characteristic features:
    • Ipsilateral squint (pupil points downwards and laterally) due to injury to the oculomotor nerve.
    • Contralateral hemiplegia due to involvement of corticospinal tract.
    • Involvement of the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (riMLF) in the midbrain causes Weber syndrome with vertical gaze palsy.

Horner’s syndrome (Option A) is caused by damage to the cervical sympathetic trunk, which is characterized by:

  • Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid)
  • Miosis (constriction of the pupil)
  • Anhydrosis (loss of sweating on that side of the face)
  • Enophthalmos (retraction of the eyeball)
  • Loss of the ciliospinal reflex (pinching the skin on the nape of the neck does not cause pupil dilation, which typically occurs).


 

Benedikt’s syndrome (Option B) is due to damage to most of the tegmentum of the midbrain, which is characterized by:

  • Loss of proprioception due to the lesion of the medial lemniscus
  • The pupil points downwards and laterally due to injury to the third nerve
  • Tremors and twitching of opposite side due to damage to the red nucleus and superior cerebellar peduncle.



 

Parinaud’s syndrome (Option C) is due to a lesion of the superior colliculi (as shown in the above image), characterised by weakness of upward gaze and vertical nystagmus due to involvement of the superior colliculus.
